1229.1.text: Humans should stop eating animal meat.

1229.7.text: Consuming meat is an important part of many cultures and religions.

1229.12.text: Ceasing to eat meat would harm the economy.

1229.17.text: Vegetarian diets directly and indirectly contribute to better health outcomes for all humans.

1229.21.text: Eating meat, in the majority of cases, involves the cruel and immoral treatment of animals.

1229.68.text: The taste of meat is delicious and brings many people pleasure in a manner that vegetarian food cannot fully imitate.

1229.134.text: Eating meat is a key element of human nature, evolution, and physiology/biology and thus its consumption is inherent to humankind.

1229.2122.text: Ending the production of meat will be necessary in order to meet the growing food needs of the world's population.

1229.44.text: Some of the oldest forms of human expression and art are [cave paintings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cave_painting) of wild game, prey of humans. The chase and consumption of meat have therefore constituted a central component of human culture since its beginning.

1229.61.text: In the most world-renowned cuisines, meat plays a central part and is often the highlight dish.

1229.128.text: Cultural components change over time: cultural transformation is a natural dynamic process.

1229.174.text: In many cultures, a meatless diet plays an important cultural role.

1229.188.text: In some cultures, it is logistically very difficult to follow a meatless diet.

1229.774.text: Culture explains behavior but does not necessarily justify it.

1229.3564.text: Many religions explicitly permit or encourage eating animals.

1229.4891.text: A deliberate cultural evolution away from meat will overcome many current cultural issues with not eating meat.

1229.5049.text: Once a culture has the resources and technological knowhow to live in a way that avoids harms it previously needed for survival, that culture permanently progresses. Other cultures may have a valid argument for consuming meat or other [ESS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionarily_stable_strategy) such as raids involving murder of rival tribes' members. Western culture, with its great abundance and alternate foods, does not.

1229.157.text: Intensive livestock farming is economically bad for small farmers.

1229.470.text: Breeding livestock is necessary for many people \(particularly farmers\) to survive. Stopping this will eliminate their foundation of life.

1229.679.text: Global meat production is constantly [rising](http://www.worldwatch.org/global-meat-production-and-consumption-continue-rise-1). Worldwide meat production has tripled over the last four decades and increased 20% in just the last 10 years. This causes more jobs as the industry expands.

1229.773.text: According to a study, less meat would come with [economic benefits](http://www.pnas.org/content/113/15/4146.abstract) due to lower [healthcare costs](https://web.archive.org/web/20080517050751/http://www.worldwatch.org/press/news/1998/07/02/) and fewer lost workdays associated with deaths from specific diseases caused by poor diet, adding up to an impressive savings of between $700 and $1,000 billion annually.

1229.2141.text: If the externalities of meat were properly priced in, meat production would be far less economically efficient than the production of crops.

1229.2368.text: Whether or not something is good for the economy does not impact whether it is morally acceptable.

1229.2509.text: Keynesian economic theory deals pretty well with large fluctuations in commodities.

1229.2514.text: Ceasing to produce meat would be extremely harmful to low-income countries.

1229.2776.text: Systems-based agricultural models are often reliant on meat production, both as an ecological service and money maker. Ceasing meat production would limit those farmers from receiving both those benefits.

1229.2781.text: Animal agriculture is an important part of local food economies in cold climates where many crops are not available year-round.

1229.2819.text: If subsidies related to farming animals were removed, the demand for meat would decrease due to higher prices and lower supply; allowing for reduction in meat consumption without a very unpopular and difficult to regulate law.

1229.2841.text: In the short term, yes. In the long term not ceasing to waste land and continuing to emit massive amounts of unnecessary greenhouse gasses will incur devastating economic consequences.  Beyond this, optimizing the use of water and ending subsidies for animal agriculture would encourage inevitable growth in other sectors, something which companies like Best Foods have been [compelled to accept](http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-hellmanns-vegan-mayonnaise-20160202-story.html) and are now making vegan mayonnaise after losing their lawsuit over eggless Just Mayo.

1229.3078.text: Most of what we consume and buy today comes from animal production. It's not only about meat, it also concerns eggs, feathers, leather, but also candy. Stopping the production of meat will impact much more than the "Meat industry", and have a huge impact on global economy

1229.3434.text: Living beings should not be treated as commodities. It would be considered to be dehumanizing if applied to humans, and I believe similar emotional disconnection and distancing even from animals is a bad idea which leads to undesirable results \(abuses, desensitization to all harm including that done to humans, etc.\).

1229.3468.text: The economic impact may be manageable - it would not be the first time an industry has wound down, or been shut down or suppressed.

1229.5250.text: Meat keeps food prices high \(due to supply and demand\). With meat taking resources, such as land and water, the food supply is limited for consumers, which pushes the prices higher for food. [This is good for the economy because if food prices go too low, farmers run into difficulties covering their costs.](http://economics.fundamentalfinance.com/micro_price-floor.php)

1229.5528.text: Meat raises food prices for consumers. Livestock eat grains, which drives up demand for them.

1229.2571.text: Many people across the world depend on meat as part of their diet, and ending meat eating would lower food security/diversity for the majority of people.

1229.6451.text: Ceasing to eat meat would increase the economy. Exporting the grains fed to livestock in the US would increase the trade balance by $80 billion. [news.cornell.edu](http://news.cornell.edu/stories/1997/08/us-could-feed-800-million-people-grain-livestock-eat)

1229.4458.text: This is an advantage as financial pressure is a force for change.

1229.6869.text: Slavery was the backbone of the economy in the past. Slavery was defended by economic interests throughout the life of human civilization until the time of the Industrial Revolution. From today's point of view, advocating slavery with economic interests seems absurd, and it can also be associated with the enslavement of other creatures.

1229.6870.text: Restricting or replacing meat leads to projects that, with the help of state-of-the-art sciences, create [innovative solutions](http://web.unep.org/championsofearth/laureates/2018/impossible-foods-and-beyond-meat) that [drive society](https://www.unenvironment.org/news-and-stories/story/tackling-worlds-most-urgent-problem-meat) in many ways \(economic, moral, environmental, health, jobs, technology etc.\).

1229.2051.text: Scientists have concluded that vegetarian diets can in fact [provide benefits](http://freefromharm.org/featured-articles/catching-up-with-science-burying-the-humans-need-meat-argument/) in the treatment and prevention of certain diseases.

1229.2090.text: People who must already follow [restrictive diets](http://www.ibsdiets.org/fodmap-diet/fodmap-food-list/) due to medical conditions such as IBS or IBD cannot consume most plant-based or dairy sources of protein, making it necessary for them to resort to meat-based proteins.

1229.65.text: Meat consumption itself is not unhealthy. It strongly depends on the [amount](http://www.nhs.uk/Livewell/Goodfood/Pages/meat.aspx) consumed as well as its origin - whether it is from industrial livestock farming or organic farming.

1229.2406.text: Eating meat is linked to increased risks for certain types of cancer.

1229.2410.text: The farming of meat can fuel the spread of disease and ingestion of drugs that may pose significant risks to human health.

1229.5.text: Meat effectively delivers important nutrients for humans.

1229.1682.text: [Statistically](http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article/asset?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0088278.PDF) those who abstain from a meat based diet are exposed to higher health risk hazards.

1229.597.text: Meat-eaters suffer more frequently from various types of [food poisoning](http://www.celestialhealing.net/physicalveg3.htm) than vegetarians.

1229.427.text: Living without meat reduces [metabolic risk](http://care.diabetesjournals.org/content/34/5/1225.abstract) factors and thus reduces the likelihood of strokes, diabetes, and heart conditions.

1229.1735.text: Not all vegetarians have a healthy diet. There is a lot of meatless junk food available. Hence, an absence of meat in a diet does not equal a healthier diet.

1229.74.text: The [fact](http://qz.com/91123/vegetarians-live-longer-but-its-not-because-they-dont-eat-meat/) that vegetarians live longer \(up to nine years\) is not only due to their meatless diet, but also to the fact that they are more likely to exercise, smoke less and drink less alcohol.

1229.2824.text: When looking at smaller sample sizes and more diverse diets there is little to suggest that meat is inherently unhealthy.

1229.4723.text: Meat consists of a lot of protein. Therefore, its consumption leads to increased intake of protein. [The China Study](https://www.amazon.co.uk/China-Study-Comprehensive-Nutrition-Implications/dp/1932100660) measured the ideal daily intake to be 8 to 10 percent, whereas most people consume twice as much.

1229.5465.text: Avoidance of all meat is a luxury good, only realistic in a healthy manner, in rich societies. In poor societies practicing vegetarianism, it often correlates with malnutrition. In most societies, this claim is both arrogant and moralizing, condemning poor countries to malnutrition, contributing to expanding in equality.

1229.5651.text: Vegetarian foods are nutritionally superior to meat.

1229.5895.text: Meat is dangerous in that it increases the risk of injuries to those who eat meat.

1229.6479.text: Whether or not people have better or worse health outcomes due to their diet is irrelevant to the claim that people should completely stop eating meat. It is only an argument to restructure health policy to reduce meat consumption or encourage veganism.

1229.6632.text: Vegetarian diets are only more beneficial for the health of an individual if they are [well balanced](https://www.webmd.com/food-recipes/tc/vegetarian-diets-how-can-vegetarians-eat-a-balanced-diet), [and if compared to an unbalanced omnivorous diet.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3967195/) The essence in the question of health is not that which is more healthier: eating, or not eating animal related products, but the overall quality and composition of a diet.

1229.6800.text: A substantial population require meat in their diet for health reasons, as thousands of [stories show](http://meatheals.com/).

1229.6872.text: [All diets](https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article/95/3/614/4578300) generally lead to better health outcomes compared to people who do not follow a restrictive diet, because people on a diet make conscious decisions about their food.

1229.6885.text: A vegetarian diet might lead to better health outcomes, but for some who live in countries where getting vegan/vegetarian food easily isn't an option, a non-veg diet is a trade off between health and convenience.

1229.114.text: The meat industry has harmful effects on the physical and mental health of its workers. Eradication of this industry would reduce these harms.

1229.10683.text: Many populations across the globe lack the practical availability of alternative nutritional sources such as many of the [East African](https://www.intechopen.com/chapters/74388) countries.

1229.10836.text: Meat contains some [nutrients](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/7-nutrients-you-cant-get-from-plants#1.-Vitamin-B12) such as vitamin D3 and omega-3 fatty acids which are absent in a plant based diet.

1229.8.text: All animals have a right to live and be free of suffering.

1229.34.text: The common practices underlying the production of meat \(massive livestock farming\) are unethical.

1229.40.text: Unlike other animals, humans are morally conscious of their behaviour and are thus subject to [moral standards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morality), meaning they cannot justify meat consumption on the basis of \(arguments such as\) convenience or their own mental superiority.

1229.988.text: Not eating the meat of animals killed for other purposes would be a waste and thus morally wrong.

1229.1404.text: While much meat farming is cruel, it does not have to be. Ethical consumers could choose only to buy from ethical sources \(i.e. free range farming\) that afford animals the same \(if not better\) quality of life than they would have had in the wild, and a painless death.

1229.2917.text: For most people, eating meat is needless and the needless killing of beings with a will to live is immoral.

1229.3093.text: Conscious vegetarianism facilitates compassion towards other living beings and discourages us from viewing them as mere ingredients to a recipe.

1229.3337.text: Morality is subjective, so eating meat is not necessarily immoral.

1229.3663.text: Ceasing to eat meat would mean that vast quantities of livestock would die without being replaced as they are unable to survive effectively outside of human agriculture.

1229.3810.text: A great many human activities cause the deaths of animals. A focus on meat leads to moral inconsistency and potential hypocrisy.

1229.5113.text: Given that meat is still the primary food source for many people in less fortunate countries. Given that human bodies vary wildly in which foods they will process more efficiently. Given that some conditions will actually make eating plant only foods a negative life choice for many. It is cruel and immoral to presume that no human should eat meat under any circumstances. The above claim completely ignores the quality of life of other humans, making the claim itself cruel and immoral.

1229.5107.text: Eating meat is not immoral; the production of meat can be cruel but the consumption is not.

1229.5168.text: Consuming vegetables is also cruel to both the plants and to the workers responsible for the agricultural process.

1229.5298.text: If everyone who cares about the ethical treatment of animals were to stop eating meat, then the only people farming and consuming meat would be those who lack compassion for the animals. Human's relationship with nature should be one of mutual respect and compassion - this will never happen if those who would put this in practice choose instead to have no symbiotic relationship with nature at all.

1229.5548.text: We should not rely on other lives \(such as eating animals\) to progress our own. Finding a way to not depend on others for people's existence allows for independence. Then people will not feel compelled to resort to cruelty to survive.

1229.5620.text: The effects of this cruel treatment are twofold. Not only does it involve the suffering and murder of billions on an annual basis but also negatively impacts the environment \(methane and phosphorous outputs, deforestation\). Ultimately hurting non-domestic animal species and ourselves in the process

1229.5809.text: Take the flesh that the average meat eater consumes and make them take the action of the rearing and slaughtering of the life form behind that flesh, other than letting a fish suffocate most today would find themselves unable. A wrong they can not replicate if not delegated.

1229.6611.text: So many people are worried about animals but don't even think twice when walking by a homeless person on the streets. It's preposterous. How about we worry about our own kind first and then start talking about animals.

1229.6814.text: The statement is unclear as it is not specified what the "majority of cases" are. What delineates those from the others, supposedly not cruel or not immoral?

1229.6815.text: Moral values are typically pertinent to particular individuals, groups, religions or schools of thought. There are no universally accepted moral values that condemn eating meat or treating animals in any particular way. Therefore the statement that eating meat can involve immoral treatment, is false.

1229.6824.text: The ignorance and confusion about how animals are treated may have been deliberately caused by the meat industry [lack of transparency](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/10/09/magazine/meat-industry-transparency-fight.html) and [misleading advertising.](https://www.ecowatch.com/dairy-industry-facts-2525727633.html)

1229.6826.text: For those who eat meat, it may also mean that they neither have a developed empathy nor a developed compassion - leaving farm animals out of their [circles of compassion](https://www.brainpickings.org/2016/11/28/einstein-circles-of-compassion/), or just that they don't have [reliable sources of information](https://www.viva.org.uk/blog/meat-myths). \(e.g. ["suicide food".](https://suicidefood.blogspot.com/)\)

1229.6825.text: Relating to the standards of good behaviour \(not killing / not imprisoning\), fairness \(not profiting on others pain / not imposing artificial insemination to females or robbing them their byproducts -eggs or milk\), and honesty \(not enslaving entire species -farm animals / not robbing other intelligent and sentient beings offspring to subdue them as well\), [i.e. morals](https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/moral), eating meat is wrong, especially when there are [alternatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_meat_substitutes).

1229.2000.text: Farming vegetarian products also directly or indirectly harms animals in the process of crop production and harvest.

1229.5313.text: Since meat eating is in human nature, it cannot be immoral.

1229.10636.text: It is now possible to grow meat without the animal, therefore this argument's effectiveness is beginning to diminish.

1229.2001.text: As animals lack rights, it is morally permissible to raise them for slaughter.

1229.72.text: It is because the taste of meat is so good and popular that scientists try to imitate it and create vegetarian "meat" products.

1229.1412.text: Non-meat products can offer an equivalently pleasing food experience.

1229.342.text: Meat is convenient and consumer friendly.

1229.4660.text: Popularity and pleasure has no relevance to what is right or wrong.

1229.5728.text: It is not clear that the additional pleasure \(if any\) of eating a meal containing meat compared to eating a meal without outweighs the suffering of the animal bred, raised and killed for their meat.

1229.5997.text: Pleasure is important to human quality of life, so if meat consumption is more pleasurable than anticipated, abstinence could have a meaningful negative impact on quality of life. The overwhelming popularity of meat throughout almost all cultures could be an indication that eating meat is enormously pleasurable.

1229.6400.text: What people commonly refer to the "taste of meat" is directly linked to one of the five basic tastes: [umami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umami). This taste can also be found in [vegetable foods](https://www.onegreenplanet.org/vegan-food/how-to-add-umami-flavor-to-vegan-dishes/) such as miso, seaweeds, tomatoes, mushrooms and many others, thus providing an alternative way to achieve satisfying flavors without animal protein.

1229.6748.text: Eating other animals \(human beings are animals\) is not necessary for our survival, it's for our pleasure, and this pleasure has to be balanced with the cost of the victims, which is too high \(suffering and death\).

1229.10790.text: [Cultured meat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellular_agriculture#Meat) will likely soon be available to the general public, scale up over time and taste similar.

1229.139.text: Buying and consuming processed meat from intensive livestock farming is anything but natural.

1229.181.text: Just like other conceptions of what is natural, the idea of eating meat as being natural is socially constructed and subject to change.

1229.62.text: The [consumption](http://www.livescience.com/24875-meat-human-brain.html) of \(cooked\) meat was crucial for the development of the human brain. Therefore you can state that eating meat is what made humans what they are today.

1229.861.text: Early humans were known as [hunter-gatherers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter-gatherer), not only gatherers. Therefore hunting animals and consuming their meat was something typical human from the very beginning.

1229.1266.text: There is no reason to assume that a natural lifestyle is essential \(healthwise or morally\), as there are plenty of reasons for humans to follow an "unnatural" lifestyle.

1229.2635.text: Meat has historically been both valuable for our technological progression, and necessary to continued human existence, it is not clear that that value has ended.

1229.4455.text: Being that we're classified as omnivores, consuming meat would best be described as functional and significant, but not "central" to our existence.

1229.4864.text: There are many other things which could be argued to be "a central part of human nature and biology and thus inherent to humankind" which we do not \(continue to\) do.

1229.165.text: The brain's circuits are designed to generate behaviour that is appropriate to our survival. Generally, beings find things tasty that their system needs, as the brain tells them [unconsciously](https://books.google.de/books?id=nkPj3dNFYwoC&redir_esc=y). Thus we can conclude: meat tastes good because it is useful.

1229.5996.text: Low retention rates among vegetarians could be an indication that the majority of people cannot [consistently abstain](http://skeptoid.com/blog/2011/10/16/lapsed-vegetarians-or-return-of-the-meat-eaters/)(What made them return to their omnivorous ways? Reasons fell into one of five categories: health, hassle, cravings, social and ethical. A full thirty-five percent of participants indicated that declining health was the main reason they reverted back to eating flesh. To quote one participant, "I was very weak and sickly. I felt horrible even though I ate a good variety of foods like PETA said to." Another states, "My doctor recommended that I eat some form of meat as I was not getting any better. I thought it would be hypocritical of me to just eat chicken and fish as they are just as much an animal as a cow or pig. So I went from no meat to all meat." One particularly blunt fellow said, "I will take a dead cow over anemia any time.") from eating meat. If this is the case, expecting humans to abstain from meat consumption [contradicts](https://sawer.medium.com/kant-the-vegan-3cf0b6420913)(As we saw -one- Kant was not vegan. And -two- Kant reserves the enablement of the categorical imperative to reasonable beings alone, meaning beings who not only act according to laws \(which, for example, a stone can do when falling from a cliff face into the valley below\), but that also have the ability to act in accordance with representations of laws. This means being capable of subjecting their own will to principles. No rocks, no plants, and, in his mind, no animals.) the [categorical imperative](https://sawer.medium.com/kant-the-vegan-3cf0b6420913)(Act only according to that maxim whereby you can at the same time will that it should become a universal law.) and thus cannot be unethical, or "wrong" to eat meat.

1229.5356.text: As a vegetarian diet can satisfy our nutritional needs, there's no need for most humans to eat meat.

1229.10782.text: [Animal meat is one of the richest, natural sources of protein](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/high-protein-foods#summary), which is crucial for the growth and development of people’s body

1229.2163.text: The production of meat consumes disproportionately more resources than the production of crops.

1229.2172.text: Given current methods of agricultural production, the world will be unable to meet growing food demand. It is therefore urgent that we increase agricultural productivity by producing less meat.

1229.2174.text: There are various ways to exploit existing agricultural resources more efficiently to meet food demands.

1229.3941.text: There are over 7 billion people on the planet and we are not able to responsibly care for all of them. The correct choice of action is to lessen the population to manageable sizes. Ideally, the most intelligent course of action would be to lessen the population to the point where factory farms are not needed.

1229.4613.text: Moderation rather than prohibition should suffice; for any population level there is, mathematically speaking, an amount of meat that can be sustainably consumed \(e.g., each person eating meat twice per week might be sustainable for 7 billion people\).

1229.4644.text: [Meat is an unnecessary luxury food](https://makewealthhistory.org/2007/04/23/meat-is-a-luxury/) in a world of [food wastage](https://static5.businessinsider.com/image/56e1b879dd0895bb478b467d-960/ti_graphics_food-waste-regions-map.png) and [localized oversupply](https://assets.weforum.org/editor/KAPPoMvLpzHTC3IVCkz3T14jpvXwPAP7Z5eZubq6fr0.jpg).

1229.4982.text: We live in the 21st century and should progress out of the less civilized ways of living such as eating meat. The vegetarian movement will lead to more innovation as the meat industry ages and becomes obsolete. Humanity could advance ideas such as [feeding the future population](https://www.forbes.com/sites/ronaldholden/2017/11/04/its-called-vertical-farming-and-it-could-be-the-future-of-agriculture/#f787ccf11752) and [colonizing other planets](https://phys.org/news/2017-03-food-mars-earth-nasa-usu.html) when moving away from meat.

1229.5091.text: Just because something potentially becomes a problem in the future does not alone require it to stop today.

1229.5253.text: The land and water supply [is so low already](http://www.worldwatch.org/node/554) that soon we will have to find food sources that do not so heavily rely on agriculture.

1229.5545.text: Once someone eats a plant, they can use the [scraps to grow new food](https://www.diyncrafts.com/4732/repurpose/25-foods-can-re-grow-kitchen-scraps). Regenerating food takes pressure off the food system. The same cannot be said for meat.

1229.5916.text: Hunger and starvation worldwide [have been in decline even with a growing population until recently](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/global-hunger-rising-after-decade-decline-who-report/) and the recent increase is caused by war and global warming. Nothing indicates this growth to be a result of less meat production.

1229.6256.text: The growing food needs of the world's population can be met whether or not we stop meat production.

1229.10538.text: Population growth is slowing down for last half century [ourworldindata.org](https://ourworldindata.org/world-population-growth)

1229.4973.text: Supplies of [seafood](http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1533125/All-seafood-will-run-out-in-2050-say-scientists.html) and [meat](http://www.quantumrun.com/prediction/vegetarians-will-reign-supreme-after-meat-shock-2035-future-food-p2) are likely to run out in the future.

1229.10634.text: These claims fail to account for growing innovations. When problems and needs arrive, innovation to meet the demands does as well. This argument is much like Paul R. Ehrlich's, who wrote in the late 1960's The Population Bomb. Paul warned that growing population was unsustainable and the world would fall into massive starvation. However, time has proven him wrong. There is less starvation now than in the 1960's.

1229.2074.text: Eating and producing meat heavily contributes to climate change.

1229.209.text: Farming animals has severe impacts on the local environment due to its heavy resource use and impact upon the landscape.

1229.4384.text: Consumers can choose to purchase meat that is farmed in an environmentally friendly manner.

1229.5403.text: "Animals" is an overly broad term which includes creatures with a high range of mental capacity/complexity. Banning the consumption of lower orders of animals is not necessarily the same as banning the consumption of high level mammals.

1229.280.text: The [species](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cave_painting#Subjects.2C_themes_and_patterns) found most often in cave paintings were suitable for hunting by humans, but were not necessarily the actual typical prey found in associated deposits of bones. The most common animal hunting and meat consumption practices in the stone-age have not, therefore, necessarily made significant contribution to this part of human cultural history.

1229.797.text: There is no necessary correlation between a particular cuisine, restaurant or dish's level of prestige and whether it includes meat or not.

1229.2637.text: If eating meat is too far abandoned before artificial replacements can suitably be found, culinary arts developed over centuries may be lost.

1229.2840.text: Something being tasty does not justify torturing animals or destroying the environment. Jeffrey Dahmer used humans as the central piece of his meals. Protecting that culinary option for him was not more important than protecting the lives of those he would destroy.

1229.3050.text: Culinary styles and traditions change and evolve over time. If the world stops eating meat, international cuisines will adapt to that fact.

1229.3272.text: Most world-renowned cuisines developed seasoning and preparations to make up for the lack of meat or mask the deficiencies of poor quality scraps. What makes them world renowned is not the meat ingredients, it's everything else around it.

1229.3678.text: Bacon. Whenever there is a debate about not eating meat, bacon is quite a strong argument for the case that eating meat brings more taste and pleasure than most plant based foods.

1229.2598.text: When meat is the main focus of a meal, it is often marinated, covered in sauces, seasonings, cheese, and vegetables to enhance its taste. It is those things that are delicious, not the meat itself.

1229.3794.text: An increase in vegetarianism would generate newer and better vegetarian foods, recipes and cooking techniques, which could rival the pleasure generated from meat-based meals.

1229.6709.text: Maybe it is not because it's the tastiest food, it could also be that it is the most exclusive, expensive and a symbol of power and wealth.

1229.827.text: Western \(European\) culture began to undergo rapid changes starting with the arrival of Columbus in the [New World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Revolution), and continuing with the [Industrial Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Revolution).

1229.828.text: Cultures around the world are undergoing [transformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformation_of_culture#Environmental_stresses_and_impacts_on_cultures) due to environmental stresses, such as [climate change](http://Cultures around the world are undergoing change due to environmental stresses, such as climate change.).

1229.276.text: Eating habits change, and meat has not always been an integral part of most cultures. Only [relatively recently](http://www.colostate.edu/Dept/GDPE/Distinguished_Ecologists/2006/Smil/Eating%20Meat.pdf) has the consumption of meat become wide-spread, for example during the mid-19th century in Europe and not until the mid-20th century in large parts of China.

1229.330.text: Convictions surrounding different foodstuffs, and their corresponding cultural importance, change over time.

1229.792.text: Humans' meat consumption patterns today are not the same as those of their stone-age ancestors. Naturally, the kind of hunting and consumption of meat practised by stone-age humanoids does not, therefore, hold the same importance in modern-day culture.

1229.2627.text: Cultural transformation should not be forced and attempts to do so rarely succeed, cultures only transform gradually as a result of natural processes.

1229.3544.text: The 21st century's marked by globalism and increasing interconnectivity of all cultures. In other words, a global culture is the new paradigm. The interconnectivity of our actions obligate us to behave in a way that is sustainable for all subsidiary cultures. Using one culture's norms as justification for a practice that harms the global society is not an adequate response. This debate, and Kialo in general, is the articulation of a global society working out its ethos in a dialectical process.

1229.175.text: India has one of the lowest rates of annual meat consumption per head at [about 10%](http://chartsbin.com/view/12730) of the world's average. About [40%](http://www.fao.org/WAIRDOCS/LEAD/X6170E/x6170e09.htm) of households eat a vegetarian diet.

1229.176.text: Vegetarian culture is prevalent in Taiwan due to the country's Buddhist heritage and visible in the popularity of [vegetarian days](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegetarianism_by_country#Taiwan) every week and strict [food-labeling laws](http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/national/national-news/2009/06/09/211405/All-vegetarian.htm).

1229.548.text: Just like the formerly low rates of meat consumption in many of today's rich countries were driven by poverty and a lack of affordable meat rather than culture, so is vegetarianism in many developing countries more of an economic than a cultural reality. People would eat meat if only they could.

1229.4655.text: Not [harming animals](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4093044/) is also an important part of many cultures.

1229.5345.text: According to the Biblical apocrypha original Christians were vegetarians \(as well as alcohol abstainers\). [Article with multiple quotes](https://medium.com/sant-mat-meditation-and-spirituality/evidence-that-jesus-and-the-original-aramaic-christians-were-vegetarians-b8784ac42506) and [a book](https://www.amazon.com/Gospel-Jesus-Search-Original-Teachings/dp/185230720X) for reference.

1229.10655.text: [Ethiopian Christians](https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/vegetarian-diet-beginners-coronavirus-wellness/index.html) refrain from eating meat for 250 days of ever year.

1229.262.text: The general trend shows [meatless](http://www.mfablog.org/veganism-taking-the-world-by-storm) diet is on the rise all over the world.

1229.291.text: As a meatless diet does not restrict people in any common social situations it cannot be insociable.

1229.363.text: In many countries, restaurants often serve not a variety of dishes, but variants of a single dish. If this dish is not meatless, it either excludes vegetarians, or requires groups with 1 or more vegetarians among them to actively avoid these restaurants when eating out, restricting choice on social venues for all involved.

1229.365.text: In many countries - for example [China, Japan. and Korea](https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=uMnubkF5HjAC&pg=PA3&dq=vegetarianism+concept+korea&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=vegetarianism%20concept%20korea&f=false) - meatless diets are not widely popular and recognized, hence maintaining a meatless diet is not entirely feasible.

1229.369.text: There are many meat eaters which have certain food preferences and will not ever eat certain dishes. However nobody would say they are unsociable because of that.

1229.461.text: People with certain food allergies / intolerances \([Coeliac disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coeliac_disease), [lactose intolerance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lactose_intolerance), histamine intolerance, nut allergies etc.\) will not ever eat certain dishes, but noone would say they are insociable because of that.

1229.730.text: Among all cultures there are people who do not eat certain kinds of meat for [religious reasons](http://www.chewfo.com/philosophical-reasons-for-food-choices/religious-dietary-restrictions/) and they do not seem to be stigmatized as insociable.

1229.4871.text: The solution to this would be to minimize the stigmatization and increase the availability of meatless diets, not embrace eating meat.

1229.821.text: The argument that something is part of a dominant culture was used to justify numerous evils of human history, from racism to corruption and the suppression of minorities.

1229.902.text: According to [moral absolutism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_absolutism), particular actions are intrinsically right or wrong.

1229.897.text: As there are no absolute standards for judging right and wrong, good and bad, as these terms are products of social agreement, individuals can only use their culture and the values / attitudes it has created for moral guidance. From this point of view, the dominant culture thus explains and justifies behavior.

1229.984.text: The amounts of culturally-prescribed meat, for example at rituals, are limited and thus come with marginal negative effects. There is nothing to justify.

1229.1462.text: The fact that eating meat is natural or inherent to human culture does not imply that we ought to eat it. According to Hume, it is a fallacy to make claims about what [ought to be](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Is%E2%80%93ought_problem) \("we ought to eat meat"\) on the basis of statements about what is \("it is natural to eat meat"\).

1229.2839.text: "Culture" is not important. Cultural behaviors can be positive or negative. The practice of female genital mutilation is not something we should strive to protect simply because it is part of the culture. Slavery was our culture once. People fought and died to preserve that culture, yet the culture was wrong, just as the culture of eating animal products is.

1229.3543.text: The cultural basis for meat consumption originated in hunter gatherer times. We no longer live in hunter gather societies and therefore dietary custom is an antiquated justification for meat consumption. Hunter gatherer meat consumption is more justified than agrarian meat consumption because meat was a scarcity that had to be earned; consequently it was the highlight of the meal. The amount of meat consumed is unnatural and is therefore at odds with the foundation of this cultural argument.

1229.3748.text: Slavery was once accepted by the society and their culture. This does not mean it is morally justified.

1229.4140.text: Not all cultural or religious values should be respected.  They are not equally valid.

1229.5163.text: People live traditionally and rarely stop to ask whether our traditions are blinding us from the reality of the cruel way we indirectly treat certain animals. At the root of their treatment is discrimination, which leads to exploitation and abuse. Eating animals in the modern world is cruel because it is no longer necessary to eat animals to survive and live a healthy life. If these animals we not bred into existence, there would be no need for them to exist in the wild.

1229.5716.text: Eating meat was necessary for survival. Many meat-eating cultures have some inherent respect for the animals they eat. If there is no longer a necessity to eat meat to survive, the slaughter is purely for gratification; we should reduce our consumption, and develop other ways of fulfilling our recreational eating desires.

1229.6238.text: More humans eat meat than choose to abstain from eating meat, and most abstention is poverty based. Whilst non-meat eaters are the more vocal and empassioned cohort on this issue, this does not make them the majority and societal intersubjective truths are generally determined by majority thought constructs. In other words, eating meats is okay because most humans believe it to be okay.

1229.6686.text: It's not ethically wrong since the definition of "Ethical" is "A set of moral values and principles that guide the human conduct in the society". Knowing that, the most part of the society eat meat and don't see any problem in this. We can declare it not ethically wrong.[Ethical Definition \( Brazil Website \)](https://www.suapesquisa.com/o_que_e/etica_conceito.htm)

1229.3553.text: According to Mormonism, God [created animals for our use, to eat sparingly](https://www.lds.org/scriptures/dc-testament/dc/89).

1229.3558.text: Biblical citations and religious assertions alone are not reasoned evidence.

1229.3832.text: As this is a moral statement, with no declarable moral code defined, the Bible even from a atheistic view is valid here. For example,  \(Romans 14\): "As for the one who is weak in faith, welcome him, but not to quarrel over opinions. 2 One person believes he may eat anything, while the weak person eats only vegetables. 3 Let not the one who eats despise the one who abstains, and let not the one who abstains pass judgment on the one who eats, for God has welcomed him."

1229.4308.text: In the Bible, God granted the animals to Noah and his family after the flood, saying "The fear of you and the terror of you will be on every beast of the earth and on every bird of the sky; with everything that creeps on the ground, and all the fish of the sea, into your hand they are given. Every moving thing that is alive shall be food for you; I give all to you, as I gave the green plant. Only you shall not eat flesh with its life, that is, its blood."

1229.5067.text: Meat was created by God for the righteous use of all of us, his children. The scriptures are eloquent, clear, and common sense on this topic. [1st Timothy Chapter 4 Verses 1-16](https://www.lds.org/scriptures/nt/1-tim/4?lang=eng)

1229.5251.text: In the Bible, God tells Adam and Eve not only to have dominion over all animals, but he also gives instruction in the mosaic law as to what types of animals you can and can’t eat. There are dozens more religions that promote certain diets that include meat.

1229.5849.text: Jainism encourages vegetarianism on the basis of ahimsa which is the principle of nonviolence and noninjury and is, in the case of Jains, applied to all beings.

1229.5884.text: If God created some living beings subservient to others, this would indicate God doesn't care about the welfare of some of his creations.

1229.5887.text: An omnibenevolent God would not create living beings that have the capacity to suffer with the purpose of being eaten and abused which results in suffering.

1229.6294.text: If the temple in Jerusalem ever gets rebuilt, there will be a need of sacrifices there. That involves killing animals.

1229.158.text: As intensive farms are highly mechanized \(requiring little manual labor\) their introduction into rural areas tends to [reduce](http://thegreentimes.co.za/negative-impacts-of-factory-farming/) rural employment. In the U.S., for example, the number of farm workers has dropped 80% over the past 50 years.

1229.274.text: Intensive livestock farming is not the only option for small farmers. They can easily specialize in alternatives, such as organic livestock farming.

1229.2488.text: The negative effects of mass-production on smaller retailers is true of most industries, it is not particular to livestock farming.

1229.3686.text: Some farms are only useful for livestock rearing. For example farms on areas of clay which cannot be ploughed. The farmers can only earn a living on small farms if they rear livestock intensively.

1229.680.text: Of the 880 million rural poor people living on less than $1 per day, 70% are partially or completely [dependent](http://www.worldwatch.org/global-meat-production-and-consumption-continue-rise-1) on livestock for their livelihoods.

1229.1303.text: Stopping meat production would come along with an increasing production of substitutes, such as vegetables, crops and fruits. This creates new livelihoods for farmers.

1229.1537.text: Meat production is economically irrelevant in most national economies. Thus, impacts on farmers are easy to mitigate.

1229.3899.text: Not eating meat means not farming animals, not farming animals means no money to feed them, no money to feed them means no more cattle, chicken, pigs, etc. as long as we live in a capitalist system/economy.

1229.6696.text: Economists believe that [creative destruction](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/creativedestruction.asp) is pertinent for economic growth. 200 years ago [90% of the U.S. worforce](https://www.agclassroom.org/gan/timeline/farmers_land.htm) were farmers. If we hadn't let the farming jobs go, economic development would have been impossible and the rise of living standards would have been suppressed.

1229.6805.text: Speaking of cliche's, the old buggy whip trope comes to mind. But as NYT and a guy named Mike Masnick, writing at TechDirt notes, many carriage-industry companies in 1890s found ways to adapt to the automobile market that could have put them out of business. Farmers can be helped to adapt.[Buggy Whips Not The Perfect Analogy Of Businesses Disrupted By Innovation?](https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20100110/1613597692.shtml)

1229.684.text: Poultry production is the fastest growing meat sector, increasing 4.7% in 2010 to 98 million tons.

1229.714.text: As this [model](http://www.nistads.res.in/indiasnt2008/images/it6rural/t6rur15_fig3.jpg) shows, meat consumption has been increasing in the last 30 years, in the developed world as well as in the developing world.

1229.705.text: Generally, rising incomes and urbanization in developing countries lead to a higher [demand](http://www.voanews.com/content/decapua-farm-animals-29mar12-144898655/179917.html) of animals products and meat.

1229.1559.text: Between 2001 and 2005 the employment growth in the Australian meat industry stood at [10%](https://docs.employment.gov.au/system/files/doc/other/profile_of_the_australian_meat_industry.pdf).

1229.2140.text: Growth in the meat sector is simply due to growing demand for food. When people transition to other food, this demand will allow other sectors to grow instead.

1229.3206.text: The idea of the possibility of constant growth is wrong. It is not possible to constantly grow the meat industry, because we live on a limited planet. Therefore what happened in the past cannot be extrapolated into the future just like that.

1229.5127.text: The meat substitutes industry can grow to replace the meat industry, taking jobs from the meat industry and creating new ones.

1229.3641.text: 18% of USA GDP is spent on healthcare. If there was a drastic reduction in demand for healthcare it could result in a recession and a loss of healthcare jobs \(for the USA at least\).

1229.1906.text: Mass produced meat is not sustainable regarding increase of CO2 and consumption of nitrogen by plants used to feed livestock. The real cost of meat is [much higher](http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/13/opinion/the-myth-of-sustainable-meat.html?_r=1) than the current consumer price.

1229.2584.text: Livestock farming can only be beneficial for the economy in the short term. Over the long term, the economy will be harmed by climate change induced from farm CO2 and methane emissions as well as land degradation

1229.2522.text: Economic harms would leave many people worse off. This is a morally relevant consideration.

1229.3141.text: Slavery was also once essential for economic concerns.

1229.3935.text: Something that is not morally acceptable for one person may be morally acceptable for another. Suggesting that eating meat is morally unacceptable completely negates human history and the fact that, at one point, we needed to sustain off of it. However, this is not to say that there aren't more humane ways to treat cattle / livestock.

1229.2624.text: Harvesting human organs and reselling them would be good for the economy. This does not make it morally acceptable, and this debate centres around the morals of the action, not its economic viability.

1229.5084.text: Slavery once was a big part of the Global Economy but was abolished even though the economic issues caused by it, there was bigger problems then just the economic part and it is the same here, there are bigger problems now, such as forest devastations, climatic effects, and the fact that we are using animals as slaves

1229.6704.text: The state can boost aggregate demand in response to a fluctuation in commodities by using expansionary fiscal policy \(spending more, lowering taxes, or giving cash handouts\).

1229.6747.text: According to this school it means that public expenses will raise; one of the policies of Keynesian economics is to increase governmental spending.

1229.2142.text: The production of farm animals provides an [economic safety net](https://www.voanews.com/a/decapua-farm-animals-29mar12-144898655/179917.html) for many people in poor countries.

1229.2517.text: Farmers in low-income countries are typically poor, and would not have the resources to transition to a different occupation or type of farming if they were no longer able to buy livestock.

1229.2518.text: The economies of low-income countries are [particularly vulnerable](http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/usappblog/2016/09/10/climate-change-impacts-the-economic-development-of-low-income-countries/) to climate change. Insofar as stopping meat production helps alleviate climate change, it is beneficial for the economies of low-income countries.

1229.3052.text: Low-income countries suffer from malnutrition and food shortages. Since ceasing to eat meat would allow us to produce more food, this would benefit low-income countries.

1229.4696.text: A lot of food produced in poorer countries is for the consumption of livestock which is then imported as meat to the west. This food could be be used to directly feed people in low income countries.

1229.5481.text: The farming of animals for meat can be problematic.  For example, when the practice involves using land to produce food for animals at the expense of food for people.  However, I stayed in poor villages in Indonesia where pigs and chickens were fed scraps or scratched for grubs.  Those chickens and pigs did not take any food that was otherwise edible for people and I felt OK to eat the meat they produced.

1229.6102.text: Countless small farmers make a living from raising chickens, goats and other animals for meat.  If artificial meat supplants that industry it will be just more wealth accumulating to the corporate techie elite.

1229.6344.text: Many bioregions are incapable of supporting one human let alone whole societies without the use of animals as a necessary part of the foodchain.

1229.6372.text: An increase in vegetarian or vegan diets could harm the economies of countries who depend heavily on their meat exports for income.

1229.1248.text: Livestock production accounts for [1.4%](http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/feed_the_world/2014/05/meat_eating_and_climate_change_vegetarians_impact_on_the_economy_antibiotics.html) of the world’s total GDP. The production and sale of animal products account for 1.3 billion people’s jobs, and 987 million of those people are poor.

1229.11.text: Factory farming fosters poverty in the Global South.

1229.3642.text: New technologies can allow plant foods to grow in artificially controlled environments, for example aquaponics. It would be more energy intensive, but with the parallel rise in renewable energy, this may curtail some of the negative effects of energy intensive processes.

1229.3643.text: Most countries have access to global markets, and can trade non-food goods and services for food from other countries to meet any gaps on local production.

1229.3644.text: Traditional and contemporary methods of preserving food can be used to make sure food harvested earlier in the year is stored for the winter.

1229.4779.text: There are just as many subsidies for the growth of plant based foods. The same argument could be made for most foods.

1229.4836.text: Nobody has suggested \(in this branch of the debate\) outlawing eating meat, or that there should be governmental action to this effect, rather that it is an action we should take, as individuals or as a collective, out of our own free wills or moral imperatives.

1229.3640.text: Disruptive innovation can increase growth in untapped markets. Tech companies are currently making large investments in the plant based sector. Having a huge impact on the global economy is not necessarily a bad thing, for example, the internet was disruptive, but it created new opportunities.

1229.6637.text: Leather products are totally dependant on meat consumption. Imagine no leather shoes, belts, jackets or shoes or bags. Other industrial products like fertilizers come from recycled waste products. Then imagine the impact of shutting down the interconnected industries and the loss of jobs and taxes for what?

1229.6717.text: [Modern economics teaches](https://www.mruniversity.com/courses/principles-economics-microeconomics/tariffs-quotas-protectionism-definition) that supporting production for production's sake \(protectionism\) is economically harmful, because it takes labor and resources away from production for consumption's sake.

1229.5735.text: It can be compared with the need to lower the depencency of fossil fuel - in the short term there may be negative consequences, but in the longer term, the advantage clearly outweighs the disadvantages

1229.3799.text: Cultural and technological changes cause economic shifts all the time. Products and whole industries become obsolete or unacceptable. Societies and economies adapt to these changes.

1229.1453.text: Meat and the meat industry would simply be replaced with the production of vegetarian foods, meaning the effects on the economy would be minimal.

1229.5483.text: We have examples of economic shift working already. In the dairy industry, for example. There are less people drinking milk now, which has caused the plant-milk and other non-dairy industries to flourish.

1229.3233.text: Producing enough meat to provide the entire world's population with a meat-centric diet is not realistic or sustainable with current dominant farming models and a rising global population. Lowering meat consumption while shifting food production towards plant-based foods will give many more people around the world greater food security overall.

1229.3461.text: There are parts of the world still where meat is the more readily available diet for humans than vegetable products - such as tribal Greenland where fish and seal meat are still majority sources of nutrition.

1229.2450.text: Eating [plant foods instead of animal-based foods](https://freefromharm.org/featured-articles/catching-up-with-science-burying-the-humans-need-meat-argument/) can bring about health benefits including reducing the chances of high blood pressure, diabetes, stroke, and some types of cancer.

1229.2451.text: The [American Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics](https://freefromharm.org/featured-articles/catching-up-with-science-burying-the-humans-need-meat-argument/) has stated that well planned vegetarian diets are nutritionally adequate and appropriate for individuals at all stages of life.

1229.2453.text: A major [study by Oxford University](http://www.oxfordmartin.ox.ac.uk/news/201603_Plant_based_diets) concluded that universal adoption of vegetarian diets could avoid 7.3 million deaths per year by 2050.

1229.2702.text: There is much we do not yet understand about gut health and how the body metabolises and interacts with foods.

1229.2868.text: Individual studies might show advantages to a vegetarian diet, but [literature reviews](https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2014/03/science-compared-every-diet-and-the-winner-is-real-food/284595/) show no significant gains when all the various popular diets are compared to each other. Many different diets based primarily on the idea that we should eat whole food and mostly plants all show substantial health gains. We don't need to remove meat to achieve the health outcomes -- we just need to make sure we get enough plants and focus on unprocessed foods.

1229.3005.text: Eating meat is no longer necessary due to the range of meat substitutes on offer.

1229.4472.text: In the long run \(many years into the diet\), vegetarianism makes people depressed, as stated by Lierre Keith in her book The Vegetarian Myth.

1229.2724.text: The idea of a meatless diet being weak or deficient in protein is not accurate as we know some of the strongest animals on Earth are vegetarian.

1229.5289.text: This health claim was promoted by vegetarian societies that deceptively qualified their dietary recommendation with "well-planned" when this doesn't belong to any single food group.

1229.5291.text: The alleged health benefits of vegetarianism came from caloric restriction and fibre, both of which can be gotten from omnivory and carnivory, whereas alcohol and tobacco are both plant products that were arbitrarily excluded in the vegetarian diet.

1229.5457.text: Freefromharm.org contradicts itself where it says our species needs the same nutrients but then some of us are allergic or diseased \[but doesn't say so by genetics\].  Thus some lack the ability to digest lactose in milk, gluten in wheat, beta-carotene in several crops, albumen in egg white, glucose-6-phosphate in fava, and lectins in seeds and nightshades.

1229.5459.text: The [phytate](https://www.google.com/search?num=100&q=phytate%7Cphytic+rickets%7Cpellagra%7Cberiberi) antinutrient in whole grains has killed 100,000s by [pellagra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pellagra#History) and [ric](http://austinpublishinggroup.com/pediatrics/fulltext/download.php?file=ajp-v1-id1001.pdf)[k](https://books.google.com/books?id=4IhXAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA443&lpg=PA443)[ets](https://books.google.com/books?id=zp30zkTvfmMC&pg=PA90&lpg=PA90).  Tannin antinutrients destroy thiamine in the bran that has the same phytate which without the bran causes beriberi.

1229.5460.text: A vegetarian diet requires a complete set of disparate ingredients that, when taken in bad proportion or alone, cause heart disease, obesity, diabetes, cavities, osteoporosis, kidney stones, fatigue, brain fog, and malnutrition.  The nutritional supplements with the diet suffer from different bioavailabilities such that amine and vitamin compounds cause overdose of calcium and transition metals whereas carbonate and citrate compounds are not absorbed well.

1229.5461.text: The same species does require very different nutrients.  Freefromharm.org will quote-mine nutritionists, rather than doctors or scientists, for requirements when it serves their position even if it supports opposite premises: milk is only for babies which is why adults lose the ability to digest milk \(same species\) but everyone needs the same nutrients.  Diet varies by age \(enzymes and fatty acids for extremes\), sex \(saturated fat, calcium, iron for women\), and culture \(tastes and enzymes\).

1229.10824.text: [A review of studies](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/advance-article/doi/10.1093/eurheartj/ehad211/7177660?login=false)(Plant-based diets have the potential to lessen the atherosclerotic burden from atherogenic lipoproteins and thereby reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease) found that plant-based diets reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease.

1229.3149.text: The source cited lists the following high-protein foods under "good to eat food": lentils, Quorn \(high-protein meat substitute\), a variety of different nuts, 5 types of protein powder, brown rice, bean sprouts, and more. Even [spinach](http://nutritiondata.self.com/facts/vegetables-and-vegetable-products/2626/2) is 30% protein/calorie, compared to 33% in a [hamburger patty](http://nutritiondata.self.com/facts/beef-products/3460/2).

1229.3329.text: Considering the extreme genetic diversity of human kind and the astronomical complexity of protein stings, blocks and complexes, it would be disastrous for certain individuals to stop eating meat, as not all people can metabolize certain protein blocks, gluten for instance.

1229.4124.text: Some people biologically require animal protein and will fall ill from malnutrition and depression when they switch to vegetarian diets. Having to go back to meat-inclusive meals is the only way to recover their health.

1229.6439.text: For people who have problems with their digestive tract, there can be disastrous health consequences when eating the nuts, grains and fibrous vegetation needed in a vegetarian diet. I know this as I have Crohn's disease. Here are some other links: [insoluble fibre](https://www.livestrong.com/article/49246-cant-digest-raw-vegetables/) and [foods that tax your system](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/tasneem-bhatia-md/5-health-foods-that-can-t_b_5852998.html). Here is some specific info on diet if you have a [gut troubles](https://blog.kettleandfire.com/leaky-gut-foods/).

1229.1553.text: The feeding of antibiotics, faulty food and the unhygienic conditions in industrial livestock farming makes meat produced this way unhealthy for humans.

1229.3292.text: Whilst there are some fats associated with say, heart disease, particularly those in beef, and dairy, and processed meats are linked with cancer - heart disease does not occur in high degrees in all meat heavy national diets, such as Spain, not cancer in unprocessed meat diets. Where bad heart seems to be most clustered I think, is in nations with heavy fast food diets like the US - the combination of high starch, high sugar, and high saturated fat and processed meats.

1229.4925.text: No diet is without risk to health. Most sugars are known to have worse effects on cholesterol levels than any meat, and this also means fruits and vegetables! However, it may be sugar in meat that makes it so unhealthy — meat from many species is found to have toxic sugars Neu5Gc responsible for inflammation and autoimmune disorders, and possible links to cancer. In the end, whole unprocessed vegetables appear to be the best way to absorb carbohydrates slowly and avoid many of these issues.

1229.4984.text: Eating a little amount of meat permits to have a balanced diet without the inconvenience of nutritional lack and guarantee a higher quality of life for the animals

1229.2347.text: Eating meat involves a tradeoff between pleasure and health consequences. Individuals are capable of evaluating that tradeoff for themselves, and may often legitimately decide to eat meat despite the health consequences.

1229.97.text: Studies have linked heme iron found in red meat with an increased risk of colon and rectal [cancer](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10582688). Vegetarian sources of iron like leafy greens and beans contain [non-heme iron](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/nih_dietary_supplement_fact_sheet_on_iron.pdf).

1229.58.text: Those who eat meat are far more likely to contract cancer than those following a [vegetarian](http://time.com/9463/7-reasons-vegetarians-live-longer/) diet.

1229.1150.text: [USDA researchers](https://www.peta.org/living/food/meat-contamination/) have found that eating two ounces of chicken per day \(the equivalent of a third to a half of a boneless breast\) exposes a consumer to 3 - 5 micrograms of the most carcinogenic form of arsenic, which can dramatically increase cancer risk.

1229.2935.text: Eating meat, particularly processed meats and bacon, has been recognized by the World Health Organization to be [carcinogenic](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24148709).

1229.5004.text: Recent research implies that cancer is a metabolic decrease, which in part forms the basis of the ketogenic diet \(eating meat and good fat\). [Cancer is a metabolic disease](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3941741/)

1229.6673.text:
Studies done on negative health consequences of meat consumption are done in high carbohydrate diets. Carbohydrates are closer linked with cancer than meat consumption. 
[Starving cancer: Dominic D'Agostino at TEDxTampaBay](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3fM9o72ykww)

1229.133.text: [Diseases](http://theweek.com/articles/457135/5-modern-diseases-grown-by-factory-farming) such as BSE, MRSA or [bird flu](http://ecohearth.com/eco-zine/food-and-garden/865-swine-flu-bird-flu-and-bse-three-legacies-of-factory-farming-.html) are connected to intensive livestock farming conditions.

1229.2867.text: This is only true of CAFO or Industrial meat production.  Organic silvopasture, permacultural, and organic intensive grazing meat production do not create the same health risks. They do not use antibiotics and animal waste doesn't build up. It is, instead, immediately turned into fertilizer. Animals are kept away from areas of the pasture long enough for the waste to be incorporated into the soil and for the plants to recover.

1229.5837.text: [Animals cause vegetarian foods to get contaminated, which leads to food-borne illness. Eating meat increases the capabilities of animal products \(such as manure\) to contaminate crops \(such as using manure for fertilizer or wastewater for irrigation\).](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4265071/)This could lead to people who do not eat meat \(such as vegetarians\) to be affected \(i.e. sick\) by it, even though they do not contribute to the problem.

1229.150.text: Consuming meat from organic livestock farming could help to mitigate these risks.

1229.1736.text: Meat from factory farming contains a number of [growth hormones](https://www.organicconsumers.org/scientific/growth-hormones-fed-beef-cattle-damage-human-health) that are detrimental to our health.

1229.10593.text: Antibiotic use in animals farmed for meat can have harmful effects for human health.

1229.110.text: Meat is the best source of [vitamin B12](http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/78/1/131.long), a vitamin necessary for the nervous system and digestive system health.

1229.288.text: Neal Barnard of the [Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine](http://www.pcrm.org/media/experts/neal-barnard) notes that when people switch from meat-eating to plant-eating, their intake of vitamins and other nutrients improves.

1229.1037.text: Meat is a great [source](http://www.webmd.com/diet/iron-rich-foods) of heme iron, which is important for the human body.

1229.663.text: The human body does not require consumption of animal protein.

1229.1897.text: One of the foods with the [highest](https://www.healthaliciousness.com/articles/foods-highest-in-protein.php) protein to calorie ratio is cheese, which is not a meat product.

1229.1985.text: Meat is packed with protein. While there are other ways to get protein, lean meats are an extremely healthy and efficient way to obtain it.

1229.1732.text: Vegetarians/vegans generally consume a diet consisting of [less](http://www.livestrong.com/article/481795-the-statistics-of-vegetarians-vs-meat-eaters/) saturated fat and cholesterol than the average meat eater.

1229.98.text: A meatless diet helps build healthy bones because vegetarians absorb more calcium than meat eaters.

1229.83.text: [Good fats](http://www.health.harvard.edu/staying-healthy/the-truth-about-fats-bad-and-good) come mainly from vegetables, nuts, seeds; not from meat.

1229.1733.text: Without a carefully balanced diet non-meat eaters could suffer from certain deficiencies, like [protein](http://vegetarian.lovetoknow.com/Protein_Deficiency_Symptoms#Fur0di7vVrR60mUF.97) or [vitamin B12](http://www.webmd.com/food-recipes/guide/vitamin-b12-deficiency-symptoms-causes#1).

1229.2580.text: Maintaining a meatless diet in a meat-eating society is costly and requires nutrient planning.

1229.2629.text: Rapid evolution of humans was directly supported by the high protein diet of eating meat.  Meat diets provide more energy and nutrients that are more filling and energy efficient than plant based diets. Thus, precious time and energy is saved with the more efficient meat diet. Time and energy that can be used for different things like evolution, education, and technological advancements.

1229.2684.text: Vegetables do not sufficiently contain the nutrition needed by the human species, and additionally the much larger space requirements because of lower caloric density mean that relying on vegetation alone is not likely to be feasible, especially in comparison with the feasibility of creating ethically sound animal husbandry conditions and even changing to use less-neurologically-complex organisms as food sources, such as shrimp and aquaponics.

1229.2769.text: There is no one-size-fits-all regiment for optimal health and nutrition for human beings. It may very well be that some of us are more genetically wired to thrive on vegetable only diets while others need to metabolize meat.

1229.3138.text: Plant protein products are improving. You can receive the same levels of proteins and vitamins without the chemicals and hormones found in meat products. [thrivemarket.com](https://thrivemarket.com/garden-of-life-raw-organic-meal-replacement-shakes-vanilla?utm_source=google&utm_medium=pla&ccode=FIRST3&ccode_force=1&utm_medium=pla&utm_source=google&utm_campaign=Shopping_Health_Beauty&utm_content=658010116022&utm_term=google-pla_na&gclid=EAIaIQobChMIoOyxk7Oo1wIVS5V-Ch3m_gASEAYYCCABEgJkivD_BwE)

1229.3212.text: It is difficult and more expensive to achieve the protein requirements for best possible health without eating meat.

1229.3475.text: A [recent study](http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2017/11/07/1707322114) shows that vegan diets would not provide sufficient nutrition for the current population without supplementation potentially causing disease.

1229.3512.text: Meat is essential for a healthy diet, especially for developing and maintaining muscles.

1229.3982.text: The bioavailability of vegetable matter is much lower than meat for human beings. Not only is meat cellular tissue far more similar in constitution to our own cells than plant cells, but it is far easier, for example, to extract the majority of iron available in red meat than it is for us to extract iron present in vegetation such as spinach, only a small fraction of which is available.

1229.3286.text: It may be arguable that essential nutrients in meat are generally more bioavailable from those sources. For example, omega-3, choline. It is also arguable that mineral balances such as copper-zinc that are recommended for health are identical to that which one would receive from a meat heavier diet, rather than plants. Likewise saturated fats serve essential roles in the composition of hormones, in the brain, heart and liver. In other words, in the long run, a vegan diet may be harmful.

1229.3574.text: Meat has been shown to be an [important component](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0309174012003385) of a balanced diet.

1229.4702.text: Ceasing to eat meat can lead to health problems as replacing it with plant-based materials requires a plethora of different types of plants to get every nutrient needed.

1229.4970.text: Eating meat is good for the brain \(check the link\), and nutrients are absorbed easier \(see how cows spend all the day chewing grass\). [www.businessinsider.com](http://www.businessinsider.com/5-brain-nutrients-that-you-cant-get-from-plants-2013-10)

1229.5001.text: There are more efficient and sustainable methods for putting nutrients into our body than eating meat. These include [synthesizing nutrients from chemicals](http://www.doctorsresearch.com/articles4.html), modifying existing foods to use [less resources](http://c4rice.irri.org/index.php/component/content/article/19-about/55-why-c4-rice) or [have more nutrients](https://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2013/03/07/173611461/in-a-grain-of-golden-rice-a-world-of-controversy-over-gmo-foods), and [individually growing food](https://www.seeker.com/food-helmet-sustains-you-with-algae-1767693118.html). Way out there is [people being genetically enhanced to become autotrophs](http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120906-will-humans-ever-photosynthesise).

1229.5669.text: There is [some evidence](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3137939/) that ceasing to eat meat would harm brains of those who are in the developmental age.

1229.5705.text: A Stone Age diet is the most natural and beneficial diet to the human gut. Meat and fats and some grains and fruit. Studies have shown that those people who follow this ancient way of eating are less susceptible to diabetes, heart disease and cancers. Take a look at this article which shows how fat is very important to the human diet.[files.meetup.com](http://files.meetup.com/1463924/Homo%20Carnivorous-WAPF2.pdf)

1229.6460.text: Some of the most healthful nutrients come exclusively or in greater bioavailability from animals sources: liver containing CoQ10, B vitamins, zinc, iron, chromium and other trace minerals, bone broth containing collagen supporting compounds such as hyluronic acid and glucosamine. While vegetarian diets can be healthful, they lack many nutrients that, while present in vegetables, have much less bioavailability. Humans thrive only when consuming moderate amounts of healthy animal food sources.

1229.6417.text: Animals process a vegetarian diet. Meat is the effect of that process - and this is why meat packs more nutrients in than vegetables. The organs and bones of the animal are particularly high in essential nutrients.

1229.6438.text: Eating just the cooked muscle is unhealthy. When meat is cured it increases it's bio availability and introduces good bacteria which facilitates digestion; coupled with eating bone broth and organs, eating meat in this way is extremely healthy.

1229.6697.text: Though there may be some health benefits associated with eating meat, [many](https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2019/10/meat-wars/599728/) humans typically eat much more of it than is healthy or necessary to obtain such benefits.

1229.1691.text: The study cited has methodological flaws and therefore its results are uncertain, i.e. the number of participants \(330\) is too small to be representative and the measure of life quality is insufficient.

1229.2678.text: The study was comprised of self-reported data with very little explanation about what constituted each dietary subset. It's hard to draw any significant conclusions from self-reported data.

1229.5279.text: Vegetarianism is linked to reduced physical and mental health, increased risk of allergies and specific forms of cancer. Vegetarians, who are on average more health conscious than the general population, are twice as often sick, and spend twice as much money on doctors, when compared to equally health conscious meat eaters. [journals.plos.org](http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article/file?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0088278&type=printable)

1229.6592.text: This relies on cherry-picked data, when there is much more data and research which concludes otherwise. A [meta-analysis](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/1832195?hc_location=ufi) is a better way to get a larger spectrum of properly representative data.

1229.6821.text: Ketosis is a state of metabolism that cannot be achieved without consuming meat.

1229.1149.text: According to the US Department of Agriculture \(USDA\) 70% of food poisoning is caused by contaminated [animal flesh](http://www.earthsave.org/pdf/ofof2006.pdf).

1229.1176.text: The CDC \(Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\) published in a [report](http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/255645.php) that leafy green vegetables like lettuce or spinach are among the top sources of food poisoning.

1229.1178.text: Seedy vegetables \(tomatoes, zucchinis\) are responsible for more [Salmonella](http://www.medicaldaily.com/salmonella-food-poisoning-most-common-vegetables-not-meat-325070) infections than any kind of meat in the USA.

1229.3656.text: Food poisoning occurs in cases of poor preparation of food and poor food hygiene. There is nothing more inherently risky in eating meat than in eating vegetables.

1229.4804.text:
The largest food poisoning disasters \(dwarfing all others\) are chemical contamination of grain products. For example the 
[Iraq poison grain disaster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_Iraq_poison_grain_disaster) or this case of [toxic cooking oil in spain](https://www.theguardian.com/education/2001/aug/25/research.highereducation).

1229.4802.text: In terms of severity \(hospitalizations and deaths\) vegetarian diets offer no significant advantage for avoiding food poisoning. Hospitalizations and deaths \([wwwnc.cdc.gov](https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/5/5/99-0502-t3)\) are mostly due to listeria, salmonella, and toxoplasma gondii. None of these have any particular vegetarian advantages.

1229.428.text: Alternative factors, such as that vegetarians smoke less and have an overall [healthier lifestyle](http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2849819/Vegetarians-healthier-meat-eating-cousins-not-happy-prone-mental-health-issues.html), are strong alternative variables.

1229.73.text: [Vegetarians](http://time.com/9463/7-reasons-vegetarians-live-longer/) have lower blood pressure, are less likely to be overweight, and have less chance of heart diseases.

1229.102.text: A meatless diet helps prevent hypertension, and thus reduces the risk of [stroke](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/hypertension_and_blood_pressure_among_meat_eaters_fish_eaters_vegetarians_and_vegans_in_epic_oxford.pdf).

1229.33.text: A compound found in red meat, called [carnitine](http://www.prevention.com/health/health-concerns/carnitine-red-meat-linked-risk-heart-disease), has been found to cause atherosclerosis, the hardening or clogging of the arteries.

1229.103.text: A peer-reviewed [2004 study](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/a_prospective_study_of_red_meat_consumption_and_type2_diabetes.pdf) from Harvard researchers found that eating meat increases the risk of getting type 2 diabetes in women.

1229.2633.text: Amy Keating, a dietitian from Consumer Reports, says, "Many people replace the meat with refined carbohydrates," \([Nov. 2017 Consumer Reports](https://www.consumerreports.org/healthy-eating/eat-smarter-eat-healthier-sugar-salt-fat-gluten/)\), and these types of vegetarians have an increased risk of heart disease by 32%.

1229.3617.text: Eating meat [has recently been linked with developing Type 2 diabetes.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3942738/)

1229.4830.text: Doctors often suggest vegetarian diets to help with hormonal chronic conditions like PCOS and Endometriosis. While the science of why is inexact, vegetarian diets seem to help alleviate symptoms.

1229.5110.text: The lead cause of diabetes type ll is eating read meat, its actually the first link and it is as toxic for our organism as cigarettes are. You can watch it on the WHO website.[harvardmagazine.com](https://www.harvardmagazine.com/2012/01/a-diabetes-link-to-meat) you can see the first fact in here by Harvard University researchers, which I consider are highly recommended

1229.5065.text: Stopping eating meat can lead to more illness. It has been [shown](https://elpais.com/elpais/2014/11/26/buenavida/1417006731_060496.html) that people who don't eat meat present more allergic, carcinogenic and cardiovascular pathologies than meat consumers.
