1229.2232.text: Common vegetarian food can easily contain more saturated fat than meat products:[many cheeses](https://www.google.co.uk/search?q=saturated+fat+in+cheese&oq=saturated+fat+in+cheese&gs_l=psy-ab.3..35i39k1j0i7i30k1l5j0l2j0i20i263k1j0.109157.109157.0.109378.1.1.0.0.0.0.74.74.1.1.0....0...1.1.64.psy-ab..0.1.73....0.I8SP0mw2-eM) contain double \(or more\) the amount of saturated fat that steak contains per 100g.

1229.3230.text: Obviously there is plenty of room for variation in the health outcomes of both vegetarian and omnivorous diets. However, on average, vegetarian diets are more healthy.

1229.4134.text: A good reason for why meats are unhealthy is the artificial means meat is raised, the hormones, etc.  Similarly, pesticides on vegetables are unhealthy too. Comparing vegetables to meats obfuscates the real causes of health detriments.

1229.5736.text: That is not an argument for eating meat, but for eating more healthy food, which is clearly possible, and will become more easy as the range of vegetarian food available increases

1229.4920.text: A heathy vegan diet is theoretically possible, but it is extremely hard to maintain such a diet long term without consuming any animal products, unless you take an industrial preconceived super balanced food.

1229.4799.text: This misconception is the result of a self-selection bias. Basically, vegetarians are all people who are unusually interested in their health to begin with. Thus, naive studies will tend to show that vegetarians are healthier regardless of whether vegetarianism is healthy.

1229.2894.text: The Inuit people in Russia, US, Canada, and Greenland [survive primarily off of meat while suffering fewer health problems](http://discovermagazine.com/2004/oct/inuit-paradox) than modern nations; even with their high animal fat and protein diet.

1229.3165.text: The lifestyles of these groups are radically different from normal human populations in very many ways. The fact that they are healthy therefore does not prove that their consumption of meat does not harm them - it could simply be the case that the harm is offset by other aspects of their lifestyles.

1229.3545.text: The Masasai tribe in the Kalahari desert [are healthy yet primarily eat meat and Mongongo nuts](http://sciencenordic.com/maasai-keep-healthy-despite-high-fat-diet).

1229.3841.text: By definition, the sample sizes are smaller, and therefore less predictive of dynamics governing the overall population.

1229.4365.text: The science of diet is far from settled. This is a complex topic that will take many decades, if not centuries to understand. The advent of quantum super computer arrays will undoubtedly speed our understanding of diet, but today, there is much to learn about nutrition and heath. To suggest otherwise is to be dishonest about the topic. Take the science of salt consumption as a recent example. Today, it is now known that the dangers of too little salt vastly out weigh the dangers of too much.

1229.3998.text:
A study of 544 seven-year-old children in Kenya who previously had a vegan diet found that: 
"The group that received the meat supplement showed the biggest improvement in fluid intelligence over the two years, and those who had either milk or energy supplements were better than the controls. The group that received the meat supplements were more active in the playground, more talkative and playful, and showed more leadership skills," \([Link](https://www.theguardian.com/society/2005/feb/22/food.sciencenews)\)

1229.5712.text: Humans are accustomed to eating meals containing meat. The meals not only gives us proteins that are important for several bodily functions but also even the people who are eating vegetables don't necessarily become healthier. You become healthier based on you intake of foods that your body needs, which may include meat. I think that genes, outside factors \(smoking, levels of stress, sleep time, junk food etc.\), have a actually bigger toll on the body than the actual consumption of meat.

1229.4917.text: The eating of meat increased in the verge of WWII and the farming of animals was exacerbated; however this was due to  consumer demand. It's very difficult to build political measures for consumption reduction unless it's a global measure. The greater power is the market, the second is the consumer.

1229.6251.text: [Even nowadays the meat is still needed for human survival](http://hungerreport.org/2017/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/hunger-report-2017-full.pdf). We, the golden billion, can afford to choose. The rest of the world can not. So only after complete worldwide victory over the global problem of hunger we can afford to debate about what type of food should we choose to eat. But even then the humanity would just not have any possibilities to produce enough vegetarian food for all of our fast-growing population. It may be good, but it's simply impossible on this step of human evolution.

1229.5652.text: Per pound, spirulina has over double the protein of chicken \([261g](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/foods/show/3306?man=&lfacet=&count=&max=&qlookup=&offset=&sort=&format=Abridged&reportfmt=other&rptfrm=&ndbno=&nutrient1=&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=&totCount=&measureby=&Qv=4.536&Q6228=1&Q6229=1&Qv=1&Q6228=1&Q6229=1) vs [113g](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/foods/show/937?man=&lfacet=&count=&max=50&qlookup=chicken+meat+cooked&offset=&sort=default&format=Abridged&reportfmt=other&rptfrm=&ndbno=&nutrient1=&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=&totCount=&measureby=&Qv=4.536&Q2228=1&Q2229=1&Qv=1&Q2228=1&Q2229=1)\)

1229.5539.text: Healthy vegetarian foods [clean your teeth while you eat \(called "detergent foods" for that purpose\)](http://www.drhudis.com/blog/2016/08/detergent-foods-clean-your-teeth-while-you-eat).

1229.5655.text: Vegetarian food is high in beneficial nutrients \(such as [Vitamin K](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/nutrients/report/nutrientsfrm?max=25&offset=0&totCount=0&nutrient1=430&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=0&sort=c&measureby=g) and [magnesium](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/nutrients/report/nutrientsfrm?max=25&offset=0&totCount=0&nutrient1=304&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=0&sort=c&measureby=g)\) whereas meat is high in unhealthier ones \(such as calories and [cholesterol](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/nutrients/report/nutrientsfrm?max=25&offset=0&totCount=0&nutrient1=601&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=0&sort=c&measureby=g)\) when in excess

1229.6671.text: The fat in plants is generally high in polyunsaturated fat which is unstable leading to inflammation and oxidation in the body vs saturated fats in meat. [westonaprice.org](https://www.westonaprice.org/health-topics/know-your-fats/good-fats-bad-fats-separating-fact-from-fiction/)

1229.6781.text: People who eat meat can also eat vegetarian food. They benefit from both.

1229.5899.text: Ingesting "[bones can lead to intestinal perforation and peritonitis](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3856294/)"

1229.5900.text: [Beef jerky increases tooth pain and possibly triggers temporomandibular joint \(TMJ\)](http://diet.lovetoknow.com/why-does-beef-jerky-hurt-my-teeth)

1229.5901.text: [Meat trapped in-between teeth \(i.e. food impaction\) can be a reason for sore gums.](http://www.intelligentdental.com/2009/09/09/causes-of-sore-gums/)

1229.5902.text: [Grilled food usually is associated with meat \(burgers, hot dogs, steak...\). Wire brushes for cleaning a grill expose people to possibly ingesting the bristles and having emergency situations \(i.e. GI tract injuries\)](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6126a4.htm)

1229.5903.text: [Deboning fish by-mouth can lead to injuries such as nose bleeds, choking, and facial puncturing](http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/202360/help-ive-swallowed-a-fish-bone/).

1229.5906.text: Knives pose a danger to eaters from meats that require cutting before eating. In Spain, "[60,000 Spaniards end up in emergency rooms each year because of ham-cutting accidents](https://www.pri.org/stories/2012-08-23/dangerous-art-ham-cutting-spain)".

1229.5907.text: [People can chip their teeth from biting into bone.](https://www.injuryclaimcoach.com/questions/broken-tooth-biting-into-bone.html)

1229.5949.text: Some of these could occur while eating vegan foods too, such as cutting large and tough-skinned fruits and vegetables.

1229.5950.text: [Blenders used to make vegetarian foods \(such as smoothies\) cause emergency room visits](https://www.consumerreports.org/cro/news/2013/02/blender-injuries-stir-up-more-visits-to-the-emergency-room/index.htm).

1229.6116.text: This has no bearing on the ethical question of whether it is wrong to eat meat, unless you are going to say that it is morally wrong to eat anything that is less healthy than vegetables \(or at least anything that is not healthier than meat\). But no one says that it's morally wrong to ever eat a french fry.

1229.107.text: Eating meat has negative impacts on [worker safety](http://www.mdpi.com/1660-4601/13/2/197/pdf). Meatpacking workers are injured at a rate of 27.6 per 100 workers - double the average of all manufacturing industries.

1229.845.text: Poultry processing workers at big companies including Tyson, Pilgrim’s, Perdue and Sanderson Farms are denied [basic rights](https://upvoted.com/2016/05/27/we-wear-diapers-activists-behind-the-givethemabreak-campaign-reveal-the-horrific-conditions-of-poultry-workers/). They are not allowed to go to the toilet while working.

1229.1496.text: Workers in other food producing industries do not fare any better than workers in the meat industry.

1229.2049.text: The meatpacking industry is [made particularly hazardous](https://www.hrw.org/news/2005/01/24/abuses-against-workers-taint-us-meat-and-poultry) due to a lack of training being provided to workers, close working quarters and insufficient safeguards.

1229.2133.text: This is a problem that should be solved through regulation of workplace conditions or temporary boycotts, not permanently ceasing to eat meat.

1229.2278.text: [Studies](http://www.news.com.au/national/slaughterhouse-workers-are-more-likely-to-be-violent-study-shows/news-story/f16165f66f38eb04a289eb8bd7f7f273) have shown that working in animal slaughterhouses leads to desensitisation to suffering and violence in general: abattoir workers have aggression levels comparable to those of incarcerated people, and towns with abattoirs have higher rates of domestic violence and violent crimes including murder and rape. This suggests not only that the meat industry harms worker psychology, but that it indirectly harms the wider human population as well.

1229.5150.text: This claim is a generalization. It is impossible to claim that the meat industry as a whole is harmful to its workers. Some companies may be harmful to its workers, but to apply this characterization to all companies in the meat industry is not logically sound.

1229.5862.text: Slaughterhouse workers often suffer from serious psychological damage due to the violence involved in their job.[ptsdjournal.com](http://www.ptsdjournal.com/posts/the-psychological-damage-of-slaughterhouse-work/)

1229.1498.text: Working on a fishing boat is a very hard and dangerous job and ranks [second](http://www.forbes.com/sites/jacquelynsmith/2013/08/22/americas-10-deadliest-jobs-2/#3ea9405c5095) most deadliest in the US.

1229.6964.text: By this same logic, not eating meat involves being complicit in them losing their livelihood.

1229.36.text: Because animals feel, they should be treated according to [utilitarian ethics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utilitarianism), which advocates maximising pleasure and minimising suffering for all sentient beings.

1229.37.text: Killing an animal can only be justified by extreme necessities, such as survival; consuming a living creature just for its taste, for convenience, or out of habit is thus not justifiable.

1229.164.text: Humans currently give different consideration to animals such as pets \(whom we care for\) and farm animals \(whom we eat\). This is an arbitrary line to draw, as both have the same right to live.

1229.1405.text: Some animals, who due to their reproduction disturb a natural balance, need to be killed in order to preserve biodiversity. This is the case with rabbits on the German island [Norderney](http://de.alamy.com/stock-photo-rabbits-on-a-meadow-oryctolagus-cuniculus-norderney-island-lower-saxony-78982277.html) where the rabbits were accidentally brought to the island by humans.

1229.54.text: Animals are not morally equivalent to humans and therefore do not possess an equal natural right to live.

1229.1562.text: Most animals whose meat is eaten have been the property of humans. Their property rights conflict with animal rights.

1229.1909.text: Humans are at the top of the food chain, which means that they are merely following the natural order of things when they kill and eat other animals.

1229.1955.text: The limited sentience of most animal species means that they can be used to fulfill human desires, such as through farming, as long as it is not unnecessarily cruel.

1229.2777.text: Animals do not have "rights" at all. They live in a state of eat or be eaten. Rights do not exist in the natural world at all, only in the socially constructed world that humans have created for themselves.

1229.2908.text: "Human rights" are not laws of the universe but rather a practical tool humans use to govern interaction with each other. They are a means of outlining and governing acceptable behavior so that we may live peacefully with each other. We can do this because we can communicate with each other and hold each other accountable. We cannot communicate with other species and hold them accountable in the same way yet.  A wolf does not understand, and will not respect, a universal right to life.

1229.2921.text: Even if animals did live free of human slaughter, they would most likely die due to consumption by predators anyways so you might as well use the animals in a way that benefits humans.

1229.2969.text: It would be good to eradicate certain Mosquitos and parasites, so they cannot have such a right.

1229.3006.text: A chicken or cow doesn't have any frame of reference, and hence doesn't know what a good or bad life is. We like to attribute meaning to our own lifes and subsequently, animals lives too. If a chicken does not know what it is like to live in the wilderness then is it suffering inside?

1229.2301.text: Humans are not superior to any other animal, they are simply a small part of a whole ecosystem. As such, they have no legitimate right to kill animals as they please.

1229.3065.text: Imagine we could harvest meat from a meat plant. If you believe it is more ethical to harvest meat from a plant than from an animal, then you recognize that harvesting meat from animals is unethical.

1229.3043.text: It is our moral duty to minimize the suffering we cause to conscious beings. To the degree to which a being has the capacity to suffer, we have a responsibility to minimize the suffering we cause it.

1229.3648.text: This statement is illogically selective. Why it should apply to just animals versus all living things? Why do all plants or microbes not have a right to live and be free of suffering?

1229.3681.text: Animals bred for meat would not exist if their meat was not to be consumed. Wherein does their right to life reside if nobody is willing to create the circumstances of their existence?

1229.3976.text: Animals are sentient beings - they feel pain and have complex emotional lives. Many have family structures and are able to bond. Killing them for our pleasure when alternatives exist is immoral and archaic.

1229.3943.text: Meat comes from a living source that only dies in order for us to sustain our own living. We say it is morally incorrect to kill another human being but for an animal it is okay? This belief is hypocritical in nature.

1229.4185.text: Without the raising of animals for slaughter, they wouldn't have had a life in the first place. They are fed and raised to maturity.

1229.4509.text: Animals feel pain. And if you suggest that they are inferior therefore you have the right to do anything to them, you should also have the right to do anything you want with mentally challenged people or any other human who is inferior to you. Society is better than in the past exactly because of empathy from which morality arises. It is time to get past our arrogance towards other animals.

1229.4988.text: 70 billion animals [are sacrificed every year for consumption](https://www.ciwf.org.uk/media/3640540/ciwf_strategic_plan_20132017.pdf).

1229.4618.text: Ethics persuade us that we have a duty not to exploit anyone, and beyond that, a duty to actively help all victims of exploitation from their plight to the best of our ability. Animals in this case are innocent victims of mass exploitation.

1229.6822.text: The type of intensive agriculture required to produce vegetarian food on a scale to feed current populations inherently causes the death of animals. To plant acres of soy one must displace every single animal living there, eradicate every bird, mouse, squirrel that would eat the crop, poison every insect, grind up every creature in the path of the harvester, etc. Farming is an ecological disaster that represents death to every living being that is not the crop.

1229.122.text: Raising animals in confinement, deprived of sunlight, natural soil and freedom to move, is cruel and against their nature.

1229.125.text: Many animals raised for food are not slaughtered or kept humanely.

1229.236.text: Unnatural methods of farming could be easily curbed if industrial nations consumed less meat. Everyone being on a meatless diet is not necessary.

1229.1403.text: Because egg and meat production are separated by modern production practices the males of egg-laying chickens are often [shredded](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chick_culling) shortly after hatching as they are not needed.

1229.2054.text: Animals on farms are routinely [mutilated with no anesthetic.](http://freefromharm.org/animal-products-and-ethics/a-comprehensive-analysis-of-the-humane-farming-myth/) The animals are castrated, given nose rings and ear tags, dehorned and debeaked, all of which are painful exercises carried out on most farms.

1229.2053.text: Cows have been seen to have incredibly strong bonds, particularly between mothers and their calves. On these farms the calves are often taken away from the mother to be killed and there are numerous reports of [mother cows calling and searching](https://www.peta.org/issues/animals-used-for-food/factory-farming/cows/hidden-lives-cows/) for their babies.

1229.3812.text: Cruel practices and incidents of animal abuse have been repeatedly exposed in animal agriculture. The true incidence is probably greater than those shown up through investigation.

1229.4346.text: Stressed out livestock will produce lower quality meat and less of it. It is in farmers' best interests to make sure their livestock are comfortable and safe.

1229.4757.text: Many meat producing companies use misleading titles like "Cage Free" and "Free Range" to make buyers feel better. Meanwhile instead of having individual cages that barely allow for movement, animals are crammed into huge pens where they often are so close that they bump into each other constantly. Either way you put it, it is inhumane and unnecessary to continue this practice for the sake of enjoying the taste.

1229.5917.text: Unethical common practices suggest more ethical practices exist, and thus this is an argument to change practices not halt farming of animals.

1229.6103.text: Animals in the slaughter chute that sense mortal danger feel fear—terror, in fact. That fear manifests as rushes of adrenaline and other biological processes may lock that fear into the meat that carnivore humans eat. According Jess Zimmerman, writing in Atlas Obscura, botched slaughtering of pigs—the pig survives the first attempt to kill it—causes less saleable, bad-tasting, acidic “pale soft exudative” meat, i.e., pork from frightened animals. [Why Meat from Scared Animals Tastes Worse](https://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/why-scared-animals-taste-worse)

1229.5484.text: This claim depends on examples of treatment that is cruel.  Many of the examples of farming practices viewed as cruel serve a function that benefits the animal's well being.  For instance calves are separated from their mother at birth because we are able to prevent infections better while they increase antibodies, killing is necessary but pain free, animals are restrained, but in many cases are free to exhibit normal social behavior. Producers know that reducing stress increases output.

1229.743.text: Morality is not absolute. While vegetarianism is a sign of moral virtue for [some Buddhists](https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=RNBgCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA78&lpg=PA78&dq=buddhism+moral+vegetarianism&source=bl&ots=sdH97MDzta&sig=LZsKluIQOJ5QPhboqstbQTlePRA&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjp_7aBzoPNAhXmYaYKHQtDAQcQ6AEIMDAC#v=onepage&q=buddhism%20moral%20vegetarianism&f=false), eating meat has equally been interpreted as a [moral duty](http://animalethics.blogspot.kr/2011/06/roger-scruton-on-duty-to-eat-meat.html).

1229.1665.text: Simply stating that humans should be morally conscious does nothing to argue that eating meat is morally wrong.

1229.2751.text: The normalizing of killing animals for food leads to a close-minded population less able to feel empathy and emotions for other species.

1229.4013.text: The uniqueness of humanity lies in its ability to reason beyond the forces of entropy and past the constraints of an impulse for survival. Humanity has for the most part conquered survival, and we continue to conquer the vices with which we were born as we progress towards something of a species to be proud of. We must undo these obsolete desires for pleasure as they come at the cost of life. It is in our power, our moral beliefs, and our logical perspective of life as humans to do so.

1229.4126.text: Our sapience necessitates moral standard.  A similar argument can be made against homosexuality. The naturalness or temptation of an act does not immediately award permission.

1229.4770.text: The wholesale slaughter of sentient non-human animals demonstrates that violence is an acceptable human behaviour.

1229.5135.text: Morality is wholly subjective, this argument presupposes an absolute moral authority counter to popular opinion. Indeed even if we were to follow the prevailing democratic subjective morality, the vast majority regularly eat meat. The idea that killing animals for food or eating meat is 'immoral' one can assume is an opinion held by [less than 10% of the global population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegetarianism_by_country) with not a single major territory where it is the prevailing norm.

1229.5475.text: The assumption that animals are not morally conscious is just that— an assumption. Prove it.

1229.6030.text: The more we learn about other animals, especially mammals, the more we learn they're intelligent, feeling beings. It is therefore morally and ethically wrong to continue farming and killing animals, and eating their meat, due to the suffering we cause them \(parent-child separation, cramped conditions, etc\).

1229.4732.text: We instinctively feel compassion towards animals, while carnivorous animals instinctively try to kill weaker species. E.g. Put a toddler and a rabbit in a crib, \(s\)he will hug it; put a lion cub and a rabbit in a crib, it will try to eat it.

1229.6325.text: Empathise with animals - how would you feel if your children were taken from you, fattened and then slaughtered for the purposes of feeding another beast. Or if you were herded into an abattoir where the friends you graze with are stunned and killed before you as you wait your turn. Cattle and pigs are mammals like us and experience the world through emotions not dissimilar to our own.

1229.6615.text: Abstaining from animal meat consumption allows one to reflect on more compassionate views of the world, and human involvement as caretakers of the ecology.

1229.466.text: If animals get fatally hurt it is better to eat them than to waste the meat. [Horses](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2011/sep/23/claims-five-broken-leg-horse), for example, are highly unlikely to recover from breaking a bone.

1229.460.text: Young goats cannot be [kept or sold](http://wildrootshomestead.blogspot.kr/2010/06/what-to-do-with-boys-wethered-male.html) because they fight and killing and burying them is just a waste. Eating them is a moral and ecological solution.

1229.2259.text: There are very few opportunities to eat animals killed by non-human causes. Eating only those animals would be very similar to not eating any meat at all.

1229.2263.text: Many religions use animal sacrifices. It would be a waste to not then eat those animals.

1229.2369.text: Selling meat from animals that have been killed anyway creates a demand for meat, which then encourages people to kill more animals than otherwise would have died.

1229.2546.text: Since a lot of institutions and professionals sustain that a diet that contains meat will necessarily cause a lot of health problems for the eater, not eating meat is not a waste. If someone doesn't want to drink poison, we would not say that they are 'wasting' poison.

1229.2675.text: We don't consider the food we feed to our pets "wasted". Every organism eventually "feeds" the ecosystem in which it dies \(including humans\), thus it's invalid to call organic matter objectively "wasted" simply because humans aren't the ones eating it.

1229.2670.text: Most of us wouldn't like the idea of eating a pet, regardless of its cause of death. Moral wrongness can vary depending on a person's view of how a dead body ought to be treated, and this subjective moral view varies wildly throughout culture, and from person to person.

1229.2697.text: Many societies, admittedly, less that are around today, [cannibalized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endocannibalism) their dead for religious purposes, out of reverence for them.

1229.2923.text: Many animals that we eat or commodify were brought into existence by humans and would otherwise not exist. By reducing the demand for meat, we reduce the animals that are killed for any reason. Therefore, it is only a waste because we have created something we do not need.

1229.3734.text: Humans have morally acceptable reasons to kill animals besides eating them. If a human has a good reason to kill an animal it would be immoral to waste the edible sections of that animal.

1229.4322.text: In practice, yes, but to be precise, eating the flesh from dead bodies is not cruel nor immoral if the act can be shown to never create demand for the murdering of animals. A free-range animal that dies from natural causes could have its body eaten without causing any suffering. Anonymously eating murder meat purely from others' leftovers also causes no suffering. Necessarily cruel and immoral are the various acts of torture and finally the murder, not the flesh-eating part which has exceptions.

1229.2506.text: Every sentient animal has the same moral status. You therefore can't treat pigs and cows as means to an end if you can't treat humans as means to an end.

1229.2625.text: Eating meat is not cruel and immoral if the animals that are being consumed are provided with humane living conditions, able to live full lives, and die of natural causes.

1229.3032.text: Animals cannot possibly enjoy the same quality of life that they'd have had in the wild if they were bred and raised with the sole purpose of being eaten.

1229.3215.text: The "free range" designation is not well regulated in the United States, and is more of a marketing term than a true indicator of how animals are treated. There are no rules enforcing the quality, size or degree of access to the outside.

1229.2275.text: It is immoral to bring creatures into existence in order to use and kill them. For example, it would be immoral to give birth to new children and use them as slaves or food.

1229.2036.text: Unlike wild animals, farmed animals are born explicitly due to human action. While we may have a duty to ensure that their lives are not unnecessarily cruel, it is not immoral to kill them for our own ends given they would not have existed otherwise.

1229.3622.text: Free range animals are often worse for the environment, [as they are more resource intensive in terms of land and less efficient in terms of food conversion](https://www.newscientist.com/article/2149220-grass-fed-beef-is-bad-for-the-planet-and-causes-climate-change/). Meanwhile, lower welfare animals benefit from efficiency of scale \(heat recapture in intensive farms for example\). Meat eaters must choose between welfare and the environment. Vegans need not make such a choice.

1229.3754.text: We can eat meat responsibly - choose carefully, develop small productions and local food, and make it a rare and savoured special dish.

1229.3973.text: The best way to incentivise humane and quality meat production is to buy and eat more from local farms. Avoiding meat entirely causes industrial meat factories to cut costs even more, leading to even more unethical production. Vote with your money.

1229.4131.text: Do means justify ends? We cannot argue the humaneness of raising animals for consumption when the end goal is their slaughter en masse anyway.

1229.5355.text: What is actually wrong is the treatment of animals in the  "meat industry", not the meat-eating itself. So, a change in the meat "production" would solve the problem, in a way that makes ceasing to eat meat unnecessary.

1229.5649.text: While is possible that ethical farms exist, there are no ethical slaughter houses. They are all horrifying death factories that expose animals to unimaginable stress and have terrible effect on human workers.

1229.5694.text: Nothing in the world had to be cruel, it just is. Facing the situation where animals are being constantly tortured in the name of bigger profits and simply advocate for a moral shift is an over simplification. Defend an ethical way to produce meat is a nice thing but not practical

1229.5954.text: Choosing to eat meat ethically is a luxury that many can't afford. Ethically produced meat is generally expensive and cheaper meat is generally amongst the least ethically produced.

1229.6281.text: All animals are not the same in their ability to grow meat while suffering. Good animal welfare \(and meat quality\) is highly correlated with high meat production rates in beef for example. There is a profit incentive to increasing animal welfare outcomes in this case. Therefore if consumers chose to eat meats of this type there would be financial incentives for the big meat producers to maximise animal welfare.

1229.6563.text: Animals can be raised in ways that cause little-no suffering, such as organically where they are free to roam outside and not fed things like growth hormones.

1229.6917.text: Despite attempts to advocate for better farming, farms are becoming more industrialised over time. See for example the graph [Annual Pig Crop Distribution by Size of Operation – United States: 1994-2014](https://downloads.usda.library.cornell.edu/usda-esmis/files/rr171x21v/cz30pw658/js956j577/hogview-10-29-2015.pdf). There is no evidence that consumers can realistically reverse this trend.

1229.5378.text: In many, if not most, places it is much more difficult or [expensive](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-money-chicken-organic/is-organic-chicken-worth-the-price-idUSKBN0FM24Q20140717) for consumers to purchase truly 'ethical' meat rather than to simply opt for a vegetarian option.

1229.5377.text: Even under an 'ideal' farming circumstances \(i.e. free range; painless death\) killing an animal still violates its right to life. To do so for such as simple \(and substitutable\) need such as food is immoral.

1229.6172.text: It is impossible to upscale 'ethically sourced' meat production to meet the huge demand for meat, in order to not change current meat consumption habits. 'Better consumer choice' is therefore impossible on a global scale.

1229.2986.text: Those people don't have to eat it. No one is forcing anyone to eat meat, so there is no need to tell people who enjoy it to stop. There are plenty of other arguments in this thread related to the morals of the animal kingdom.

1229.4188.text: Why is it immoral? Would you say it is also immoral for the average person to kill a spider in their house? They don't NEED to kill the spider most of the time.

1229.6014.text: Causing unnecessary harm should be avoided on ethical grounds. Eating meat clearly does cause unnecessary harm, unless our survival depends upon it. Since humans can thrive without eating meat, it is an unethical thing to do.

1229.5547.text: Animals' lives are wasted when their meat is not eaten \(due to spoiling...\), causing them to suffer needlessly and thus die in vain.

1229.6828.text: Many revered thinkers and most of the [collectively recognized geniuses](https://www.elephantjournal.com/2011/02/the-worlds-greatest-geniuses-are-vegetarians/) of every age followed and promoted some form of vegetarian diets \(Pythagoras, Socrates, Plato, da Vinci, Francis of Assisi, Newton, Darwin, Einstein, Tesla, Edison, Tolstoy, Franklin, Luther King… and far more recurrent among the Eastern philosophy figures. Also in modern times of every discipline: Van Gogh, Kafka, Henry Ford, Stephen Hawkins, Antoni Gaudí, Bill Gates, Carl Lewis, Matt Groening, etc\) [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_vegetarians)

1229.3114.text: It is hard to feel sympathy for being one never sees, or interacts with, even if the alternative is only seeing them as part of a meal.

1229.3143.text: Many who eat meat also feel compassion towards other animals. It is very possible to research where your meat comes from to ensure that no cruel methods were used in raising the animal, and in the case of hunting, thinning the population allows for expansion of resources, allowing the survivors a greater ability to thrive. This also allows their offspring more room to grow with less competition.

1229.3728.text: Conscious vegetarianism facilitates a lack of compassion toward other living beings because they see plants as mere ingredients to a recipe.

1229.4766.text: Specifically, it facilitates the reduction of suffering among living beings capable of suffering. Reducing suffering is good.

1229.5114.text: The above claimant presumes to know what human beings "feel" when they eat meat, and how those human beings view life. It is an inaccurate representation, and therefore it is invalid.

1229.5720.text: Conscious living facilitates compassion toward other living beings. Vegetarianism is not a necessary component of this.

1229.5766.text: By consuming farmed meat you are [ingesting the suffering and trauma those animal experienced in their short lives](http://sciencenordic.com/meat-stressed-animals-unhealthy) which has potential metaphysical consequences we cannot comprehend.

1229.5843.text: Eating someone or parts of someone is contradictory to compassion. Compassion involves the understanding of suffering and its reduction as much as possible. It is unlikely that there is not any suffering associated with the steps involved in eating a living being.

1229.5811.text: Love for fellow Earthlings would include the notion that our lives are precious and, therefore, we are not something to be eaten.

1229.5785.text: The thinking man must oppose all cruel customs no matter how deeply rooted in tradition and surrounded by a halo. When we have a choice, we must avoid bringing torment and injury into the life of another, even the lowliest creature; to do so is to renounce our manhood and shoulder a guilt which nothing justifies. - Albert Schweitzer

1229.4791.text: A large majority of meat eaters either have a pet, want one or watch cute cat videos with an "aww" type of reaction. That again shows the fact that we have the innate ability to think compassionately about animals and not think of them as supper.

1229.2628.text: Humans subjectively determine what has moral value, and the majority of humans place significantly less moral value on the lives of farm animals than the incomes and pleasure of humans.

1229.3058.text: It is cruel, but morality is a very relative concept. In the perspective of the animal kingdom, we are part of the omnivore group, and eating meat is what our species do, as many many others. Applying morality to nature is pointless, many other species cause harm to many others. Applying the term morality to meat eating is pointless and counterproductive to the actual goal: to reduce harm to some animals.

1229.3287.text: Moral arguments are often subjective. The comparative harm of eating say, an oyster, versus a higher plant which may, according to studies have a central nervious system depends on philosophical assumptions that are unprovable, such as that plants do not feel, or the degree to which animals feel.

1229.2822.text: Moral relativism is a weak standard of morality, with no true consideration of why things are wrong, it is only an example of [stage 4 of Lawrence Kohlberg's stages of moral development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Kohlberg%27s_stages_of_moral_development). We need a better reason, a real reason why things are right, or wrong, like [overall happiness,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utilitarianism) [rights,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_contract)or [good will.](https://kantphilosophy.wordpress.com/kants-ethics/the-good-will/)

1229.3296.text: Humans do not subjectively determine what has moral value. For example, humans could not subjectively determine that some races have fewer rights than others.

1229.3265.text: Animals have preferences, as frequently demonstrated through their actions, so under preference utilitarianism their demonstrated preferences should be taken into account.

1229.4533.text: Finding morality in consulting ones own or wider society's values is necessarily subjective. Consulting reason however leads to deontological ethical truths free from subjectivity.

1229.5507.text: Morality apply to things we chose to apply it to. For example, some humans chose to treat other humans less morally, such as criminals or simply a person they don't like based on their ideology, therefore, it is normal for humans to be "cruel and immoral" selectively, including to animals.

1229.2910.text: Morality only applies to humans. Morality functions to allow people to live together and cooperate in social groups. Morality is an irrelevant concept in the context of the natural world.

1229.3652.text: Animals are meant to exist as part of a food chain. If we, the apex predators, simply stopped consuming meat thousands of species \(cows, sheep, pigs etc..\) would become extinct as they only exist due to their value as food, due to selective breeding. This would invariably destabilise countless ecosystems.

1229.3666.text: Even if there was a one-off slaughter of all of those livestock, it is still a preferable outcome from the perspective of animal welfare to prevent the enslavement of untold future generations of animals.

1229.3667.text: The quantity of animals that exist is less important than having each animal posses a good quality of life free of suffering.

1229.3983.text: Veganism is endangering animals. Diversity of all kinds is worth preserving. Without demand for animal products the majority of domesticated animal breeds would become extinct. Cows do not exist in the wild, they exist within the framework of supply and demand. Just because animal diversity was created by humans doesn't make it less valuable than natural diversity. Treat animals well within the supply and demand structure. Don't prevent them being born by removing the need for them.

1229.4153.text: Current farming practices prevent certain species from going extinct. Animals bred on farms have been selectively bred for centuries, resulting in genetically imprinted tendencies. Many widely farmed species are incapable of surviving in the wild. With many species being sustained solely to provide nutritional purpose, veganism would effectively disincentivise the further preservation of these species. Notably, cattle, chickens, and sheep come to mind.

1229.4216.text: The habitat, well being, and continued survival of a majority of domestic livestock is directly dependent upon human consumption of meat.

1229.4793.text: All farmed animals are artificially inseminated more times a year than it is natural. So left alone, farm animals will become half in number after the first generation dies.

1229.4794.text: All farm animals have natural predators, which means that, left in the wild, around a third of them will be eaten.

1229.4839.text: This claim implies that what effectively amounts to an unnatural overpopulation of farm animals is desirable.

1229.4840.text: It would be ethically permissible to allow these excess animals to live pleasant lives and die of old age without being replaced. The moral objective is not to maintain a certain quantity of farm animals, rather to maintain an acceptable quality of life for all animals wherever possible, and avoid actively wronging them.

1229.10798.text: This depends on the assumptions that a\) all humans act on this ethical imperative to cease meat consumption completely b\) that their replacement is necessary or intrinsically good and c\) that these animals are not replaced without being the source of meat such as due to ecosystem-integrity motivated work or due to introduction of certain wild species.

1229.3811.text: Construction, manufacture, driving and aviation are some examples of human practices which cause the deaths of many animals. Vegetarians and vegans participate in these practices.

1229.3820.text: There is a difference between intentional and premeditated deaths, and incidental ones.

1229.4916.text: The large part of foods have in some way animal origin intakes. That includes the sugars, some of them, the exaustion and death of bees for the production of japan almonds. It's almost impossible to prevent eating moving life, the only way is to certificate, under some sort of paid authority.

1229.4943.text: Humans fail their moral obligations in many ways, and eating meat could be considered to be one of them.

1229.5872.text: If we stop eating meat, the consumption of dairy-product proteins will increase, and the dairy industry will grow. Dairy farming is even worse for animal welfare than the meat industry, because the animals suffer for longer.

1229.6546.text: A great many human activities cause the deaths of animals, but focusing on one of those activities will still lower the overall negative impact on animals. Moral inconsistency itself has no negative moral value.

1229.10478.text: This is a straw man fallacy. We should limit all activities causing animal suffering.

1229.5162.text: The pressures of supply and demand drive meat production. If you consume meat you are driving up the demand for meat, which increases production and all the attendant suffering related to it.

1229.6414.text: All human consumption implies the destruction of something. All food systems are morally debatable.

1229.5087.text:
It is cruel and immoral to eat fruits and vegetables that have been picked by forced labor, child labor, brutal sexual abuse, or other cruel and inhumane conditions. For the majority of the fruit- and vegetable-buying population, this is unavoidable, so therefore, eating meat is no more cruelty-free than eating vegetables: [www.pbs.org](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/labor-laws-left-farm-workers-behind-vulnerable-abuse), [www.ilo.org](http://www.ilo.org/ipec/areas/Agriculture/lang--en/index.htm), 
[www.hrw.org](https://www.hrw.org/news/2011/10/03/national-cashew-day-more-nuts), [www.pri.org](https://www.pri.org/stories/2016-06-25/farmworkers-push-back-against-machismo-and-abuse-california-s-wine-country)

1229.2843.text: If eating meat is immoral because animals feel pain, then eating plants may also be immoral. Scientists have been applying the strategies of animal behavior research to plants and finding that plants share many of the characteristics of animals - including an awareness of their environment, of injury \(pain\), memory \(non-genetic\), and the ability to communicate. If consuming beings that feel pain is immoral, and both plants and animals feel pain, where does that leave us?[\[1\]](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CrrSAc-vjG4)[\[2\]](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q-4w5xYLwiU)

1229.5232.text: Time is relative for each living thing. Plants/trees live for 100s of years, they just don't feel the same amount of pain as animals do because of their slow growth. However, you're still hurting them. For example, think of us as trees and mosquitoes as humans.

1229.5254.text: Increased farming to produce more plant foods will result in an increase in the amount human exploitation in countries where work regulations and workers rights are poor. Perhaps these concerns should be addressed first?

1229.5774.text: We don't eat other humans. Why? Because we're so similar to them, so we feel strong empathy. Animals share much of the same DNA, biology and even emotions as humans, so we feel strong empathy for them as well. Plants, however, are from a separate biological kingdom, and work very differently from both humans and animals. Although we do have to eat some organic food to survive, we can choose the source that causes the least suffering from our human perspective.

1229.5775.text: Workers can suffer in both plant and animal agriculture, so this not an argument for or against either of them.

1229.5840.text: Eating botanical fruit from plants is not damaging to the plant in any way, so it is not cruel. Some vegetables are actually, in the botanical sense, fruit. Conversely, eating root vegetables, for example, is damaging to the plant. But since plants are not biologically designed to feel pain, it is not cruel to eat them.

1229.5969.text: Assuming this was true, consuming meat indirectly consumes vast amounts of plants that are used as animal feed. Eating meat means indirectly contributing to the death of both plants and animals, not animals instead of plants.

1229.6162.text: Cruelty suggests suffering. As plants lack any sensory system, and by observation take longer to die, it is perhaps safer to assume that less suffering means less pain. As plants do not experience physical pain, such a claim is moot.

1229.6901.text: Deontologian ethics support this claim. Since slaughter is ultimately an act of violence, it is certain that someone being mean to animals is more likely to act violently against others.

1229.10490.text: This argument isn't leading anywhere. If we used the proposed metric of "deserving something only by doing the difficult task\(s\) for it", most vegetarians/vegans would have to live from water and fresh air, as they surely wouldn't manage to till a huge farm, containing everything they eat, either.

1229.6630.text: This implies that caring for animals or caring for people is a binary choice. It isn't. There are those who are well placed and willing to care for people and those who prefer to serve the animal kingdom. As a species we don't just have one idea at a time and follow that to conclusion before we pursue another. It benefits all if humans divide their attentions between various issues and problems we face.

1229.6838.text: Humans have freedom of choice to some extent, animals subdued by humans don't. The very intention of help urges it to go where is most needed. And so far never was [any biggest](http://www.adaptt.org/about/the-kill-counter.html), flagrant and needless cruelty and slaughter as that towards industrial farm animals.

1229.10814.text: Moral values are pertinent to objective effects where particular individuals, groups, religions or school of thought only follow different approaches and/or differently subjectively weigh certain aspects or effects. In this case, these may for example differently weigh a\) the importance or moral imperative of avoiding suffering, miserable lives, lifespans much shorter than potential lifespans and b\) to which degree this applies to non-human animals that are less sentient than average humans.

1229.6948.text: It is not realistic to treat all living things equally and apply the same moral code.

1229.2103.text: Millions of animals are [killed](http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=97836&page=1) every year to allow for appropriate land to grow crops such as wheat and barley.

1229.2105.text: A [study](http://freefromharm.org/common-justifications-for-eating-animals/comparing-animal-deaths-production-plant-animal-foods/) done on how many animals die to produce 1,000,000 calories of a number of different food sources found that for vegetables it is only 2.55 animals, while for beef it is 29 animals and for chicken it is 251.1. This suggests significantly fewer animals are harmed in the production of vegetarian products.

1229.2106.text: Converting land to make it suitable for harvesting soybeans and other vegetable products results in [habitat loss](http://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/footprint/agriculture/impacts/habitat_loss/) that threatens entire ecosystems.

1229.2271.text: Since animals hurt by vegetarian farming are hurt as an unintended consequence, while producing meat necessarily involves killing animals, the former is moral and the latter is not.

1229.750.text: The dairy and egg industries cause extreme animal maltreatment that is arguably on a par with the meat and fishing industries.

1229.2802.text: Killing pests - not just insects but large, intelligent animals - is a necessity on farms of any kind.

1229.3080.text: Land must be cleared both for farming crops and rearing livestock, so the cumulative damage done by vegetarian farming is still lower.

1229.3702.text: When we eat vegetables we are taking away food that animals could possibly eat. This could harm them in the long run.

1229.3797.text: Over time indirect animal deaths from farming could be reduced, if this was an explicit goal.

1229.4042.text: The argument is an example of [Whataboutism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whataboutism) aka [Tu quoque logical fallacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tu_quoque), and therefore does not directly refute the argument that eating meat is wrong.

1229.4663.text: Food production for humans will always directly or indirectly disturb the ecosystem of other animals. If we take that as a given then we have to ask ourselves what types of harm to animals and the broader ecosystem are acceptable tradeoffs when producing food.

1229.2919.text: Raising farm animals ultimately kills more plants than raising plant foods, due to the amount of feed required to raise the animals.

1229.6212.text: Insects are not what many people would consider "sentient animals", although they technically are. "Minimizing" the harm to a smaller volume of animals, or to animals from a specific phylum is sort of splitting hairs.

1229.6904.text: Most farmed animals live miserable lives on factory farms, which is arguably a more important consideration than the number of animals killed.

1229.5262.text: Morality is best described as an ideal way "to be." This coincides with natural law. The most basic natural law seems to be that a system must adapt to subjugate other less-adapted systems \(eat or be eaten\). All moral systems are subservient to this basic universal morality. Thinking we may or should transcend that construct, when we are, ourselves, products of it, reeks of hubris.

1229.119.text: Every organism on earth dies or is killed at some point, so other organisms can live. This is how nature works.

1229.3843.text: Keeping animals for slaughtering is a lot more humane then letting them die through natural ways such as predation, starvation or disease.

1229.4408.text: People should treat things \(other humans, animals, plants, or minerals\) according to their natures. It is natural for a prey animal to be eaten, and so there is nothing immoral in eating it.

1229.5321.text: As humans are animals the logical extension of this is that humans should be allowed to kill each other without consequences. Clearly we have progressed beyond such fatalism.

1229.5322.text: Humans, as the dominant species on Earth, have transcended the natural order in countless ways. We are no longer required to kill to survive and so have no excuse for not taking on higher moral obligations.

1229.4032.text: There is nothing natural about factory farming and caging, controlling, and herding "prey" animals on a day to day basis. This cannot be argued to be treating said "prey" animals "according to their natures".

1229.5393.text: Many natural things, like murder, rape, or leaving offspring to die are deeply immoral. The consumption of meat is immoral on similar grounds.

1229.5406.text: If we are concerned about the death and harm of animals the logical extension of this care is to do as much as possible to prevent animals from dying in the wild. That we don't do so supports the idea we accept that this natural dynamic of predator-prey is not always overridden by animal welfare concerns.

1229.5578.text: It may be natural for reflectively rational creatures like humans to become aware of the consequences of their actions and to abstain from doing things like eating meat.

1229.5667.text: Humankind has exceeded 8 billion individuals in size. this achievement was possible due to unnatural mechanisms. Humankind has not followed the natural order \(at least\) since the industrial revolution. The concept of morality today is different from the concept of morality in pre-historic times.

1229.5670.text: If predation is the natural order of the world, then humans should actually predate rather than blindly consuming meat from sources they are not familiar with. Humans desiring to eat meat should go into the wild, kill the wild animal, and then consume it. However, many people are more comfortable with blindly consuming animals whose death they do not have to consider — this is not the 'natural order' at all.

1229.5737.text: Equating "natural" and "not immoral" clearly could be used to justify any activity and status quo, and is a fallacy. Eating meat must be judged not simply on whether it is "natural", but whether it is necessary \(in todays advanced society\), and in the context \(e.g. what is best for humans? for society? for the animals?\)

1229.5763.text: It may not be immoral to eat other animals, but the fact that having to grow animals to satisfy this need creates environmental issues may make it immoral.

1229.5987.text: If domesticated animals are raised ethically in a way as to have reasonable lives, then they are allowed to exist and experience life, where in a world without meat farming they probably would not.

1229.6219.text: This isn't just an issue about morality or natural order. This is also an issue about resources, raising animals, fishing and a lot of other related activities consume lots of resources. Population is growing and with the population, the needs of humanity as a whole. The massive amounts of resources needed for meat mass consuption in todays format is an ineficient and irresponsable use of the resources of the planet, which will unavoidibly affect humanity itself as well as the whole planet.

1229.5595.text: Nature is much more cruel in the way of animal on animal violence. When humans kill most animals for food it is done in a fast and humane way.

1229.6961.text: If eating meat is morally wrong and we are obligated to minimize the meat humans eat, we are also morally obligated to minimize the meat other animals eat.

1229.10582.text: Just like other animals, it is simply part of the food chain for us to eat meat.

1229.2024.text: Animals are unable to conceptualise of morality therefore they do not deserve to exist within our moral community.

1229.2030.text: The fact that humans have developed to a greater extent than animals means that they should have the ability to use animals for their own ends.

1229.2035.text: Humans should not have the authority to make decisions about animals given we do not have perfect information about their experiences.

1229.2064.text: Animals should have rights because they are sentient beings.

1229.2083.text: Eating meat violates animals' right to life.

1229.2885.text: Animals do in fact have rights. Many forms of cruelty are explicitly outlawed. One cannot, for instance, torture a dog for years in their basement. Therefore the statement that animals do not have rights is fundamentally false.

1229.3231.text: Rights by their nature correspond to duties. Since the actions of animals lack moral content they can't be said to have duties; we don't talk about a tiger or a cow being morally good or bad, or assign moral obligations to them, because by their nature they are not rational beings.

1229.3281.text: Animals not having rights doesn't imply in any way that killing and torturing them for our consumption is moral.

1229.3582.text: There is no trait that makes animals different than humans that if the same logic were applied to a human, it would justify farming that human as meat.

1229.4367.text: Rights are socially constructed by fallible and limited humans. Animals not having enforced 'rights' does not mean that it is okay to do anything to animals, only that the humans in a position of power creating rights did not think it worthwhile to give them rights.

1229.4347.text: Animals are only given rights by us. If we were, as a society, to say that animals don’t have rights then they wouldn’t have rights. Ethics aren’t inherent for beings that aren’t capable of complex thought. A dog is only able to understand that the rumble in their stomach means they’re hungry — they can’t contemplate whether or not they truly exist or what it means to know something.

1229.4813.text: From a utilitarian metric, life itself has no value, but rather the emotions experienced in life is what matters. The way we harvest animals is considerably less painful than how a vast majority of animals will die naturally — such as being slowly torn apart by their predators.

1229.5266.text: Animals don't lack rights, and even if they did, they shouldn't. We should consider cruelty to animals immoral for the same reason we consider cruelty to humans immoral. It is an affront to the empathy we share with living beings.

1229.5476.text: Historically, there have been times when certain categories of humans did not ‘have rights.’ Many of those rights were denied due to a supposed ‘inferiority’ to groups in power, who possessed ‘rights.’ In some cases, those humans were born explicitly for exploitation. We now regognize how wrong those policies are and have been working past the problematic moral dilemmas and inequities these policies caused. It’s a moral imperative that we do the same with other species.

1229.5829.text: Rights are inalienable and "endowed by our creator". They are not given just by law which why it is morally defensible to challenge laws that attempt to deny rights. Even though current law does not give rights to animals, it does not mean that animals do not have them under the principles through which the concept of rights was created.

1229.6604.text: In most religions, animals lack souls/spirits, putting them decisively into a different moral category than humans, permitting a different set of ethics.

1229.10608.text: All [predatory species](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnivore) of animals - and even some plants such as the [venus fly trap](https://www.livescience.com/58021-venus-flytrap-facts.html) and [pitcher plant](http://www.bbc.com/earth/story/20150420-the-giant-plants-that-eat-meat) - consume animal flesh to sustain themselves.

1229.10620.text: It is immoral to needlessly and intentionally kill a sentient being. In most cases where an animal is killed, it is done for pleasure rather than necessity.

1229.80.text: If the taste is imitable there is no need to actually eat meat, as one can consume other vegetarian products with the same "fantastic" taste.

1229.208.text: They do not imitate meat because of the taste, but because consumers do not want to miss out on certain dishes that usually contain meat, for example burgers.

1229.197.text: Meat analogues based on soy protein or wheat gluten are [getting close](http://spectrum.ieee.org/energy/environment/the-better-meat-substitute) to imitating the taste and texture of real meat and have been part of the [food culture](http://edition.cnn.com/2014/01/15/travel/10-things-taiwan/) in places such as Taiwan for a long time.

1229.1613.text: Scientists have developed a so-called "[facon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegetarian_bacon)", which is a vegetarian bacon.

1229.2634.text: Until artificial meat is provided at a competitive price, people will eat animals because meat is a simple and nourishing food.

1229.5340.text: Meat "imitations" are helpful in terms of transition to vegetarianism. Experienced vegetarians do not need such products, therefore meat "imitations" are not an attempt to fill in some void in vegetarian diet.

1229.1411.text: Soy or seitan products can exhibit a big variety of tastes because of the different spices added.

1229.81.text: The taste of vegetables, fruits and grains is popular as well.

1229.1480.text: Unless the taste, smell, texture and consistency of meat can be precisely imitated, some people would disagree. This point has not yet been reached, hence non-meat products do not offer an equivalent experience to everybody.

1229.2470.text: If that actually were the case, people wouldn't be eating meat.

1229.3137.text: If it were the case that non-meat products were universally as good as meat, then vegetarians would not try, and also not to such a degree fail, to replicate the taste of meat.

1229.3739.text: Meat imitation products are expensive and are not a viable option for low-income individuals and families.

1229.4974.text: Faux meats are getting better over time as more people demand it. With more demand fake meats will taste better.

1229.4975.text: The very knowledge that one is eating an animal is pleasurable to many people and cannot be imitated with non-animal products. Certain meats carry status in many cultures, such as beef in the US.

1229.2132.text: [Artificial meat](http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/03/artificial-chicken-grown-cells-gets-taste-test-who-will-regulate-it), which imitates the taste of real meat but is lab-grown, is being developed and could replace the taste experiences of real meat without the harm caused to animals, and with significantly less environmental consequences.

1229.5530.text: Vegetarian food offers more choices when meat is taken off the food plate. Usually there are small number of meat choices \(mostly chicken or beef with the occasional turkey, fish, and seafood\). The substitutions for this are numerous, from extra sides to faux meats.

1229.4774.text: In fact, meat itself has little to no taste, it's the texture it has and spices and flavors we add to it that makes it delicious. Other textured proteins like soy can have the same delicious taste and be almost unrecognizable.

1229.6370.text: Taste is an acquired habit. Some cultures that eat dogs, snakes, rabbits, snails etc. also do it because they acquired those tastes even though in other cultures eating one or more of those animals is considered disgusting. Same is with vegan food. There are several cultures that promote vegetarianism and of late veganism has also grown significantly. Also, all spices and flavorful ingredients added to food to enrich taste, like pepper, chilies, garlic, ginger, basil etc are all in fact, plants.

1229.6011.text: Eating is pleasurable in general. Finding more pleasure in one food type than in another is subjective and largely determined by personal experience with recepies and cooking, family traditions, memories, habits of one's environment, etc.

1229.6706.text: Stopping eating meat just means dropping a few ingredients. There are lots and lots of ingredients left to use and be creative with.

1229.336.text: There are many restaurants that do not offer meatless products.

1229.361.text: Meat has to be prepared, whereas most vegetables can already be consumed in their raw state.

1229.742.text: Although meat is convenient and consumer-friendly in the short run, our current levels of meat consumption are harmful to [the climate](https://www.chathamhouse.org/publication/changing-climate-changing-diets), [our health](http://www.bbc.com/news/health-28797106) and thus the convenience of our existence in the long run.

1229.864.text: Processed meat products such as hot dogs or [BiFi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BiFi) are easy to consume to-go products.

1229.1473.text: Human behavior should not simply be based upon questions of convenience, as other factors weigh heavier.

1229.1469.text: It is sometimes difficult to be on a meatless diet, especially if you do not have the time to cook for yourself or if you eat out with friends.

1229.1663.text: There are many meatless foods which are also convenient and consumer friendly, such as bread, pasta, fruits, cookies etc.

1229.1761.text: Not eating meat limits food options. [Four out of ten](https://faunalytics.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/Faunalytics_Current-Former-Vegetarians_Full-Report.pdf) former vegetarians state that it was difficult to stay "pure" in terms of their diet and that they were bored with the available food options.

1229.6013.text: In a more precarious context, with a small budget and little time, pleasure can more easily be found through meat consumption. The food market is still largely organised around meat consumption, making it easily accesible and cheap through mass-production. Quality cooking without meat requires more skill, more time and more fresh ingredients.

1229.4741.text: Many people are pushed to give up many forms of satisfaction, such as taking time to have fun, learn a skill, or explore the world, because they are not productive ways to spend time. Cooking and eating are basic needs that can still be pleasurable, making food-related pleasures special and worthy of moral consideration.

1229.5123.text: Concepts of right and wrong are formed by societies, and thus decided by popularity.

1229.5124.text: As people decide what choices are "right" or "wrong" based on how the choices serve the end goals they happen to value--be those goals the raising the quality of life of the world as a whole, just that of humans, or making more money as an individual--and those goals may not be shared by all of one's population, right and wrong are in fact concepts isolated from popular opinion.

1229.5568.text: Some ethical systems are built upon the concept of pleasure as the highest good \(hedonic morality\), so pleasure does indeed factor into judgments of right and wrong.

1229.6285.text: It is not morally justifiable to value one's own taste over an animal's life.

1229.6314.text: Both popularity and pleasure are relevant to "right and wrong", or the concerns of ethics and morality. They certainly do not equate to morality on a one to one basis, not are they interchangeable with ethics or morality, but they are entirely relevant. Nearly every attempt at a cohesive system of ethics must take into account what is pleasurable to the individual and the larger society as well as the beliefs held by the majority of the population.

1229.10674.text: This [begs the question](https://examples.yourdictionary.com/reference/examples/begging-the-question-fallacy-examples.html)(Technically speaking, to beg the question is not a logical fallacy. This is because it is logically valid, in the strictest sense, but it is utterly unpersuasive. The thing that you are trying to prove is already assumed to be true, so you are not actually adding anything to the argument. It would be like saying a product is the most expensive because it has the highest price.) that eating meat of any kind is immoral or unethical. If eating meat is not immoral, then taste and pleasure are relevant for the discussion.

1229.4653.text: Killing and harming animals for other sensual experiences is already deemed immoral. \(E.g. for visual entertainment in movies, bull fighting, dog-fights etc.\) There is no reason that tasting should be treated differently.

1229.4226.text: If pleasure is something that makes an action right, then something which causes the opposite - a lack of pleasure, or worse, a large amount of pain - such as torturing and slaughtering animals, is wrong.

1229.4076.text: Since humans have a higher level of consciousness and experience than animals, it is possible that the pleasure of eating meat is greater than the suffering animals experience from a quick, painless death \(depending on the farm, treatment, etc.\).

1229.6454.text: As humans live in more advanced societies, it becomes less moral for those humans to eat meat.  If it's "eat meat or starve," there's no moral issue there at all.  On the other hand, if eating meat is simply one more lifestyle choice, it is significantly less moral, because if you ascribe animals any moral value at all \(ask, "Do I think torturing animals for fun is okay?"\), then at some point their moral value outweighs the fleeting human desire for "tasty".

1229.6580.text: The claim seems to be that pleasure is good and therefore the act of eating meat for some people is pleasurable and therefore good. However, in the quantity of suffering vs pleasure, eating meat comes at a staggering cost of suffering at a level that far exceeds the pleasure experienced by people. If all 7 billion people were eating meat and enjoying it, that is far fewer than the 56 billion animals slaughtered every year and the billions more suffering on factory farms. [www.animalequality.net](https://www.animalequality.net/food)

1229.6792.text: There is no moral justification for eating meat that is more convincing than a justification for not eating meat while having the alternatives that there are today. The "superior taste of meat products" can not be part of a moral justification when it comes to killing living beings.

1229.10640.text: Sensory pleasure cannot be used as a justification for eating meat because we would never accept it as a justification for any other ethically questionable act.

1229.10718.text: Animals are believed to have sentience and hence quality of life as well, so the degradation in their life may be greater than the benefit of eating meat.

1229.10536.text: Death and suffering could easily be ignored; even though we don't need to eat meat to survive, we certainly don't need to stop killing animals for ethical reasons if you don't care about them

1229.10822.text: This depends on how one values non-human animals' quality of life \(this may be difficult to assess\), their suffering \(this varies per living conditions and slaughter practice\), and their early death \(when compared to potential lifespan\). The quality of life of insects is not a common subject of ethics and similarly the treatment of other animals has little ethical value to many.

1229.140.text: We may only talk of a 'natural' process when observing the ways of indigenous tribes such as the Inuit, who hunt and prepare their meat themselves, and do not over-consume or waste their prey. The majority of humankind today do not share these same, natural practices.

1229.241.text: Chaffing male chickens right after their hatching is anything but natural.

1229.630.text: The potential of human's progress has already been there from the very beginning, like the potential of a flower is already in its seed. So how humans live today is the real natural way, not the underdeveloped states before.

1229.1779.text: Meat requires [preservatives](http://www.foodauthority.nsw.gov.au/_Documents/industry/preservative_use_in_processed_meats.pdf) so it does not spoil.

1229.4647.text: Carnivores have a place in the ecosystem, but the human practice of eating domestic meat does not satisfy the requirement of ecological benefit and therefore becomes harmful at scale.

1229.136.text: Humans have abandoned or modified behaviours that were once considered natural.

1229.1576.text: That ancestors ate meat is an evidence proven fact and no social construction.

1229.2597.text: [A study](http://ww.w.humanecologyreview.org/pastissues/her101/101gossardyork.pdf) looking into the reasons for individuals' 'Environmentally Significant Consumption' found that social structural factors, macro-economic structure and psychological factors can all offer an explanation of the meat \(or lack thereof\) consumption patterns of individuals.

1229.3239.text: Something is natural if it occurs in nature, without modern human interference. Its definition never changed and is certainly not a human construct.

1229.5064.text: The digestion of meat and the absorption of its many nutrients, are not social constructs.

1229.5789.text: The consideration of the superiority of any diet, including a meatless one, is equally a construct.

1229.5565.text: Arguing that eating meat is human nature and inherent to humanity is the "appeal to nature" fallacy. [yourlogicalfallacyis.com](https://yourlogicalfallacyis.com/appeal-to-nature)

1229.1986.text: According to [authoritynutrition.com](https://authoritynutrition.com/7-evidence-based-health-reasons-to-eat-meat/), "Humans also have canines, with big brains, opposing thumbs and the ability to make tools to hunt. Meat was one of the reasons humans were able to evolve such large, elaborate brains." It is in our nature to eat meat, seeing as we were created with the necessary attributes to efficiently hunt and eat meat.

1229.2737.text: Consuming meat enabled the brains of our ancestors to evolve and [grow](https://www.livescience.com/24875-meat-human-brain.html) dramatically over a period of a few million years.

1229.3350.text: A diet with meat helped humans develop into humans [Sorry Vegans: Here's How Meat-Eating Made Us Human](http://time.com/4252373/meat-eating-veganism-evolution/).

1229.3850.text: Just because something was necessary or relevant in the past [doesn't make it necessary or relevant in the current context](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_fallacy). While eating meat did provide the caloric intake necessary for the development and evolution of the human brain, this fact holds no bearing in the modern age, where meat consumption is not tied to survival in many instances.

1229.4719.text: By the same logic we have not reached some kind of endpoint to this evolution, and in keeping with that one might consider that with those brains comes a self awareness, and with that self awareness comes the higher-order human traits such as compassion and empathy, and with these higher order traits come new aspirations and new appetites for self-actualisation. Just as clean air was desired after industrialisation, eliminating cruelty from ones diet will continue to be a big part of our future.

1229.5017.text: The adoption of eating meat caused the human brain to grow and increase in power, leading to the modern human as we know it. [Eating Meat Made Us Smarter- NPR](https://www.npr.org/2010/08/02/128849908/food-for-thought-meat-based-diet-made-us-smarter)

1229.6263.text: We all know well that we simply are what we eat. So basically saying that the type of food which really helped us expand, evolve and make all that progress is bad equals to saying that a priori we shouldn't have been expanding and evolving all this time.

1229.1095.text: Humans are superb [endurance](https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2004/11/041123163757.htm) runners - an important skill for chasing prey.

1229.1129.text: Human evolution, physiology and behavior are adapted to hunting and the consumption of meat. Humans have thus [been called](https://www.amazon.com/Hunting-Hypothesis-Conclusion-Concerning-Evolutionary/dp/0988604388?ie=UTF8&*Version*=1&*entries*=0) a "fully evolved hunting animal".

1229.2199.text: Vegetarianism is a greater part of our genetic heritage than meat-eating. Rationale: Apes spent more time evolving during the Miocene than the early humans \(which is a sub-group of the apes\) did later during the Pleistocene.  All other apes are almost vegetarians.\([livescience.com](https://www.livescience.com/51017-ape-facts.html),[newscientist.com](https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn3966-ape-diet-lowers-bad-cholesterol-levels/)\)

1229.2213.text: It's easier to gather a plant than to hunt an animal. Therefore our ancestors were more gatherers than hunters.

1229.2846.text: The structure of the human body, such as upright posture and density of sweat gland distribution, suggest an evolutionary advantage towards persistence hunting due to unparalleled heat mitigation. [Waterlogged by Dr. Tim Noakes](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nlmcatalog/101587029)

1229.3453.text: Human dentition is designed to mechanically process both meat and vegetables. Millions of years of evolution have shaped us with canine teeth to be able to pierce meat. We have genetic code for enzymes that process meat in our DNA and have been omnivorous since the earliest human relatives. The problem is not the humans should stop eating meat, the problem is the process for how the meat makes it to our plates.

1229.3660.text: Eating meat has created social structure from group hunting which helped with intelligence and creating societies. We are who we are because we eat meat.

1229.4276.text: Human beings have long been understood to be omnivores. Perhaps the arguments "eating less meat is better" or "substituting land-mammal meat with farmed fish is better" would be more persuasive.

1229.5320.text: Whilst we may have been hunter-gatherers in the past it does not mean we should continue to be. Continuing to be hunter-gatherers on the basis that we were known as hunter-gatherers is an [Appeal to Tradition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appeal_to_tradition)

1229.561.text: Humans have not evolved to hunt, eat, or digest meat very successfully.

1229.4666.text: As a species we are good hunters, not only as a result of our superb reasoning skills, but because of possession of many biological adaptations which are specific to carnivorous animals.

1229.10800.text: The part of "hunting animals" has now been superseded by industrial food production, leaving only meat consumption as "something typical" from early human times.

1229.10802.text: Many humans or human populations were largely vegetarian over long stretches of time. Anthropological studies substantially challenge such beliefs and some sources even claim that "Human ancestors were nearly all vegetarians".[\[1\]](https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/human-ancestors-were-nearly-all-vegetarians/)[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paleolithic_diet)[\[3\]](https://phys.org/news/2022-10-ancient-humans-paleo-diet.html)[\[4\]](https://www.inverse.com/culture/real-paleo-diet-had-carbs)[\[5\]](https://www.inverse.com/science/the-real-paleo-diet)

1229.1267.text: Thanks to un-natural means such as modern medicine the lifespan of humans has [increased tremendously](https://www.nia.nih.gov/sites/default/files/global_health_and_aging.pdf). The lifespan of our closest primate relatives, who are presumed to live a natural lifestyle, is [merely half](http://bigthink.com/videos/natures-calling-how-long-should-humans-live) of ours.
