1229.2712.text: Glasses, wheelchairs, and other such inventions have greatly added to the quality of life of those nature would leave in a quite poor position.

1229.10614.text: While an entirely natural lifestyle may not be essential, there are many aspects of modern human life that are unhealthy because they are unnatural. Thus, one cannot rule out the possibility that in at least some cases, a more natural lifestyle is the healthiest.

1229.2792.text: Our development of cooling technology has centered around the preservation of meat.

1229.2793.text: Bone is a good material that we used to make our early tools.

1229.2794.text: Animal skins are an effective source of protective clothing.

1229.2791.text: Without meat we probably would have died, which would have hindered our advancement greatly.

1229.3403.text: Replacements for much of its value to survival are available, as per the study of nutrition.

1229.3404.text: Attempting to minimize the presence of meat in our diets, or remove it from them, would also drive technological progression.

1229.5128.text: Our ancestors ate meat, allowing them more free time \(away from agriculture\) and thus allowing our early technologies to blossom.

1229.793.text: There are ancient vegetarian tribes, such as [Etyottydaih](http://www.earthisland.org/journal/index.php/elist/eListRead/an_ancient_vegetarian_tribe_struggles_to_keep_its_traditions_alive/). Eating meat was not an important cultural component for all ancient human tribes.

1229.3409.text: Historically, many behaviours could have been considered "a central part of human nature and thus inherent to humankind" yet are now considered abhorrent and forbidden, such as murder for resources on an individual level.

1229.6749.text: Following that line of thought we could also say that violence, murders, rapes, and man's exploitation by man are all a central part of human nature. But this doesn't explain why they should be considered as right or wrong.

1229.1423.text: [Eating](https://askentomologists.com/2015/02/11/journey-through-time/) insects is equally part of human nature but was abandoned by some parts of humanity.

1229.166.text: This does not explain why many people find products such as alcohol, tabacco or drugs \(that are not necessary nor useful for our body, but rather harming\) tasty.

1229.169.text: Just because something is useful does not mean that it is necessary in any way.

1229.2020.text: Our brains evolved at a time when food was scarce and we needed to maximise our intake or we would not survive. Thus it incentivised us to consume food rich in nutrients; an instinct that is no longer necessary.

1229.3848.text: The quality of "tasty" is a fluid concept based more on the idea of [appetitive and aversive taste stimuli](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/two-great-tastes-not-great-together/). Indeed, while appetitive tastants \(e.g. sugar, salt, umami\) signal calorie-rich foods the organism should consume, high concentrations of these [tastants can actually become aversive](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature11905).

1229.3861.text: Just because our sensory systems convey that meat is good \(i.e. pleasurable\), [that doesn't mean that we can extrapolate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturalistic_fallacy) that it's morally "good" to eat meat.

1229.4715.text: Not only is it impossible to say that enjoying the taste of meat is universal but for many the thought of animal suffering accompanies the act and undermines any potential for "pleasure" to be derived from it.

1229.10688.text: While meat is considered a tasty source of protein, there are many vegetarian dishes around the world that are comparably protein-dense and delicious.

1229.10692.text: Many plant-based foods do not naturally have enough [vitamin B12](https://www.healthline.com/health/vitamin-b12-foods-for-vegetarians#_noHeaderPrefixedContent)(Plant-based foods do not naturally contain B12, so people who follow a vegetarian diet or vegan diet need to make sure they get enough each day to avoid a deficiency.\n\nA lack of vitamin B12 can lead to serious health consequences, such as pernicious anemia.) for a healthy diet, so many vegetarians must take supplements to remain healthy.

1229.10812.text: Many non-animal natural sources of protein could replace it, including microbial protein and various pulses \(such as Quorn, pea products and white beans\). Many of these have also been consumed for a long time and have a higher share of protein than meats.

1229.2164.text: Meat production uses twice as much land, water, and feed to produce the same amount of [calorie intake](https://www.economist.com/blogs/feastandfamine/2013/12/livestock) as other foods.

1229.2165.text: [It takes](https://www.economist.com/blogs/feastandfamine/2013/12/livestock) two kg of grain to produce one kg of chicken, and between five and twenty kg of grain to produce one pound of beef.

1229.2170.text: While the practices of meat production in high-income industrialised countries tend to be resource inefficient, meat production in other countries is [a lot more efficient](https://www.forbes.com/sites/timworstall/2012/09/03/it-does-not-take-7-kg-of-grain-to-make-1-kg-of-beef-be-very-careful-with-your-statistics/#1fc7709d5f0d). Rather than ceasing production altogether, we should ban inefficient methods of production.

1229.2282.text: A lot of the world's crops are currently used for animal feed, rather than human consumption.

1229.2558.text: Irrigation systems channel a catchment's water to agricultural uses rather than lead it follow it's natural path over a landscape. This deprives natural water ways and landscapes of their water supply and degrades local ecosystems.

1229.2563.text: Agricultural use of water disrupts the water table equilibrium and leads to [desertification](https://www.greenfacts.org/en/desertification/l-2/4-causes-desertification.htm) and [salinification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salinity_in_Australia).

1229.3291.text: There are countries where 99.9% of farming is grass fed. Industrial farming need not rely on grain - the nutrients are better, and the animals happier if you don't. Free range. Ethical farming practices would have one trying to replicate natural conditions. IMO, the same applies to agriculture, and recreating ecoystems/permaculture. We shouldn't I think, aim for the cheapest system - we should aim for the best system, to live on the earth, like we intend to stay here.

1229.4037.text: Meat is inefficient. In growing animals for meat consumption the animal will always consume a significantly larger energy content in plant matter than can be obtained from the meat of that animal \(less than 5%\). This is due to the animal wasting massive quantities of energy in heating, digestion and movement.

1229.1112.text: The demand for, and pollution of, water resources from farming animals is immense.

1229.5309.text: Energy obtained from meat is second hand energy. It was first processed through a plant that was eaten after. And in each level of the chain some of the energy is dissipated.

1229.6141.text: The amount of crops \(soy, corn, others\) that is fed to farm animals could feed more people if directly fed to humans. Therefore, meat aggravates world hunger and veganism can contribute to [ending world hunger](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/cutting-back-on-meat-consumption-could-help-end-hunger-by-2030-experts_us_55f3424ee4b077ca094f27a5).

1229.6024.text: Animals are able to produce calories from kinds of plants and organic matter that humans cannot. Plants also do not rely on the seasons to live, breed, or be harvested thus creating for a more stable food source.

1229.1511.text: According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN \(FAO\), 60% of the world’s agricultural land is used for grazing livestock and 1/4 of the world’s croplands is used for animal feed. In total, 2/3 of the world’s agricultural area and 1/3 of the total global land area is used for [maintaining livestock](https://www.ciwf.org.uk/includes/documents/cm_docs/2008/f/factory_farming_and_the_environment_1999.pdf).

1229.10548.text: [77%](https://www.onegreenplanet.org/news/chart-shows-worlds-land-used/) of the worlds agricultural land is given over to livestock production.

1229.5436.text: Meat production will always be less calorie-efficient than vegetarian food production, since grain must be produced to feed meat animals.

1229.2167.text: The production of meat uses up agricultural land that should instead be used to grow crops.

1229.2173.text: Agricultural land [worldwide](http://www.scidev.net/global/food-security/feature/sustainable-food-production-facts-and-figures.html) suffers from soil erosion and loss of soil nutrients, which make the land unfit for future agricultural production.

1229.2176.text: By 2050, the world will have to produce [50% more food](https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/food-blog/10-things-need-to-know-global-food-system) than it does now.

1229.2179.text: Current crop yields are [growing too slowly](https://hbr.org/2016/04/global-demand-for-food-is-rising-can-we-meet-it) to meet expected increases in food demand.

1229.2180.text: Climate change will [harm crop yields](https://hbr.org/2016/04/global-demand-for-food-is-rising-can-we-meet-it) by increasing global temperatures and extreme weather events.

1229.3294.text: There is a reasonable chance of large scientific innovations, like the [Green Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Revolution), drastically boosting our agricultural productivity without necessitating the removal of meat from our diets.

1229.3097.text: [Demographics demonstrate](http://www.prb.org/Publications/Datasheets/2012/world-population-data-sheet/fact-sheet-world-population.aspx) that developed nations' birth rate are far below the replacement rate.  As countries develop, overpopulation will be a non-issue.

1229.3830.text: The amount of crops grown for the meat industry is not efficient. Meaning we could feed the entire population of the US with less than half the crops used to feed the animals which are then slaughtered. [news.cornell.edu](http://news.cornell.edu/stories/1997/08/us-could-feed-800-million-people-grain-livestock-eat)

1229.4183.text: Actually, we currently are producing enough food to feed 10 billion people \(about 1.5 times or 150% as much food as we need\). The problem concerning starvation is actually a food distribution problem, which is part of the reason why obesity is so endemic in areas like the USA, while people starve in other countries.

1229.5035.text: [Meat is less efficient for acquiring vitamins than it used to be](http://baltimorepostexaminer.com/carnivores-need-vitamin-b12-supplements/2013/10/30). This causes people to overeat foods to make up for the inadequate dietary intake, which amplifies the growing food demand.

1229.2175.text: Mechanisms to reduce food waste could increase food production by [about 1/3rd](https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/food-blog/10-things-need-to-know-global-food-system).

1229.2178.text: Genetically modifying crops could [increase agricultural productivity, particularly in poor countries](http://www.econ.yale.edu/growth_pdf/cdp878.pdf).

1229.2187.text: [Vertical farming](https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/01/09/the-vertical-farm) could solve issues of scarce agricultural land.

1229.2188.text: New agricultural technologies are mostly experimental at this stage, and unlikely to be able to meet the large increases in food demand that are expected.

1229.2190.text: Agricultural productivity has, and will continue to, increase dramatically.

1229.3293.text: There are many many solutions to this. Marine permaculture, artificial lab grown meat, insect farming. However my greater point would be this - we will face an energy crisis, a water crisis as well as a food crisis, possibly an economic crisis and likely war in the mix. It is crisis that precipitates change, either these events will produce the desirable outcome, or we will die.

1229.3928.text: An exclusive plant-based agriculture to feed the growing world population wouldn't be the most efficient way. Many current pasturages can't be used for the cultivation of crops.

1229.4814.text: The world produces more food than necessary. A sizable portion of all food is wasted.

1229.10804.text: While there are various ways to do so, reducing meat consumption is one of the most effective ones as it for example takes up most of agricultural land.

1229.10806.text: That there are various ways does not mean that reduction of meat consumption is not required.

1229.3962.text: Non-meat food production will still make it easier for every person to be fed, and will be more efficient \(less wasteful\) for any given population size.

1229.3974.text: It is not reasonable to expect every single human on the planet to change their diet.

1229.4095.text: Yes. Eating meat is not inherently bad, because it is possible for a human population of a smaller size to eat meat at sustainable levels.

1229.3693.text: The Earth cannot support such a growing population even if meat consumption is halted.

1229.3513.text: It is generally poorer countries that have expanding populations. The first world has now reached a point of stagnant population growth - even declining populations, as in the case of Japan and others. The inability of poorer countries to control their populations should not impact the lives of those in the first world. The first world having earned their luxuries and should not be denied them.

1229.3530.text: Switching to a more efficient form of food production is unlikely to prevent us from reaching a carrying capacity in the long run. Changing farming to feed a growing world population is a never-ending treadmill. Instead, we should probably focus more on the ecological stability of a system we are creating.[See Jevons Paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jevons_paradox)

1229.4725.text: We manage to produce food for far more people than that. The problem is to transport it to them as it requires expenses and the investment does not come back --- poor countries are not able to pay for it. Through correct legislation, countries could ban supermarkets from wasting food and they would have to transport it to those in need of food, manage their supplies better, and stop trashing imperfectly shaped foods and veggies.

1229.5816.text: It is morally reprehensible to suggest the population should be reduced if you don't lead by example. Otherwise you are calling for the killing or restricted ability to procreate of others.

1229.5817.text: We absolutely have the ability to feed all of them, which can obviously be seen by the fact that we are feeding almost all of them right now, given that very few people in the world starve to death.

1229.4664.text: From an efficacy standpoint, it might make sense to promote reduced meat consumption as a bridge instead of a cudgel toward vegetarianism. Meatless Mondays got a ton of pushback at my University - for a few weeks.

1229.4763.text: We are already way past 7 billion people today and we need to prepare the world for tomorrow. Meat production is simply a waste of nutrients we cannot afford much longer. Limiting meat production instead of forbidding it would only make it a luxury good, thus even more desirable for the masses. Countries which once had only little meat consumption already copy the western lifestyle of eating lots of meat, because it is a symbol of wealth. Meat should be a symbol of exploitation instead.

1229.4914.text: It's not about the meat. The problem is unconscious consumerism. We eat far more meat than we need and buy far more stuff than we should. We need to look at the bigger picture instead of thinking that just ceasing to eat meat alone will solve the problem.

1229.5485.text: The population growth is predicted to flatten out in 2100. By then there will be [11.2 billion \(Page 2, figure 2\)](https://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/Publications/Files/WPP2017_KeyFindings.pdf) people on Earth. If we reduce the consumption of beef and eat more pork, fish and chicken, then we will be fine.

1229.6903.text: Most people will make no change at all, so conscious consumers should aim for 0 meat to offset that apathy and bring the average consumption closer to what it needs to be.

1229.5379.text: The practice and habit of moderation is much more difficult to follow successfully than simple abstention.

1229.5092.text: Civilized people, in cultures around the world, eat meat.

1229.6249.text: A desire to make vegetarian lifestyles more appealing or convenient have certainly lead to some innovations in food science, such as the development of "lab-grown" meat, or various other meat substitutes. It has also advanced the development of conventional food replacement systems, such as Soylent or Huel.

1229.6250.text: The idea that eating meat is less civilized than not eating meat is a subjective value judgement, which is neither sufficiently justified here, nor widely accepted.

1229.6972.text: Evolutionary speaking, hominids only had access to meat after coming down from the trees, which means eating meat came after eating fruits and vegetables, and is therefore more civilized. Moreover, eating meat required the invention of weapons to hunt, and the discovery of fire, furthering the correlation between meat and civilization.

1229.5199.text: It is important to be cautious of future consequences when qualifying the morality of an action. The scarcity of resources in the future is a relevant implication of eating meat in this discussion.

1229.5471.text: Because of the anticipation of scarce resources in the future, we ought to begin conserving resources now by stopping meat consumption.

1229.5797.text: There is no possible way to account accurately for how the advances of technology will be able to solve current limitations we have. You can't assume conditions will always be the same.

1229.10808.text: At this point it is clear that it is not only "potentially" becoming a problem, but has scientifically determined high likelihood or even certainty \(if e.g. population size roughly develops as projected\) of causing problems \(specifically major problems\) in the future. This concerns climate change[\[1\]](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-023-01605-8) and food production more broadly.

1229.5413.text: This is empirically false. The article at worldwatch references United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization \(FAO\). FAO we can see that land used for wheat, most common staple, have decreased by 25% while production has increased due to much greater yield per acre. 1986 vs 2016: [www.fao.org](http://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/QC)

1229.3347.text: How much meat to produce will be solved automatically by supply and demand. If food is scarce, prices will rise, and the most efficient forms of production will be favored.

1229.6307.text: The world's population will live in less ideal conditions by the continued production of meat products, compared to [plant](http://www.onegreenplanet.org/environment/facts-about-animal-agriculture-and-air-pollution/) products.

1229.6406.text: Starvation is due to people not having access to food, as opposed to there not being enough food to go around.

1229.704.text: The [meat](http://shrinkthatfootprint.com/food-carbon-footprint-diet) lover's diet has the worst carbon footprint: about double the amount of a vegan diet.

1229.682.text: [Livestock](http://www.worldwatch.org/global-meat-production-and-consumption-continue-rise-1) account for an estimated 18% of human-caused greenhouse gas emissions, producing 40% of the world’s methane and 65% of the world’s nitrous oxide.

1229.3933.text: Any major industry heavily contributes to climate change. This is not particular to meat production.

1229.4090.text: This does not make eating meat inherently wrong, because the massive scale of our population is the main cause of the massive scale of farming and therefore also the massive scale of green house gas emissions.

1229.4639.text: Farming meat has a disproportionate impact on the climate, contributing as many or more greenhouse gases than well-known polluters like cars and other industries.

1229.4699.text: Producing meat heavily contributes to climate change. Eating meat does not contribute to climate change. Even if it is true that humans should stop producing meat, it does not follow that humans should stop eating meat \(eg. from a hunted wild animal\).

1229.4859.text: It is critical to address climate change in order to prevent drastic effects \(up to and including mass extinctions\) on both humans and all other forms of life.

1229.5516.text: While meat production does entail production of [up to 9%](https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/sources-greenhouse-gas-emissions) of the world's greenhouse gases, the source of the carbon is less problematic than the other 91% of the carbon, mostly produced by fossil fuels. Cows belch methane, but this carbon originates from the atmosphere and goes back into the atmosphere in climate-boosted form. Fossil fuels take carbon formerly sequestered deep underground, and adds it to the atmosphere. So meat is problematic, but not in the same league as fossil fuel.

1229.5604.text: Meat's transport and storage requirements consume more resources and generate more emissions than for vegetables.

1229.5602.text: 22% of meat [ends up in landfills in U.S, Canada, Australia, & New Zealand, collectively](https://www.savethefood.com). Meat in landfills [releases methane, which is 35x as potent in Global Warming Potential as carbon dioxide](https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/understanding-global-warming-potentials) over the span of a century.

1229.5918.text: Focusing on the gasses released by live stock alone doesn't take into account the huge swathes of forest which are destroyed not only to house these animals, but also to grow feed. These forests are burned which releases large amounts of C02 and also takes away one of the best natural converters of carbon dioxide to oxygen. Feeding humanity with plants would require significantly less land use.

1229.6239.text: Producing meat only has a substantial impact on Carbon Dioxide and methane emissions. There are greenhouse gases with 32,000 times the Greenhouse Warming Potential \(GWP\) of CO2 and 4,289 times the GWP of Methane. Other greenhouse gases should be our priority as carbon emissions are reversible if re-forestation and re-greening efforts are made. [ghginstitute.org](http://ghginstitute.org/2010/06/28/what-is-a-global-warming-potential/)

1229.6476.text: The fact that meat eating and production contributes to climate change is not an argument for complete abstention from eating meat, it is only an argument for reducing the impact of meat eating, either through reduction in per capital amounts eaten or more sustainable farming practices.

1229.6684.text: The net effects of climate change are not obviously bad. There's no reason to believe the climate is perfectly optimized the way it is.

1229.6774.text: 1 kg of chicken produces 6,9 kg CO2 eq; 1 kg of vegetables about 1.5-2 kg CO2 eq \([www.greeneatz.com](http://www.greeneatz.com/foods-carbon-footprint.html)\). However, chicken has about 3-5 times more calories and up to 10 times as much protein as many vegetables, meaning you need to consume less of it on a kg to kg basis. A single mile in an airplane produces about 24 kg CO2 eq \([blueskymodel.org](http://blueskymodel.org/air-mile)\), about the same as 2 pounds of beef - so one single domestic flight will usually offset a person's meat-related carbon emissions for a whole year.

1229.6936.text: If humans stopped producing meat, the livestock would not simply disappear overnight and many of the animals could return to nature and reproduce.

1229.6971.text: Livestock-born GHG emissions have mostly been interpreted isolated from their ecosystemic context, ignoring their negligible significance within the global balance. There is no [scientific evidence](https://www.intechopen.com/books/forage-groups/domestic-livestock-and-its-alleged-role-in-climate-change), whatsoever, that domestic livestock could represent a risk for the Earth’s climate.

1229.10810.text: Current trajectories of dietary patterns alone would lead to failed Paris Agreement global climate goals.[\[1\]](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-023-01605-8) This means that if meat production is not mitigated, climate goals are likely to fail leading to many synergistic negative effects and risks on humans and civilization.

1229.2008.text: Many of the animals that we kill for meat, such as kangaroos or deer, are pests that are bad for natural ecosystems or for agriculture. Demand for their meat actually creates net benefits for the environment.

1229.255.text: A 2012 study, examining the impact of a typical week’s eating, showed that plant-based diets are [better for the environment](https://www.vegsoc.org/eatingsustainably) than those based on meat.

1229.2075.text: Livestock have severe effects on their immediate environment, causing issues such as  [overgrazing, compaction, and erosion](http://www.fao.org/newsroom/en/news/2006/1000448/index.html).

1229.2501.text: The vast amount of land required for animal agriculture leads to greater amounts of habitat loss.

1229.2914.text: There are many things that people do that have negative impacts on the environment which we would not want to complete stop doing.  For example, farming plants and trees, mining for construction, manufacturing of consumer electronics, etc. The negative impacts on the environment of farming animals is not a sufficient reason for the contention that all meat consumption should stop.

1229.4214.text: Many farm animals don't have their own native, wild habitat, and removing them from their farm habitat, by releasing them into the wild would very likely result in severe environmental, and ecological disruption. Many of these livestock would likely fail to survive in the wild, and others would likely displace existing species of plants and animals.

1229.4379.text: Many approaches to farming plants leads to monocultural agriculture practices that have a harmful impact on the wider environment.

1229.4380.text: In many cases land is best suited \(or only suited\) to farming meat; meaning that converting it to crops would be less efficient and thus cause greater environmental harms.

1229.4534.text: There is no moral imperative for the environment to remain in stasis or for us regard it as 'fundamentally' in need of preserving so. Heat death awaits the entire universe.

1229.5546.text: Plants can be grown in vertical farms, whereas animals cannot right now. Vertical farms use significantly less land through stacking.

1229.5553.text: Vegan foods offer little waste at the end since all of it could be turned to compost. This contrasts with the by-products of meat \(organs, fat, and bones\) that need to be re-purposed \(such as pet food\) for them not to get thrown away.

1229.5863.text: Eating meat causes human suffering, particularly in poor communities. Health problems in communities living near to animal agriculture operations and psychological problems in abbatoir workers.

1229.6179.text: Current industrialized fishing is responsable for getting many species of fish and other sea animals near extinction if not extinct already, which is detrimental to ocean's ecosystem.

1229.6477.text: If the impact is local, then the decision to prohibit meat eating and/or production should be local. This argument is relevant only to local policy and has no bearing on the absolute morality of meat eating and production.

1229.6677.text: Avoiding eating animals will help global bio-diversity in a big way. No longer will the planet be saturated with a few breeds of cows, chickens etc.

1229.6796.text: Regenerative livestock farmers worldwide are responsible for rehabilitating enormous tracts of land and in some cases helping bring at risk species of wildlife back into areas. I'm yet to see many grain and veg farmers to have a similar awareness.  [Stewardship with Vision](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yW82TiCagbE&list=PLpv166NSeBHuOkeZRoGm2950uxIJCrHap) is just one of many such projects.

1229.6827.text: There's an overpopulation of farm animals which is likely to be ["the leading cause of modern species extinctions"](https://mercyforanimals.org/overpopulation-is-destroying-the-planet-but)

1229.560.text: All forms of modern agriculture are neither natural nor ecologically functional, as they rely heavily on monocultures, [genetically modified crops](http://www.statista.com/statistics/217108/level-of-genetically-modified-crops-in-the-us/), and chemical fertilizers.

1229.66.text: A diet including meat can be sustainable and without negative consequences to the environment. It is not about what you eat, but about the right way of farming and keeping animals.

1229.4211.text: Eating meat is not the reason for environmental problems, over consumption and wasted food are more likely causes.

1229.3999.text: Raising animals for meat using responsible pasturing practices utilizes land that cannot be farmed, improves the soil and pasture to more closely mimic native prairie, supports the livelihood of the farmers and keeps the land in question free of harmful urban development.

1229.4875.text: Corporations and companies often advertise things in misleading ways, using phrases and imagery that suggests or implies one thing but really often means another. There is no guarantee that meat advertised as "environmentally friendly" actually is, the case may be that the producers only make some token efforts or use one specific strategy to be "environmentally friendly", only doing enough to legally make the claim.

1229.6839.text: Given that meat is more environmentally damaging than plants \(with a few exceptions and at least in terms of CO2 production and water consumption\), the choice for "environmentally friendly" farmed meat is still second-best.

1229.5434.text: For example, there is substantial evidence that insects [cannot feel pain](https://www.forbes.com/sites/quora/2016/07/12/are-insects-capable-of-feeling-pain/#b8ca415f20dc), so eating insect meat would not be immoral.

1229.5540.text: We should learn to eat more insects which are more ecologically friendly. There's also a lot more variety and some cultures have been doing it for millennia.

1229.6608.text: This argument assumes that sentience is the only objection to the consumption of animal products, failing to address the issues involved with the disruption of healthy ecosystems due to the large, growing human population.

1229.4892.text: It makes logical sense that cavemen would depict the animals and hunts that were most glorious, exciting, spectacular, or otherwise worthy of commemoration, rather than hunts and gatherings which would be seen as mundane and routine to them.

1229.173.text: The Michelin guide [recommends](http://www.therichest.com/expensive-lifestyle/food/10-michelin-recommended-vegetarian-restaurants/?view=all) plenty of vegetarian restaurants; there are more meat-serving restaurants listed simply because they appeal to a larger pool of potential guests.

1229.2207.text: Regardless of whether the correlation between prestigious cuisine and meat inclusion is necessary, it exists in the minds of many: chef and owner of Brighton's reputable Silo restaurant, Douglas McMaster, still cooks meat at his restaurant despite being vegetarian as meat usage is [“deeply engrained into fine dining cooking”](http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/vegetarian-chefs-who-have-to-eat-meat-silo-flat-three-a7715651.html).

1229.2208.text: A [study](https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1502/1502.03815.pdf) suggests that it is not specific ingredients that weigh most heavily on a cuisine's reputation at all, but its combinations of different flavours at a molecular level: the study indicates that the universal popularity of cuisines such as Indian comes not from its usage \(or non-usage\) of certain ingredients like meat, but from its combining of certain ingredients whose flavour compounds do not significantly overlap.

1229.791.text: The signature dish of one of the most famous chefs of all time, [Paul Bocuse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Bocuse), is a vegetarian truffle soup.

1229.265.text: Maghreb cuisine is reportedly highly reputable among the upper-class of Paris, featured on culinary [blogs](http://www.saveur.com/article/Travels/Maghreb-Cooking-in-Paris) particularly for its exquisite \(and, by chance, vegetarian\) cous cous dishes.

1229.847.text: In a high cuisine [full course dinner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_course_dinner) fish and meat are the central courses.

1229.844.text: In the 2015 iteration of the "[World’s 50 Best Restaurants](http://www.theworlds50best.com/)" ranking by the British magazine Restaurant, only a single entry makes any reference to vegetarian cuisine [\(#50](http://www.theworlds50best.com/list/1-50-winners/The-French-Laundry)\).

1229.6944.text: It only takes a few generations to forget how to cook.

1229.6945.text: It's not only about it being tasty. The point is that you can not, at the same time, stop consuming meat and preserve the culture and identity of the people cooking and enjoying these dishes.

1229.6946.text: True, humans will try to find ways to make their food enjoyable no matter what they eat. However, the sum of all the cultures and traditions that would get lost in the process is invaluable.

1229.3783.text: Bacon has become memetic in some circles. Memes do not necessarily correspond to reality, as exaggeration is socially encouraged for entertainment.

1229.4178.text: Speaking from personal experience, when I ate meat I did not like bacon. Others, both meat-eaters and vegetarians, have said the same. It may a pleasurable taste to you but that experience is not universal.

1229.2626.text: People who order their steak rare enjoy the flavor of the actual meat.

1229.2654.text: Meat has become [much less flavourful](http://nypost.com/2015/04/26/why-nothing-especially-chicken-tastes-like-it-used-to/) since the introduction - and subsequent rise - of factory-farming.

1229.3463.text: The texture of meat more then the flavor is what most people value, and it's hard to replicate.

1229.3592.text: Meat is usually not seasoned apart from salt. It is only processed meat that needs seasoning.

1229.3738.text: Bacon tastes amazing and is very rarely seasoned.

1229.4054.text: This argument is based off an assumption. Flavour and texture of meat is something that only a meat-eater can attest to. It is opinion based and thus can't be refuted logically, merely subjectively, which can't be a basis for rational argument.

1229.277.text: Meat has been a rare and expensive good for most of human history, so it could not have been a strong cultural component.

1229.328.text: Meat was nevertheless an important cultural component before its consumption in large doses became widespread. People highly valued it, but they simply could not afford it.

1229.785.text: Cultures are changing quickly and so meat eating can be phased out without causing harm.

1229.4139.text: The argument equivocates cultures of years past with current day cultures.  Modern cultures do, as you point out, consume meat as a central and normal role in diet.

1229.4675.text: Eating meat is culturally based. There is no biological or cultural evidence that sustains an obligatory diet based on animal flesh.

1229.360.text: [Cannibalism](http://quod.lib.umich.edu/w/wsfh/0642292.0038.007/--art-of-the-table-in-eighteenth-century-france?rgn=main;view=fulltext) was, in certain times and places, preferable to vegetarianism.

1229.2152.text: In early 18th century Europe, vegetables were believed to have no health benefits and to be almost impossible to digest.

1229.443.text: The potato can be viewed as the decisive innovation – even as a central [cultural norm](http://ieg-ego.eu/en/threads/backgrounds/food-and-drink#EarlyInternationalisationandInnovationsinthe17thand18thCenturiesPotatoesMaizeandHotDrinks) – during the emergence of the modern system of dishes and meals in the 18th century, but it only entered the dietary culture of the broad masses of central Europe during the 17th century.

1229.4708.text: That cultural convictions change does not imply they will change.

1229.796.text: Many of the animals hunted and consumed by our ancestors are now extinct, such as mammoths, mastodons, aurochs and cave bears.

1229.937.text: It does not matter what kind of animal is consumed or how it has been obtained: humans' meat consumption can still constitute a significant aspect of their valued culture today.

1229.3162.text: If humans stopped eating meat, this would arguably be due to the natural process of meat production becoming gradually unsustainable.

1229.177.text: In 675 AD, the use of livestock and the consumption of some wild animals \(horse, cattle, dogs, monkeys, birds\) was banned in [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_vegetarianism#Japan) by Emperor Temmu, due to the influence of Buddhism. During the twelve hundred years from the Nara period to the Meiji restoration in the latter half of the 19th century, Japanese people enjoyed vegetarian-style meals.

1229.201.text: The roots of [vegetarianism](https://www.sscnet.ucla.edu/southasia/Culture/Cuisine/vegetar.html) in India go back to the introduction of Buddhism and Jainism in the sixth century BCE.

1229.366.text: As poor countries grow richer and experience economic as well as cultural change, even in vegetarian-heavy places like India meat consumption is [becoming more popular](http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/eats/india-changing-appetites-include-meat-article-1.1255861) and vegetarianism is [falling out of favor](http://www.dw.com/en/vegetarians-developing-a-taste-for-meat/a-16490496).

1229.552.text: Although Taiwan has a strong vegetarian culture, its annual per-capita meat consumption has increased about four-fold since the country started to grow rich four decades ago \(from [20kg](https://ir.library.oregonstate.edu/xmlui/bitstream/handle/1957/34419/238.pdf?sequence=1) to [almost 80kg](http://blog.euromonitor.com/2015/08/meat-consumption-trends-in-asia-pacific-and-what-they-mean-for-foodservice-strategy.html)\).

1229.549.text: In China, and especially in its rural parts, a meatless diet is oftentimes the [result of poverty](https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=scpwmjE3TWYC&pg=PA64&dq=vegetarianism+poverty&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjv9rXl0PbMAhUFHqYKHU2uBwsQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=vegetarianism%20poverty&f=false), not of cultral factors, religion, philosophy or politics.

1229.551.text: As India is growing richer and as its people have more disposable income, meat consumption is [becoming more popular](http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/eats/india-changing-appetites-include-meat-article-1.1255861) and vegetarianism [falling out of favor](http://www.dw.com/en/vegetarians-developing-a-taste-for-meat/a-16490496).

1229.223.text: Social stigmas change all the time and may very well disappear.

1229.227.text: Most non-meat eaters do not suffer from being stigmatised as most people never know whether they eat meat or not.

1229.281.text: Today, especially young people \([under the age of 55](http://www.vegetariantimes.com/article/vegetarianism-in-america/)\), would not describe non-meat eaters as deviant or odd.

1229.295.text: The emergence of the vegetarian movement and belief was perceived as [threatening](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/christina-pirello/vegan-diet_b_876614.html) to their initial lifestyle by some people. This caused a backlash which led to aversion.

1229.550.text: In parts of countries like China pure meatless diet still carries the [stigma of poverty](https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=Ihqp1zzJ1YsC&pg=PA346&dq=vegetarianism+china+poverty&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwikzMO60fbMAhUH6aYKHZX4Ca4Q6AEIYjAJ#v=onepage&q=vegetarianism%20china%20poverty&f=false).

1229.1145.text: In Japan, vegetarianism [is neither](https://thisjapaneselife.org/2011/09/07/japan-vegetarian-food/) well-understood nor easily practiced socially without a burden.

1229.1762.text: In a study, [six out of ten](https://faunalytics.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/Faunalytics_Current-Former-Vegetarians_Full-Report.pdf) former U.S. vegetarians and vegans stated that their diet made them "stick out from the crowd", and that this was a problem. Four out of ten current vegans and vegetarians state the same.

1229.1325.text: The vast majority of the world's population eats meat. By definition this makes non-meat eaters deviant.

1229.263.text: In [Britain](http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/health/517246/Vegetarians-are-on-the-increase-in-Britain) one in eight adults now follows a vegetarian or vegan diet. While 12% of the total population has decided to ditch meat, that percentage jumps to 20% for people between the ages of 16 and 24.

1229.264.text: In 2014 the Indian city Palitana became the first [all-vegetarian](http://www.mfablog.org/veganism-taking-the-world-by-storm) city in the world, after the Gujarat government imposed a ban on animal slaughter and outlawed the sale of meat and eggs.

1229.362.text: Across the world per capita meat consumption has been [steadily rising](http://www.who.int/nutrition/topics/3_foodconsumption/en/index4.html) and will continue to do so at least until 2030.

1229.543.text: The share of all food and drink product launches with a claim to be vegetarian [has doubled](http://www.mintel.com/press-centre/food-and-drink/number-of-global-vegetarian-food-and-drink-product-launches-doubles-between-2009-and-2013) from 2009 to 2013 in Great Britain \(from 6% to 12%\).

1229.706.text: The demand for meat is rising globally. This clearly indicates its high popularity.

1229.711.text: In the USA meat consumption is actually on the [decline](https://www.fastcoexist.com/3027191/the-us-has-passed-peak-meat-the-rest-of-the-world-is-just-getting-started). It decreased from 184 pounds per person in 2004 to 167 pounds in 2014.

1229.1770.text: The number of vegetarians in Germany [declined](http://de.statista.com/statistik/daten/studie/173636/umfrage/lebenseinstellung---anzahl-vegetarier/) since 2013.

1229.734.text: Vegetarians can without any major problem join dinner invitations, parties and all kinds of social events.

1229.364.text: In countries like South Korea and China restaurants that specialize in barbecue and fried chicken are among the most popular places for social outings but they usually have no vegetarian dishes on offer.

1229.410.text: Non-meat eaters oftentimes require special effort from the hosts of social gatherings. Asking for this effort can make things uncomfortable for them, just as not making this effort can make things uncomfortable for hosts, as Michael Pollan [described](https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=QZ1D4Q8uZuoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Omnivore%27s+Dilemma&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiuwM7P1-7MAhWD3KYKHSSpDsIQ6AEIITAB#v=onepage&q=alienates&f=false).

1229.259.text: It is very common in Chinese, Korean, and Japanese cuisine to have a large variety of side dishes, many of which are vegetarian.

1229.178.text: Japan has a rich tradition of [cooking with vegetables](http://www.japan-talk.com/jt/new/vegetarian-japanese-food). As of today, [meatless dishes](http://en.rocketnews24.com/2015/09/28/10-vegetarian-foods-you-can-order-at-almost-any-japanese-restaurant/) still make up for a big part of Japanese cuisine.

1229.542.text: Traditional restaurants in these countries oftentimes focus on a single, meat-containing dish and offer nothing besides, for example in [Japan](http://www.ibukimagazine.com/focus_on_the_tokyo_food_scene/).

1229.1172.text: There are a lot of vegetarians living in China, Japan and Korea. Thus, it cannot be that difficult.

1229.1239.text: In [Korean schools](http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2015/04/654_176353.html) there are no meatless dishes offered for children.

1229.1240.text: There is a long history of vegetarian food in East Asian countries through the influence of Buddhism, which tends to lack meat.

1229.1246.text: At celebrations for the Chinese [New Year](http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/china/Chinas-vegetarian-population-touches-50-million-Report/articleshow/29725767.cms) and Korean [Chuseok](http://www.foodrepublic.com/2013/09/19/today-is-korean-thanksgiving-heres-what-you-should-eat/) it is traditionally necessary to offer meat dishes as ritual foods.

1229.1381.text: Korean cuisine hosts a variety of non-meat dishes that are widely available, such as Kimchi, Bibimbap, Gimbap, Mandu, Bam, Gamja Jon, Doenjang Jigae, Jap chae, or Jamchi Jigae.

1229.4619.text: It's nearly impossible to live off a vegetarian diet in some areas, like [Tibet](http://liuzhou.co.uk/wordpress/2013/11/27/vegetarian-or-vegan-in-china/).

1229.541.text: Some people hate the lingering odor of onions and especially garlic and would not eat any meals including these ingredients.

1229.575.text: Some people dislike the \(hot\) spices used in Asian cuisine and thus avoid food from e.g. Korea, Thailand, China etc.

1229.576.text: Quite a few people consistently avoid meals including gluten, lactose or sugar for dietary reasons.

1229.835.text: Some people overcome their personal food preferences when custom, politeness or necessity require it.

1229.1329.text: Few other food preferences are as widely exclusive as is a meatless diet. Being on a meatless diet is thus on a different level than merely disliking certain ingredients.

1229.554.text: Vegetarianism is seen as a conscious choice; allergies and intolerances are not.

1229.731.text: You cannot prepare pork or meat that is not halal for your Muslim friends for example.

1229.732.text: You cannot prepare any meat for your Hinduist friends.

1229.733.text: You cannot prepare pork or any meat that is not kosher for your Jewish friends.

1229.823.text: In the past people were presented to gods as [human sacrifices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_sacrifice) or held as [slaves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery). However, these cruel features were eventually abandoned in most cultures.

1229.986.text: According to [cultural relativism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_relativism), judgement of right and wrong are determined by one's own culture and are thus not absolute.

1229.900.text: According to meta-ethical [moral relativism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_relativism) in such disagreements, nobody is objectively right or wrong.

1229.899.text: According to [moral universalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_universalism), a system of ethics applies universally, that is, for all individuals, regardless of culture.

1229.896.text: All humans are a part of a certain culture and society, which fundamentally characterizes their values and attitudes. Thus behavior of a certain culture can only be judged in comparison.

1229.2130.text: Moral relativism is self-defeating in this case. Suppose all cultures should follow their own ethical codes. It then follows that if our culture's code says that eating meat is unethical, then we should condemn everyone who eats meat, no matter what culture they are from.

1229.2131.text: Some cultural practices are obviously wrong. For example, slavery and torture are wrong, even if most people once thought they were right. So there are some universal moral standards that exist independently of cultural opinion.

1229.5109.text: The fundamental moral truth, that pain and suffering in living beings should be minimized as much as possible, has to be the foundation of any discussion and has to supersede cultural values. Otherwise things like slavery and ritual killings would need to be considered morally OK, just because they are part of a certain culture. This would make argument-/logic-based discussions about what is morally right/wrong pointless. Thus, if such a discussion shall take place, culture can't be an argument.

1229.985.text: There are only several occasions per year, such as on [Eid al-Adha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eid_al-Adha), that eating meat is culturally induced.

1229.1182.text: Justification is not a question of amount. If something is wrong, it is wrong regardless of the quantity in which it occurs: murdering one person is wrong, as is murdering five people.

1229.1542.text: 'What is' is a better indicator than philosophical thoughts on 'what ought to be' because it has shown its applicability.

1229.2270.text: Humans ought to do what it is in their nature to do.

1229.3153.text: Additionally, we should seek to get the relationship between what is *normative* and what is *normal* the right way around. The normative should dictate what is normal. Just because an act is normal does not in and of itself signify that the act is therefore good, just, beautiful, or useful.

1229.3315.text: One philosopher should not dictate what the entirety of human existence inherently desires.

1229.3765.text: Slavery, much like eating meat, involves harm to living beings which demonstrate clear preferences towards avoiding it.

1229.5886.text: Eating or abusing someone is harmful to their life experience. If any living beings were created with the intention of being eaten and abused, this would indicate that God did not consider their lives to be precious. There is no purpose to the creation of living beings whose lives are not precious.

1229.3864.text: By many forms of moral reasoning \(e.g. utilitarianism\), God is amoral or even sometimes commits evil acts. As such, the Bible does not provide an unambiguous view of goodness.

1229.5885.text: Meat is, by one definition, the organs or tissues of animals considered to be food. Organs and tissues of living beings were created for the functioning of an individual's living processes, perceptions and actions and not for the nutritional purposes of other animals, including humans.

1229.2903.text: It can be very costly, or economically impossible, for small farmers to change crops quickly without going bankrupt or into debt.

1229.5552.text: If rural poor people took up higher-paying jobs, they could have a higher quality-of-life and not dependent on livestock for subsistence.

1229.6618.text: Demands for meat consumption force us into meeting that demand. If there was a big enough shift away from that need, farmers could pivot and still maintain a livelihood. Example: [Swedish drinks company helps farmer shift away from livestock farming and cut climate impact with his own oat milk brand](https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2017/aug/26/wow-no-cow-swedish-farmer-oats-milk-oatly).

1229.3145.text: Experts in animal farming may have no relevant knowledge to put toward agricultural farming. Rather than creating new livelihood for these farmers, it would force them to rapidly become experts in an entirely new field with no time for transition.

1229.3146.text: The animals currently used to farm meat will not disappear overnight. In order to immediately transition to agricultural farming, all of those animals would need to be slaughtered to make room for the vegetation. Not only would this be cruel to the animals, but it would also destroy the farmers' finances.

1229.1623.text: In advanced economies [agriculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-sector_theory) in general is not very important. Meat production is therefore even more unimportant.

1229.1624.text: In underdeveloped countries meat production is marginal as illustrated by the low rates of meat consumption.

1229.1631.text: For countries like Argentina and Uruguay, [around three quarters](http://www.ers.usda.gov/media/187485/ldpm15901_1_.pdf) of their exports consist of frozen meat.

1229.3912.text: This may be a benefit, as human-raised livestock is often kept in atrocious conditions, and also has negative environmental impacts. Farming also has negative impacts on humans.

1229.702.text: In [China](http://www.takepart.com/article/2015/10/13/china-meat-consumption), with a growing population and a growing middle class, the demand for meat has risen and is expected to continue to rise.

1229.2348.text: The fact that economic development is correlated with increased consumption of meat indicates that many people refrain from consuming meat not because they don't want to but because of an inability to afford it.

1229.3790.text: This claim implies poor health is desirable as it results in increased demand for healthcare. Few would agree.

1229.3518.text: This is caused by the quality of the meat. Imagine the meat production where the animal food is contaminated with poisons from the fertilizers and other farming products. These bad substances get into the animal meat in the fat and from there to our human bodies. The distinction between bad meat \(mass farming\) and good meat \(grass fed free-range\) must be made in order to draw health consequence conclusions. [PubMed: GBHs in food.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4756530/)

1229.3625.text: Economies are not static, they can adapt and change. Where sales drop in meat products, they will likely rise in meat alternatives. Disruption could lead to more innovation and growth than traditional industries.

1229.6352.text: Conflating the biological concept of harm \(meaning pain, distress, or the loss of quality of life\) with economics, is a major moral error that nullifies any argument with regards to "economic harm".

1229.6354.text: "Economics" is simply the study of prices that arise from supply & demand. But morality in society determines what is allowed to be supplied or demanded. It is a major category error or a criminal fraud to pretend that because there is demand there must be supply, or vice versa. We don't think that way about offering children for sex abuse, for instance, or about nuclear fissile materials for bombs.

1229.3949.text: Human history includes the development of morality. Immoral things, or things now considered to be immoral, were once widely accepted in the past \(e.g. slavery\). This does not "negate history". Therefore, it is plausible that eating meat will come to be considered immoral \(by more people, and perhaps society in general\) in the future.

1229.3954.text: Depending on the moral system used, morality can depend on the situation. Even if eating meat was morally acceptable at some points in human history, it does not necessarily follow that it is morally acceptable to continue eating it today. We are less dependant on meat than we once were, and more able to reasonably replace it.

1229.3685.text: Whether introducing an industry which is immoral might be good for the economy does not detract from the contention that stopping an established industry would be bad for the economy.

1229.6108.text: The economic impacts of stopping the consumption of meat has a moral implication under utilitarian ethics in so far as negative economic conditions have the potential to cause harm.

1229.6756.text: Spending more while lowering taxes means more debt for the next generation.

1229.2520.text: Keeping livestock helps [reduce seasonal variability](http://www.fao.org/docrep/v8180t/v8180t07.htm) in food supply due to seasonal variations in crop productivity.

1229.2521.text: Animals act as both a secure form of wealth, and as an emergency supply of food in case of shocks to the normal food supply \(like droughts or famines\).

1229.6308.text: The economic benefits are far outweighed by the risk to [long-term health](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/milk/) and cost of potential medical expenses if the use of animals is relied on.

1229.3051.text: Any significant changes in worldwide meat consumption would likely, in practice, be gradual, and allow farmers plenty of time to adjust.

1229.3100.text: Geographical types are different. Some places, such as mountains, are much better to keep livestock in than to grow crops.

1229.3683.text: Adequate food is produced already and output could be increased if required. Low income countries however will have no access to it because the global economy demands payment for goods and price stability for its products so production will be controlled.

1229.5659.text: If roughly 1B of the 1.3B people producing meat are poor we can assume they would benefit from undertaking more profitable enterprises if there were not the demand.  An economy that permits such poverty for our convenience would suggest, therefore, that eating meat is wrong.

1229.6036.text: If we would base our decisions on preserving jobs, hardly any progress could be made since any change makes a certain number of jobs obsolete.

1229.56.text: Much of the world's massive hunger problems could be solved by the reduction / elimination of meat-eating, as livestock pasture needs cut drastically into land which could otherwise be used to grow food.

1229.148.text: The vast quantities of food which could feed humans is instead fed to livestock animals.

1229.159.text: In developing countries, intensive livestock farming [obstructs](http://thegreentimes.co.za/negative-impacts-of-factory-farming/) poverty elimination by driving local farmers out of business.

1229.445.text: Meat factories create a very high demand for soybeans and corn which change the production patterns of the global south.

1229.1427.text: In [South Africa](http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10806-015-9581-8) there are clear effects of meat consumption where local communities' major source of income is replaced by factory farming they cannot compete with.

1229.1883.text: Not all meat eaters consume meat from factory farming.

1229.3787.text: This may not be able to provide for unexpected rises in demand.

1229.6646.text: There are plenty of plant based or synthetic alternatives to animal materials.

1229.6647.text: "Imagining the impact" of these changes is speculatory at best, and does not speak on the core ethics of killing animals for food or materials.

1229.4074.text: Industries are constantly growing and dying - they evolve with consumer demand. Though there may be additional capital involved in switching from farming animals to farming plant-based products, farmers would make the change to ensure that their crop business remain lucrative. No-one uses floppy disks or rides to work on a horse anymore. Similar principles apply here.

1229.1476.text: Agricultural production as of today is already sufficient to cover the demand for the world. Thus, no substitute is needed and no new jobs created.

1229.2139.text: It is extremely difficult to transition from farming meat to farming normal agricultural products, and the transitionary period would cause drastic economic harms.

1229.2590.text: Other food production sectors would grow, meaning companies would require additional human capital to meet the new demand. As such, any jobs lost in the meat industry would simply appear in other food sectors.

1229.5458.text: The niacin in animal protein decreases VLDL and LDL, the mostly-fat bad cholesterol that clog arteries, and increases HDL, the mostly-protein good cholesterol that removes arterial plaque.

1229.89.text: According to the [American Dietetic Association](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/american_dietetic_association_vegetarian_position.pdf) a vegetarian diet can meet protein requirements, provide all the essential amino-acids, necessary vitamins, fats and minerals.

1229.3116.text: Well planned diets are good for people who have time, and money for them, but many people just don't have that amount of time to invest, or the funds to accommodate them, so for them, a simple diet involving meat is a necessity.

1229.4146.text: Well planned diets are not always effective. Vegetarian sources of protein are not always effectively processed, leaving some people malnourished. Even when the meal contains adequate supplies of protein it won't always be absorbed.

1229.5292.text: This study confounds three or four causes and conflates them with a more plant-based diet when their effects are not correlated with a more plant-based diet.

1229.5294.text: The studies that claim animal over plant diets use more resources such as fuel, irrigation, land, and fertilizer discount the fuel spent to transport crops from the climates suited to them like volcanic, tropical, and marine environments \(e.g. 9000 miles for coconuts between Oceania and America\) and the greater land and fertilizer use for human crops on soils that don't natively support staples.

1229.5295.text: India has a wide adoption of vegetarianism but its lifespan lags France, whose diet is rich in saturated fat and livestock, by 20 years.  The leading cause of death in India is heart disease.

1229.5462.text: The flesh substitutes are crumbly instead of stringy and are made from beans whose estrogens are bad for males, from monoculture sources of saturated fat like coconuts, and from starch fillers.

1229.2755.text: The human metabolism is much [different](http://baloun.entu.cas.cz/~cizek/EkologieLesaPrednaska/InsectPlantInteractions/Allometry%20and%20Ecology%20of%20FeedingBehavAndDigestiveCapacity.pdf) from that of elephants, gorillas, and cattle. These animals spend a majority of their time eating and their stomachs are designed to process hard to digest plant matter. Humans are not designed to eat purely plants in the same way and therefore cannot subsist on the same diet and expect the same results.

1229.3057.text: As the human metabolism is mainly designed to digest nuts and fruits, humans do not have any problem living on a vegetarian diet.

1229.4284.text: Fishes eat plankton, some mammals eat only meat , some only vegetables. Comparing humans to other species that are not similar in their metabolism and dietary need is a fallacy at best and illogical in nature.

1229.5297.text: There are many nutrients "vegans" don't get: retinol, carnitine, saturated fat, cobalamin, cholecalciferol, copper and zinc, menaquinone-4, sphingomyelin, sphingosine, and carnosine.

1229.5290.text: It's much easier to ruin your health on a vegetarian diet than omnivorose diet.

1229.3289.text: Unfortunately plant diets are high in undigestable's like insoluble fibre, and certain sugars. The fodmaps and other diets map numerous forms of plant foods that even doctors recommend people with digestive problems experiment with removing, because of these. The foods mentioned above; mushrooms, lentils, rice, bean sprouts etc, are all mentioned in these types of diets as potential food allergens/carbs. It's the carbohydrates like fructose & allergens like gluten that are problematic.

1229.3081.text: After millenia of human being's bodies becoming accustomed to eating meat, it seems reckless to suggest that it could be healthy for everyone to all of a sudden stop eating meat.

1229.6052.text: There is no scientific evidence to back up this statement.

1229.6829.text: According to those sources cited, vegetables are positive for digestion when prepared correctly, i.e. cooked, fermented, or soaked. Raw vegetables are easily avoided regardless of the meat status of the diet.

1229.4985.text: These are facts coming from in vitro studies without any ecological reliability and with concentrations way higher than the ones we assume.

1229.1800.text: Health considerations are generally not the main factor when deciding what to eat or not. Otherwise we would drink [cockroach milk](http://www.sciencealert.com/scientists-show-why-we-should-all-start-drinking-cockroach-milk) and stop eating french fries.

1229.415.text: Most meat-eaters consume meat not to maintain a healthy diet, but because it increases their subjective quality of life.

1229.3438.text: Unhealthy choices lead to poor health outcomes which will then need to be managed by the healthcare system, placing a burden on society in general.

1229.3629.text: It is also likely down to convenience and societal norms. Award winning vegan foods have beaten meat products on taste, such as the [Impossible Burger](https://www.impossiblefoods.com/burger/), meaning that this level of pleasure is not exclusive to real meat.

1229.3630.text: Recreational substances are also banned; there is precedent for restricting pleasurable, yet health-damaging goods.

1229.4543.text: Humans drink alcohol for its toxic effect. Therefore, health is not the based upon a single food item, but as a whole as the entire diet should be considered when talking about health.

1229.421.text: The finding that red meat increases the risk of colon cancer was confirmed in an [observatory study](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8162586) of US citizens in which red meat featured as prominent factor.

1229.422.text: Studies on the effects of red meat intake do not account for the differences in processed and un-processed meat, which is unacceptable because the two have vastly different effects.

1229.423.text: A [meta-analysis](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663065) of red meat-cancer studies found that the link is, at best, weak.

1229.425.text: When meat is cooked excessively, [carcinogens](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15199546) can be produced that are linked to cancer.

1229.2469.text: There is no direct reference to the study here. Severe confounding or methodological challenges is possible.

1229.5300.text: The carcinogens in processed meats come from heat and vegetal and mineral nitrites, not flesh.  The same carcinogens are present in potato chips, heated oils, prunes, and carrots.

1229.685.text: Dirty, crowded conditions on factory farms can propagate sickness and disease among the animals. These diseases also lead to human infections.

1229.155.text: Currently [organic farming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organic_farming_by_country) accounts for only a [small percentage](http://orgprints.org/29790/13/willer-lernoud-2016-global-data-biofach.pdf) of livestock farming and it is unrealistic to think we can provide for current levels of meat consumption via fair organic livestock farming. Thus, a massive reduction of meat consumption would be required nonetheless.

1229.10601.text: Organic farmers do not use [antibiotics](https://goorganicuk.com/blog/articles/organic-farming-antibiotics). This reduces the risk of [antibiotic-resistant bacteria](https://theconversation.com/organic-grass-fed-and-hormone-free-does-this-make-red-meat-any-healthier-92119)(Organic agriculture doesn’t use antibiotics to promote livestock growth. This is considered an important strategy in addressing the transmission of antibiotic-resistant bacteria to the environment and the food supply chain.) entering the food chain.

1229.681.text: 75% of the antibiotics used on livestock are not absorbed by the animals and are instead excreted in their faeces, posing a [serious risk](http://www.worldwatch.org/global-meat-production-and-consumption-continue-rise-1) to public health.

1229.5596.text: [Studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4638249/)(Antibiotics are administered to animals in feed to marginally improve growth rates and to prevent infections, a practice projected to increase dramatically worldwide over the next 15 years. There is growing evidence that antibiotic resistance in humans is promoted by the widespread use of nontherapeutic antibiotics in animals. Resistant bacteria are transmitted to humans through direct contact with animals, by exposure to animal manure, through consumption of undercooked meat, and through contact with uncooked meat or surfaces meat has touched.) suggest that antibiotic resistance in humans may be encouraged by the widespread use of nontherapeutic antibiotics in animals.

1229.289.text: Vitamin B-12 is [also found](http://www.nhs.uk/Livewell/Vegetarianhealth/Pages/Vegetarianmealguide.aspx) in eggs, dairy, fortified cereals and soya products, and yeast extract.

1229.417.text: There are only rare cases of vitamin B12 deficiencies and mostly this is [no problem](https://www.drmcdougall.com/misc/2007nl/nov/b12.htm) or easy to fix.

1229.2233.text: Even if B-12 cannot be sourced directly from one's diet, supplements are widely available in many health-food stores and chemists.

1229.2715.text: Meat is the most accessible source of those vitamins, particularly in poor countries. Growing chickens is the [easiest way to get more rich in vitamins food](https://www.gatesnotes.com/Development/Why-I-Would-Raise-Chickens).

1229.3695.text: Supplements are less accessible than meat to most people.

1229.1038.text: Too little iron causes [iron](http://www.webmd.com/diet/iron-rich-foods)-deficiency anemia, a decline of red blood cells. Without sufficient iron, the human body is not able to produce enough hemoglobin, the important oxygen carrier. Symptoms are weakness, fatigue and irritation.

1229.111.text: The body absorbs 15% to 35% of the heme iron in meat, but only absorbs 2% to 20% of the non-heme iron found in vegetarian sources like leafy greens and beans. \([vegetarian.procon.org](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/nih_dietary_supplement_fact_sheet_on_iron.pdf)\)

1229.2112.text: Iron is an oxidant and can harm the DNA of our cells. Non-heme \(vegetable\) iron is safer for us, since the body can absorb only what it needs, unlike heme iron. [nutritionfacts.org](https://nutritionfacts.org/video/the-safety-of-heme-vs-non-heme-iron/)

1229.2225.text: [Iron deficiency is the most common and widespread nutritional disorder in the world.](http://www.who.int/nutrition/topics/ida/en/)

1229.286.text: All the high-quality amino acid [proteins](http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2016/05/19/478645426/humans-are-meathooked-but-not-designed-for-meat-eating) we require are readily available in plants such as buckwheat, quinoa and potatoes.

1229.664.text: There are enough [non-animal protein](http://www.health.com/health/gallery/0,,20718479,00.html) sources humans can consume.

1229.2579.text: Just because the human body can live without eating meat doesn't rationalize living without it, nor does it justify that something is unhealthy.

1229.3611.text: Eating meat or being able to live optimally without it or on alternative diets has been shown to be coded at a genetic level and this varies from one human to another. It is not always a simple moral or lifestyle choice.

1229.2578.text: The top four foods referenced in the article are all meat. Non-fat cheese is not commonly consumed.

1229.10784.text: No one is realistically going to replace all their sources of meat for cheese.

1229.10786.text: This effectively excludes people who can’t eat cheese \(i.e lactose intolerant, allergies, etc.\).

1229.2147.text: Animal protein has a low pH and causes problems in our kidneys.[nutritionfacts.org](https://nutritionfacts.org/video/which-type-of-protein-is-better-for-our-kidneys/)

1229.2149.text: Animal protein stimulates hormones such as IGF-1, which can be used by cancer to fuel growth.[nutritionfacts.org](https://nutritionfacts.org/video/animal-protein-compared-cigarette-smoking/)

1229.6983.text: Food conversion makes loss of valuable protein. Every animal used for meat needs a larger amount of \(plant based\) protein in their food than the amount of protein it produces. To grow 1 \(eatable\) kg in meat cow must eat somewhere between [25kgs](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S014102290100504X) and [35kgs](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0924224418308409) plant based feed. Although not all of that food is usable for human consumption a lot of it is. This is a terrible loss of valuable nutrients.

1229.6396.text: There is next to [no scientific evidence](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nhzV-J1h0do#action=share) that a high-fat diet leads to a high cholesterol level; in fact, a high-fat diet turns out to be healthy in many ways.

1229.6397.text: [A high cholesterol level](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nhzV-J1h0do#action=share) has not been finally determined to be the cause of coronary heart diseases; there has merely been found a correlation. Latest research counters the assumption that a high cholesterol level is concerning.

1229.99.text: Meat has high renal acid levels which the body must neutralize by [leaching calcium](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/pcrm_protecting_your_bones.pdf) from the bones, which is then passed into urine and lost.

1229.100.text: There are many sources of healthy [vegetarian calcium](http://drlisawatson.com/40-vegan-calcium-sources) including tofu, dark leafy greens like kale, spinach, and collard greens, as well as fortified cereals.

1229.1847.text: A meatless diet does not guarantee a higher absorbtion of calcium, because vegetarians can also eat unhealthy food and maintain an unbalanced diet.

1229.6672.text:
It is highly debatable what fats are good and which are bad. We have been living under a lot of assumptions about fat. Polyunsaturated oils are chemically less stable than saturated fats. [What if its all been a big fat lie.](https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/07/magazine/what-if-it-s-all-been-a-big-fat-lie.html)
[Saturated fat is safe… this is the science that says so](http://anograiner.com/fat-chemistry/)

1229.1744.text: Non-meat eaters have enough [protein sources](http://www.bbcgoodfood.com/howto/guide/best-sources-protein) they can choose from, such as eggs, soya, beans and nuts.

1229.3186.text: Many of the minerals/vitamins found in meat are not in easily digestible forms from other sources.

1229.3433.text: If society as a whole transitions away from eating meat, there will be more support structures and systems in place to make alternative sources of nutrition more viable.

1229.3796.text: Most staple vegetarian foods, like beans and rice, are very cheap. Meat is expensive. Vitamin b12, the main problem for vegetarian diets can be supplemented cheaply.

1229.4356.text: Many scientists point to the time at which humans began to eat meat as a major event in humanity's evolution. It contributed to a drastic increase in our intelligence, according to Leslie Aiello, an anthropologist and director of the Wenner-Gren Foundation in [this NPR article](https://www.npr.org/2010/08/02/128849908/food-for-thought-meat-based-diet-made-us-smarter).

1229.4878.text: Other claims elsewhere already dispute the suggestion that meats are faster and more efficient to cook and eat in modern society.

1229.3379.text: If plant-based protein sources become more widely accepted and produced, they will be cheaper and easier to obtain.

1229.3412.text: Animal proteins are complete proteins and thus a more efficient source of amino acids.

1229.3628.text: [Many world class athletes follow a vegan diet](https://www.vegansociety.com/whats-new/blog/ten-best-plant-powered-athletes), proving that meat is not essential for developing and maintaining muscles.

1229.3627.text: Meat is not 'essential'. All nutrients found in meat can be found in plants, bacteria or can be made within the human body.

1229.3373.text: Nutrient supplements are available in today's society, and are widely used to supplement a vegetarian or vegan diet.

1229.3651.text: The typical diets of meat eaters have a lot of [evidence showing them to be harmful](http://www.whatthehealthfilm.com/facts/) and have a particularly strong association to diseases of affluence. For example, heart disease, which is caused by atherosclerosis, the build up of plaque in the arteries. [Erectile dysfunction is an early warning sign of atherosclerosis \(by the age of 40, there is a 40% chance of ED which then goes up 10% a year\).](https://youtu.be/OVXzT_RBxFk)

1229.1797.text: The study had very [bad reviews](http://www.nhs.uk/news/2014/04April/Pages/Vegetarians-have-poorer-quality-of-life-study-claims.aspx) on health platforms.

1229.6453.text: There are [other more thorough studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4073139/) that conclude the opposite.

1229.1177.text: Between 1998 and 2008, 46% of all cases of food [poisoning](http://edition.cnn.com/2013/02/01/health/vegetables-foodborne-illness-time/) in the USA were caused by leafy green vegetables.

1229.1179.text: Leafy green vegetables cause 80% of all [E.coli](http://www.medicaldaily.com/salmonella-food-poisoning-most-common-vegetables-not-meat-325070) cases in the USA.

1229.1183.text: According to the same study, poultry was responsible for the most deaths, affecting 19% of fatal cases. Meat and poultry combined were responsible for 29% of deaths. So, despite the frequency of vegetable-related illnesses, they were not the most harmful.

1229.1184.text: Officials from the CDC have emphasized that most of the vegetable-related sicknesses came from norovirus, often passed by food handlers and cooks. Thus, contamination is more related to how the kitchen or restaurant handles the food, rather than the actual food itself.

1229.431.text: It is mainly the consumption of [fresh food](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8842068) that has a positive effect, rather than whether they eat meat.

1229.101.text: According to a peer-reviewed study of 76,000 people, vegetarians had 24% [lower mortality](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10479225) from heart disease than meat eaters.

1229.104.text: A 2006 [meta-study](http://www.susanberkow.com/PDF/vegdietsandweightstatus3.pdf) that compiled data from 87 studies found that vegetarian diets are associated with reduced body weight.

1229.5148.text: High consumption of red meats has been shown to be associated with greater risk of morbidity and mortality from cardiovascular disease [sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780123739605005414).

1229.2679.text: Refined carbs/sugars are definitely not a suitable replacement for meat/dairy.  There is very little to be gained from substituting one unhealthy thing for another.

1229.2725.text: The statement that some of a group of people who are healthier because of not eating meat sometimes choose to eat unhealthy foods does not in any way make abstaining from meat a problem. Eating refined carbs or processed food is bad in and of itself regardless of vegan or not. This argument is comparable to saying that since some people who quit smoking chew more gum, then quitting smoking is bad for your teeth. In short, this is a non sequitur.

1229.5145.text: A [study](http://www.cell.com/cell-metabolism/abstract/S1550-4131\(14\)00062-X) out from University of Southern California found that eating a diet rich in animal proteins \(red meat, chicken, dairy\)  during middle age makes you four times more likely to die of cancer than someone on a low animal-protein diet — a mortality risk factor comparable to smoking.

1229.5149.text: Meat contains Carcinogenic compounds, leading to stomach cancer, breast cancer, Kidney, Colorectal, Prostate Cancer and pancreatic cancer. [See sources here](http://www.pcrm.org/health/cancer-resources/diet-cancer/facts/meat-consumption-and-cancer-risk)

1229.5147.text: A [recent analysis](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/1832195?resultClick=3) of seven studies by PCRM demonstrates that a vegetarian diet reduces the risk of hypertension.

1229.5146.text: Dr. Barnard \(president of the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine \(PCRM\)\) discovered that eating meat is consistently associated with an elevated diabetes risk, regardless of age. [Reference](http://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/6/2/897)

1229.4945.text: With an increase in vegetarians and vegans, there would be more allowances made and techniques developed to assist in maintaining these diets, making it easier and healthier to maintain them.
