1229.5132.text: Certain professions \(i.e. wildland firefighting\) require high body mass and muscular strength which can be logistically difficult, biologically disruptive, and expensive for some individuals to maintain on a vegetarian/vegan diet.

1229.5252.text: Sports and high-performance diets count on high intakes of meat to build muscle and make elite performances possible. Vegetarian supplements such as soy [can have some negative health effects](https://www.nutrition.org.uk/healthyliving/an-active-lifestyle/eating-for-sport-and-exercise.html?limit=1&start=2).

1229.5270.text: An omnivorous diet consisting of mostly vegetables supplemented by a small to moderate amount of meat is not much different to a full vegetarian or vegan diet, yet is more balanced and convenient because you are not going out of your way to avoid something completely.

1229.4838.text: There is no guarantee that all vegetarians are necessarily people who are unusually interested in their health to begin with. People may choose a vegetarian lifestyle out of moral concerns, or many other reasons.

1229.3676.text: The Innuit people consume a diet suited to the natural adaptations made over generations to their digestive tracts. Diets of the Western and developed world can potentially be less healthy as they introduce access to a variety of foodstuffs to which individuals' digestive tracts are unlikely to be accustomed.

1229.6456.text: Comparing the lifestyle and diet of the Inuit people to that of most meat consumers is a false equivalency. The source of their meat is vastly different from industrially produced meat found in grocery stores, and their daily lives are vastly different from the average meat consumer. Even when adjusted by age, race, smoking, exercise, personal income, educational level, marital status, alcohol, and region, [studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4073139/) have shown that plant based diets lead to reduced health risks.

1229.3675.text: There is no baseline for 'normal human populations' . Every established ethnic and regional group has adapted their diet to their environment and available resources. Changes to these diets result in negative health effects and so whilst eating meat does not confer any advantage, ceasing its consumption will inflict a negative effect on their health.

1229.4907.text: For the group tests to be valid, they should also be checked for malnutrition in general, and also be tested with vegan equivalent supplements that offer a similar dose of iron, protein and other nutrients that those groups' existing diets are lacking.

1229.5497.text: There is no need to predict the characteristics of the whole population. As long as identifiable groups can be shown to benefit from meat consumption, that is sufficient to prove that not everyone should stop eating meat.

1229.6455.text: This appeals to tradition. None of the nutrients listed are exclusive to meat. The rest of your argument is based on conjecture. [Studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4073139/) have shown the reduced risk of diseases from plant based diets, even when adjusted by age \(i.e., attained age as time variable\), race, smoking, exercise, personal income, educational level, marital status, alcohol, and region.

1229.5053.text: The consumers create the market. Without supply there would be no demand, and the change would naturally be gradual, letting the animal product market gently fade, transition, and evolve to meet the new needs of this earth.

1229.6629.text: The Vitamin K2 \(more absorbable form\) amounts are the highest \(lb for lb\) in the vegan food natto \([over 1mg while the meat runner up is under 0.4mg](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/vitamin-k1-vs-k2)\).

1229.108.text: [Human Rights Watch](https://www.hrw.org/news/2005/01/24/abuses-against-workers-taint-us-meat-and-poultry) has called meatpacking "the most dangerous factory job in America".

1229.109.text: The meatpacking industry can be dangerous, but the solution for improving the safety of slaughterhouse workers is the strengthening of workplace safety rules, and increasing the monitoring of factories for safety violations.

1229.1560.text: Safety in the US meat industry has increased drastically since the early [1990s](https://www.meatinstitute.org/index.php?ht=a/GetDocumentAction/i/46343).

1229.1561.text: The source cited refers to poultry but in other branches of the meat industry safety standards are very high and injuries in the US decreased from [20% to 6%](https://www.meatinstitute.org/index.php?ht=a/GetDocumentAction/i/83419/) in 2012.

1229.1690.text: Health problems for workers is [negative](http://file:///C:/Users/Gregor/Downloads/ijerph-13-00197%20\(2\).pdf) for the national economy at large and only profitable to the individual firm.

1229.2048.text: Meatpacking companies often [stop workers from getting compensation](https://www.hrw.org/news/2005/01/24/abuses-against-workers-taint-us-meat-and-poultry) for workplace injuries by denying or delaying complaints and not filing reports about injuries.

1229.5551.text: The low wages and benefits on meatpacking workers makes the injuries hard to treat.

1229.846.text: The workers are forced to wear [diapers](https://upvoted.com/2016/05/27/we-wear-diapers-activists-behind-the-givethemabreak-campaign-reveal-the-horrific-conditions-of-poultry-workers/) or to smudge themselves.

1229.6474.text: This is an argument for another topic, namely, workers rights.

1229.1497.text: Fruit and vegetable picking is an extremely [low paid](https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/aug/08/pick-fruit-veg-low-pay-brexit-vote-food-industry) and very hard job.

1229.1678.text: Slaughterhouse workers have to kill living creatures on a daily basis, which has been proven to cause [severe psychological and physiological stress or PTSD](http://scholar.colorado.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2157&context=honr_theses) \(pp. 20-25\), no matter whether the worker started the job knowing what it entailed.

1229.2280.text: There is nothing that can be done to prevent the need for carrying out certain psychologically and physically harmful tasks inherent to the meat industry: the killing of the animal by a human hand, for example, is inevitable, whatever workplace regulations are put in place.

1229.2457.text: Even if temporary boycotts are necessary to spur this sort of change, that does not imply that humans should permanently stop eating meat.

1229.3144.text: It must also be considered that cause and effect could be reversed here. There could be many people with violent tendencies or desires who work in slaughterhouses in an attempt to give that violence a safer outlet.

1229.3181.text: Facilities regarded as undesirable to live near - such as abattoirs, power stations or prisons - are often built in locations that are already run-down and have a higher level of crime, thus these studies could say little about the true effect of slaughterhouses on local violent crime.

1229.6568.text: This claim depends on an assumption that eating meat of any kind only supports large-scale meat production. There are many sources of meat that do not fit that description, and among those sources, harm to workers compares very well with peer operations in sustainable agriculture.

1229.41.text: Farm [animals feel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_consciousness) pleasure and sadness, excitement and resentment, depression, fear and pain. They are [sentient](http://www.livescience.com/39481-time-to-declare-animal-sentience.html) and intelligent beings, thus utilitarianism can be applied to them. \([psychologytoday.com](https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animal-emotions/201306/universal-declaration-animal-sentience-no-pretending)\)

1229.52.text: Humans are capable of culture, innovation, and the sublimation of instinct in order to act in an ethical manner. Animals are not, thus they are unequal to humans on a moral level.

1229.146.text: Billions of animals are brutalized and tortured on factory farms every year. Since the only pleasure humans get from eating meat is gustatory pleasure, it is doubtful that the pain and suffering that these animals experience can ever be justified according to utilitarian principles.

1229.147.text: Act utilitarian [Peter Singer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_Liberation_%28book%29) argues that the Basic Principle of Equality should be extended to nonhuman animals and that it would demand us to equally consider the interests of animals.

1229.690.text: The argument has been made that plants are [equally sentient and intelligent](http://www.theguardian.com/environment/radical-conservation/2015/aug/04/plants-intelligent-sentient-book-brilliant-green-internet), even though not in the same sense as humans and animals are. By the same logic, utilitarian ethics would forbid the killing of plants.

1229.1408.text: The pleasure of a human is worth more than the life of an animal because it is scarcer. Thus, utilitarian ethics suggest that humans should keep eating meat.

1229.2614.text: Utilitarian ethics is not only a disputed way of thinking, but is very difficult to implement \(for instance, what is the appropriate time span of pain/pleasure that we are computing?\), especially in nature, which does not care about utilitarianism.

1229.2876.text: We are beginning to find evidence that [plants feel as well.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CrrSAc-vjG4) If plants and animals both feel, we cannot afford to treat them both with utilitarian ethics, we have to eat something! Animals are not more deserving of care than plants. No matter what we do, we'll be making an ethical compromise and killing a living, feeling being.

1229.4018.text: Many animals are incapable of feeling pain. Depending on the definition of sentient this may not be able to be applied to meat from any source in general.

1229.5100.text: A pleasure maximizing ethical paradigm might just as easily justify breeding livestock for food, raising them in a way that maximizes their happiness, and killing them in the most humane manner possible. By bringing a life into this world you are increasing total happiness and satisfying the tastes/preferences of humans who desire meat as food.

1229.90.text: Killing animals to satisfy an unnecessary dietary preference creates disproportionate and unnecessary suffering.

1229.689.text: It is natural to eat whatever is convenient, even if it is not strictly necessary for survival. Bears, for example, are omnivores yet eat meat whenever [the opportunity arises](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bear#Behaviour).

1229.1348.text: Plants are living as well and yet nobody seems to have a problem with harvesting them for consumption.

1229.2709.text: It is not the decision of one person what another puts into their bodies.

1229.4057.text: This argument is based off an internally judged moral system. None of the claims have hard fact behind them. Confidence brings verisimilitude but has no effect on actual truth. Proper justification is based on reality not personal preference.

1229.4749.text: Such an act is justifiable from a hedonistic standpoint.

1229.6466.text: This has less to do with right and wrong, and more to do with justice. Is it just for humans to consume the flesh of other species when it is on longer necessary? There have been times in our history when it was necessary, but this is no longer the case, so a more relevant question would be 'should it be considered torture and murder to kill sentient beings when it is not a necessity?' If not, why? Why is it ok to kill animals who think and feel, when it is not necessary?

1229.832.text: The differentiation is not arbitrary but based on a history of social and emotional relationships which humans have with animals they generally do not eat, such as dogs and horses, but not with those they generally eat, such as cows and pigs.

1229.2061.text: We place [undue importance on animals who are viewed as pets.](https://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/03/15/some-animals-are-more-equal-than-others/?_r=0) If a pig was kept as a pet, one could be reported for animal cruelty for purposefully hurting it. However, pigs who are kept on farms for the purpose of providing meat are able to be treated very cruelly, showing the arbitrariness.

1229.2062.text: There is significant evidence that[pigs are as smart and sociable as dogs](http://www.stuff.co.nz/science/8980423/Pigs-have-the-smarts-over-dogs), but because people enjoy eating their meat we choose to treat them as farm animals instead of potential pets.

1229.3161.text: Giving different considerations to animals such as is it socially acceptable to eat it or not does not mean animals do or should have a right to life, natural or legal.

1229.3677.text: The line that seems to be drawn is not by everyone, people have been eating meat ever since the very beginning and from all livestock possible. This idea for some is hard to access but yes people do also eat animals you keep as pets.

1229.6890.text: If you respect your dog and understand their innate understanding/ caring, bonds, etc, surely you can understand all animals have these qualities.

1229.1406.text: Because biodiversity is greatest with immediate levels of stress some environmental interference is desired. The overpopulation of rabbits on [Norderney](http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11852-009-0056-9#/page-1), for example, has positive effects.

1229.1533.text: Animals disturbing natural balance are generally the result of human actions \(e.g. resettlement\). It is not right to deny these animals their right to life, if it was indeed human actions that led to the disturbance of natural balance.

1229.1565.text: All and only human beings have the [capacity to reason](http://www.animal-rights-library.com/texts-m/regan01.htm). This is a definite feature of moral judgement. As animals lack this ability they are not morally equivalent.

1229.1566.text: All and only human beings have the capacity to make [free choices](http://www.animal-rights-library.com/texts-m/regan01.htm).

1229.1567.text: All and only human beings have a concept of "[self](http://www.animal-rights-library.com/texts-m/regan01.htm)". This makes humans [morally](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2669234?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents) superior to animals.

1229.1530.text: Animals are unable to enter into a social contract, and thus cannot be possessors of rights.

1229.195.text: Plenty of researchers would disagree and argue that moral and ethical behavior can be observed in animals, for example [Frans de Waal](http://books.wwnorton.com/books/the-bonobo-and-the-atheist/) as well as [Marc Bekoff and Jessice Pierce](http://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/W/bo6407651.html).

1229.1603.text: While the life of every human being has [intrinsic worth](http://www.animal-rights-library.com/texts-m/regan01.pdf), the life of every animal has not.

1229.1606.text: All and only human beings have various [positive interests](http://www.animal-rights-library.com/texts-m/regan01.pdf), such as desires, goals, hopes and preferences. This makes them morally superior to animals.

1229.3317.text: Animals are a naturally occurring lifeform just as much as humans are.

1229.1579.text: That human rights outweigh animal rights is apparent in many legal circumstances.

1229.1585.text: Humans are [responsible](http://www.freewayinsurance.com/blog/auto-insurance/if-you-crash-into-a-cow-whos-liable-for-all-the-damage/) for damage caused by or danger done to 'their' animals, like cattle. This legal obligation results out of humans' property rights over these animals.

1229.1586.text: Nonhuman animals are the personal property of their owners, even if recognized as a special kind of property. As such, they cannot themselves possess legal rights, because they are the objects of the [exercise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animals,_Property,_and_the_Law) of someone else's rights.

1229.1588.text: Animals are legally [classified](https://www.animallaw.info/article/animals-property) as 'goods' rather than having 'personality'.

1229.1600.text: The right to property is not a natural right but a socially-enforced construct.

1229.2763.text: The property rights of slaveowners to their slaves should not interfere with the rights of the slaves. Similarly, the property rights of owners of animals should not interfere with the rights of the animals.

1229.1910.text: There is [no logical connection](https://jakubmarian.com/but-humans-are-at-the-top-of-the-food-chain-argument-against-vegetarianism/) between our current position in the food chain and the justifiability of eating animals. Such a reasoning is circular because what puts animals on a lower level than us is eating them.

1229.1911.text: [Humans are not at the top of the food chain](http://www.pnas.org/content/110/51/20617). On a scale of 1 to 5 \(trophic level\), with 1 being the score of a primary producer \(a plant\) and 5 being a pure apex predator \(predators who don’t have any predators themselves\), ecologists found that, based on their diet, humans score a 2.21.

1229.1921.text: What puts animals on a lower level in the food chain \(and what maintains humans at the top\) are the cognitive, motor and social capabilities of the human species.

1229.3368.text: [Saying something is natural proves nothing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appeal_to_nature) unless it is elaborated on why continuing to follow the "natural order of things" is a good thing.

1229.2202.text: All animals display the instinct to self-preservation, that is, the instinct to avoid pain or damage to their bodies.

1229.2909.text: We are not sure of this "limited sentience" and, in fact, the further into animal intelligence we dive, the more evidence we find that intelligence and self-awareness are far more widespread than we once thought. Some of the animals we consume as food are, in fact, quite intelligent - capable of problem solving, complex social relationships, even communicating in ways that border on language.

1229.2852.text: Fairness, being a construct of the human mind, is the concept which allows the intuition of rights. Animals cannot have rights, if their behavior does not acknowledge this assumed virtue, but rather could only be benefactors of human charity. Human charity would bestow, upon animals, privileges as opposed to rights.

1229.3167.text: Even if society did not exist and humans lived in a state of anarchy, it would still be immoral to murder or torture people. This indicates that rights exist independently of social construction.

1229.3647.text: This claim makes multiple statements. "Rights do not exist in the natural world" is true. However, "animals do not have rights at all" is false. They have rights when we grant rights to them.

1229.3332.text: This argument suggests that humans only have a right to life because a human society claims such. In other words, the right to life — for anything, is not an intrinsic value. Therefore, outside the confines of a society which grants \(which allows\) the right to life, humans do not have a right to life.

1229.3333.text: Stating that one's capacity to understand, communicate with others, and hold others accountable for their actions is not sufficient reason to argue that non-human animals should not also have a right to life. Babies and the elderly who've lost their capacity for reason are two examples of humans who do not have the capacity to understand, communicate with others, and hold others accountable for their actions. Yet, our society grants them the right to life.

1229.3399.text: Rights can be enforced on both humans and nonhuman animals, such as by imprisoning a murderer \(or predator\) that would infringe on others' right to life and safety.

1229.5587.text: We only experience human consciousness, but we don't know for sure whether animals are conscious or not. We do have some evidence suggesting that animals do have social systems which govern acceptable behaviour, communicate with each other, and hold each other accountable. We cannot discount their perspectives and values simply because we aren't able to understand them.

1229.3308.text: The way an animal lives is at least as important as how it dies, and farm animals have demonstrably lower quality of life than wild animals in at least some cases \(over-crowded cages/enclosures, absence of freedom of movement, inability to escape rivals, etc.\).

1229.6151.text: The argument that you should do something to your own benefit because the same thing would happen if you didn't so you might as well is immoral. For example, I might as well rape that passed out girl because it's going to happen to her anyway so I might as well get to do it is an immoral way to approach something.

1229.3302.text: This is already a debateable point, but even if we assume it's true, then it would be good to eradicate them because they do more harm \(and cost more lives\) than their own life's worth, NOT because their life has NO value of its own.

1229.3020.text: If this argument was true, it would be moral for someone to be raised their whole life in something akin to a prison, as long as it was all they were exposed to, as they would not know there is a better life, but this is clearly false.

1229.3169.text: Cows and chickens know what it is like to feel pain, and desire not to feel pain. This is sufficient to give them a right to live free of suffering.

1229.3216.text: It doesn't matter what the chicken's frame of reference is, as long as the chicken is suffering under our treatment. In the words of the Utilitarian philosopher [Jeremy Bentham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeremy_Bentham), "the question is not, Can they reason? nor Can they talk? but, Can they suffer?"

1229.2095.text: [98.8%](https://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/permanent-exhibitions/human-origins-and-cultural-halls/anne-and-bernard-spitzer-hall-of-human-origins/understanding-our-past/dna-comparing-humans-and-chimps/) of human and chimp DNA is the same, and they are so similar because they are closely related.

1229.2535.text: There is no inherent difference between animals and humans; to insist otherwise is [speciesism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speciesism), the act of discriminating against a being on the basis of their species.

1229.3024.text: Humans are superior to all other animals, because they have the ability to make choices based on morality, and not instinct. It's what separates us from all other life known life forms.

1229.3069.text: Following that logic, animals are not superior to any other life form, they are simply a small part of a whole ecosystem. As such they have no legitimate right to kill other life forms as they please. This is inherently problematic.

1229.3125.text: The concept of "rights" is a creation of rational beings living in a society. The idea of "rights" seeks to transcend ecosystems and the "state of nature". If we are considering humans and other animals in their natural context of a state of nature in an ecosystem, then introducing rights is an inappropriate and anachronistic interjection.

1229.5241.text: When we look at it biologically, assigning less value to animals is a form of discrimination. It's just discrimination based on more features than within-species discrimination \(e.g. different anatomical structures or less intelligence instead of just the color of the skin\).

1229.6236.text: Human beings are not better than other animals.  An increasing amount of research is showing that they have feelings and they suffer just like humans. The literature comprises articles, books and academic papers: [www.amazon.com](https://www.amazon.com/Second-Nature-Inner-Animals-MacSci/dp/0230107818/?&tag=livescience-20); [inews.co.uk](https://inews.co.uk/news/science/animals-feelings-heres-science-prove/); [www.theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/oct/11/elephants-animal-welfare-why-do-we-deny-ignore-feelings-other-species); etc.

1229.3071.text: It is more ethical to give to charity than to not give to charity, but to not give to charity is not immoral.

1229.3205.text: There are other reasons why harvesting meat from a meat plant is more desirable. It is a more efficient process to grow a plant than to raise an animal. Therefore from a carbon standpoint the plant is more ethical.

1229.3784.text: There is less clear and abundant evidence that plants and microorganisms suffer in ways analogous to humans and other animals.

1229.6109.text: Where would the animals go? If we stop farming animals for food, there will be numerous domesticated species that are no longer needed in farming but may also struggle to exist in the wild. If we could not agree space for them and invest in managing their transition to a stable wild ecosystem \(the path for which is uncertain and could take generations\), then the only alternative would be mass culling and ultimately the extinction of these species.

1229.6167.text: Countless animals have experienced life because they were bred as food. For me the better question is whether they are living a life worth living. Do they have room to roam, do they live without undue suffering, are they treated with respect while they are alive.

1229.4002.text: It is morally permissible to kill or cause the death of another human to save your own life in some situations.

1229.6410.text: Sentence "killing humans is wrong" doesn't imply sentence "killing animals is wrong". Hence one person can simultaneously assert that killing humans is wrong, and that killing animals is okay, avoiding any contradiction or hypocrisy.

1229.4199.text: They also wouldn't have been forced to suffer as they often are in modern factory farming.

1229.4565.text: Suggesting one human is \(inherently\) inferior to another is highly subjective and potentially problematic.

1229.6713.text: Animals are not innocent in the sense that they have no conflict of conscience over consuming their prey.

1229.6714.text: A "duty to help" would need to include exploitation of nature as well as mankind. Nature's treatment of animals is as bad or worse than that of humans.

1229.123.text: In confined animal feeding operations \([CAFOs](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/pew_putting_meat_on_the_table.pdf)\) pigs have their tails cut off, chickens have their toenails and beaks clipped off, and cows have their horns removed and tails cut off with no painkillers.

1229.124.text: [Baby cows](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/farm_sanctuary_welfare_of_cattle_in_beef_production.pdf) raised for veal are tied up and confined in tiny stalls their entire short lives \(3-18 weeks\).

1229.722.text: The animals' nourishment in factory farming is often contrary to their natural one.

1229.1311.text: Industrial livestock farming might not replicate the natural environment of animals, yet it is an expression of the food chain in which humans dominate these animals. In this sense, it is quite natural.

1229.1872.text: Animals are often given so little space that they cannot turn around or lie down comfortably.

1229.1874.text: Most factory-farmed animals have been genetically manipulated to grow larger or to produce more milk or eggs than they naturally would.

1229.221.text: In contemporary intensive animal farming there is massive [use of antibiotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antibiotic_use_in_livestock) and antimicrobials in livestock to treat infections as well as to promote growth and improve feed efficiency.

1229.2616.text: Humans are part of nature, and hence what they choose to do and what to they actually do are not separable from nature. It is only perception that human is distinct from nature, but there is no fundamental basis for this.

1229.2288.text: Laws in states such as the UK require that animals be [stunned](https://www.rspca.org.uk/adviceandwelfare/farm/slaughter/factfile) before being killed, so as to be totally unconscious \(and thus incapable of feeling pain\) at the time of their slaughter.

1229.2293.text: The [Humane Slaughter Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humane_Slaughter_Act) in the US has been a federal law for over 60 years. It decrees that the animal must be insensible to pain prior to slaughter.

1229.2295.text: In Australia, there is a [legal standard](http://kb.rspca.org.au/how-are-animals-killed-for-food_477.html) that calls for "the minimisation of the risk of injury, pain and suffering and the least practical disturbance to the animals” during slaughter.

1229.2296.text: [Video evidence](https://www.thedodo.com/chickens-video-legal-slaughter-gordon-1043872702.html) has shown that chickens are slammed onto hooks for slaughter, scalded alive and suffocated during the slaughtering process at some factories.

1229.2297.text: [EU legislation](https://ec.europa.eu/food/animals/welfare/practice/slaughter_en) calls for the use of properly approved stunning methods in order to minimise the pain and suffering of farm animals being slaughtered.

1229.2298.text: [Numerous](http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/outcry-after-undercover-film-exposes-brutality-of-halal-industry-10019467.html) [undercover](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/stephen-wells/undercover-investigation-_b_8131212.html) [investigations](https://www.peta.org/features/butterball-peta-investigation/) have reported slaughter-houses' gross misconducts and abuses, which resulted in a total disregard for animals' welfare during the slaughter.

1229.2916.text: Nearly one million chickens and turkeys are [boiled alive](http://nation.time.com/2013/10/29/nearly-one-million-chickens-and-turkeys-unintentionally-boiled-alive-each-year-in-u-s/) each year in the U.S. alone.

1229.3208.text: Humane slaughter is as fast and painless as possible. Death in the wild is almost always one of the following: Starvation, disease, freezing, scorching or being eaten alive.

1229.237.text: Industrial livestock farming results from peoples' hunger for tons of cheap meat. If people would consume meat only once a week we would not need these unethical structures.

1229.2050.text: This still suggests a need for a massive reduction in the amount of meat consumed to stop particularly unnatural methods of meat production. Even then, animals would be being slaughtered for food, such that the best ethical outcome is for everyone to stop eating meat.

1229.4854.text: Eating meat encourages increased meat production; not eating meat discourages it. Therefore, humans who are aware of the issues should stop eating meat, to reduce the demand for it and hence, the prevalence of unnatural and immoral farming methods.

1229.2955.text: De-beaking is a procedure in which one to two thirds of each hen's beak tip - which has similar [pain receptors](https://freefromharm.org/animal-cruelty-investigation/debeaking-video-shows-standard-practice-on-free-range-egg-farms/) to those found in human fingertips - is seared off without anaesthetic. It is reportedly standard practice on both factory and free-range egg-laying farms.

1229.3247.text: This sentience is momentary and [ephemeral](https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2015/02/150225-dogs-memories-animals-chimpanzees-science-mind-psychology/), thus should not interfere in animals' ability to predict death and retain recent events. Parenthood problems could, therefore, be avoided by sedating and giving more "humane" treatment to animals.

1229.4344.text: This is a biological response rather than emotional. Mother cows udders become full of milk when the calf is removed, and the mother is looking for her calf simply for relief. The same is true of removed calves calling for their mothers for milk. Once the calves begin to eat solid food they stop searching for the mother, and once the mothers' milk production stops they stop searching for their calves. If there was an emotional response, we could assume some pairs would continue to search.

1229.3813.text: My friend used to work in the poultry industry and personally witnessed extensive abuse of the animals on a daily basis.

1229.4583.text: Many current farming operations either do not realize or do not apply this principle.

1229.5619.text: Their claim is supported by the existence of battery cages.

1229.748.text: Roger Scruton, [on his duty to eat meat](http://animalethics.blogspot.co.nz/2011/06/roger-scruton-on-duty-to-eat-meat.html), exclusively refers to conscientious carnivores and their ability to promote compassionate farming. Thus, he also rejects the current state of meat production.

1229.2246.text: Moral behaviour would likely not include being complicit in the slaughter of animal life for food.

1229.2797.text: Humans feel empathy for their pets.

1229.2798.text: It has not been shown that animals have emotions with which to empathize; humans should thus be reciprocal in how they consider other creatures.

1229.2830.text: Care for animals and nature is necessary for human survival on this planet in a natural way.

1229.2834.text: The exercise of true care is necessary for the human race to evolve and to grow in consciousness.

1229.3906.text: Animals have feelings and positive interaction with animals help us get more connected with nature and in turns make us way more happier beings.

1229.5095.text:
This argument seem to suggest that eating meat first started in the last 50 years, or last generation.

Keep in mind humans have been eating meat a lot longer than that, and if your argument is true the issue is already lost, since the close-minded human population already cannot feel emotions.

Since you can, and you are part of humanity, you are living proof that theory does not hold.

1229.10522.text: Empathy is [subjective](https://news.psu.edu/story/600235/2019/12/09/research/empathy-option-science-how-and-why-we-choose-be-empathetic#); our response to stimuli like these can be modified easily.

1229.5502.text: Eating meat requires, at least for now, killing living and breathing creatures that feel pain and joy same way as we, humans, do. As the smartest species we are obligated to take responsibility for our actions regarding other species, and, especially when eating meat is unnecessary for our survival, it's clear, or at least it should be, that killing other animals only for our pleasure is cruel and despicable.

1229.5094.text:
Different groups define different standards all the time. Sapience does not require a common standard for all, but for groups \(consensus\).

For example: Homosexuality is being increasingly accepted around the world. Not in spite of sapience, but because of it.

Eating whales, which is common in nordic countries, and eating dogs, which is common in some eastern countries, could be considered immoral by some, but not by them.

[Gay acceptance](https://scholar.google.no/scholar?q=homosexuality+increasingly+accepted&hl=en&as_sdt=0&as_vis=1&oi=scholart&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3u82807zYAhUGCpoKHdu9CT4QgQMIJTAA)
[Whale - Norwegian food](https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=no&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=https%3A%2F%2Fnorskhval.no%2Ffakta%2Fen-unik-ravare%2F&edit-text=&act=url)
[Dog Meat Festival - China](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Lychee_and_Dog_Meat_Festival)

1229.5126.text: Naturalness or temptation does not award permission; it awards nothing. Naturalness or temptation are merely concepts, and not sapient in themselves, and as such will not affect the permission of eating meat at all.

1229.6130.text: This is an unreliable phenomenon. Whether this is an actual instinct or an instinct that are commonly warped by experience, is hard to discern. For many people the compasionate instinct described doesn't exist and the this version of compassion is a result of modern western life rather than something inherent to the human species.

1229.6816.text: One of the prerequisites for empathy to be substantiated is similar levels of sentience and cognitive capacity. It is not the case therefore there is no rational grounds for empathy

1229.469.text: It is rarely the case that we eat meat that comes from accidentally hurt or killed animals. For the main part the meat we consume comes from livestock farming.

1229.476.text: Severely injured horses are often brought to [slaughterhouses](http://www.horsefund.org/resources/Horse%20Slaughter%20Fact%20Sheet%20iFH.pdf).

1229.462.text: One could just stop breeding them in the first place.

1229.464.text: Male goats produce no benefit for the farmer.

1229.3730.text: If you're eating less meat you are still eating meat.

1229.3732.text: It doesn't matter how the animal died that doesn't change that the meat would still be wasted.

1229.506.text: Religious festivities like [Eid al-Adha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eid_al-Adha) involve animal sacrifice.

1229.990.text: A variety of animals are sacrificed in accordance with [Hinduism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_sacrifice_in_Hinduism).

1229.989.text: The religion of [Tengrism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tengrism) involves animal sacrifice.

1229.2260.text: Sacrificing animals for religious purposes is also unethical, and we should stop doing it.

1229.3742.text: Never existing is worse than dying because if you exist you at least were able to experience some form of life.

1229.3876.text: Hunting is beneficial to the environment as it helps prevent over-population of several species of animal that, if un-controlled, would destroy the environments they live in.

1229.4564.text: This is not a practically viable method of sourcing meat. Who would watch for such incidental deaths?

1229.2507.text: We treat everybody who provides us with services \(e.g. plumbers\) as means to our ends.

1229.2951.text: We should measure the morality of our actions towards animals on whether we fulfil their desires while they are alive, not on an abstract logical deduction regarding the nature of sentience. Pigs, for example, want to wallow in the mud, eat, reproduce, and have a painless death; we can fulfil all those desires and also eat the pigs afterwards, thus we can, morally, treat them as a means to an end.

1229.2638.text: Merely eating meat isn't cruel. What is cruel is the factory farm system we use to get the meat. If we can get the meat without causing undue pain to the animal, there is no issue.

1229.2636.text: Animals are currently being treated horribly, but many meat eaters are using their sway as actual consumers to improve animals' living conditions. This combined attention and sway is sure to help animal rights in the long run.

1229.2844.text: Cruelty, being a trait derived from the human mind, is only applicable to meat consumption if it is done irresponsibly as compared to other consumers of meat in the animal kingdom.

1229.5402.text: Humans can make a choice to reduce the cruelty and immoral treatment of animals, as well as to reduce their consumption to a naturally sustainable amount.  This would be more likely to work if there weren't corporate "factories" for meat production--if humans were required to raise and/or hunt their own prey, and if there were distinct regulations disallowing and punishing animal cruelty on any spectrum.

1229.5401.text: Eating meat and cruel/immoral treatment of animals are not mutually exclusive - one can exist without the other. Large farms or "reserves" where animals are able to live a full and healthy life is a possible example. Likewise, it could also be assumed that ending the suffering for animals who are injured or already dying is more humane and less wasteful than allowing their suffering or wasting their remains.

1229.3301.text: Even free range farming violates the rights of animals by imprisoning them \(albeit in a larger enclosure\) and eventually killing them against their will.

1229.5493.text: Farm animals by definition cannot enjoy humane living conditions, since their freedom of movement will necessarily have to be violated.

1229.3298.text: Animals in the wild often endure a great deal of suffering due to violent deaths from predators, starvation, or exposure. A peaceful life on a farm is plausibly preferable to a life in the wild.

1229.4637.text: Domesticated animals, including animals raised for meat, [show significantly lower levels of the stress hormones epinephrine and norepinephrine than their wild counterparts](https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/bambi-or-bessie-are-wild-animals-happier/).

1229.6091.text: The rearing of animals need not be seen as 'solely for eating', with additional responsibilities requiring a reasonable life. If meat consumption ceased, it is unlikely the farm animals would be reintroduced to the wild, they would simply vanish from existence.

1229.6136.text: In the wild, there are no such concepts as compassion or malice. There is only nature, which is primal and brutal. A swift death at the hands of a hunter or farmer who will use the animal for food, clothing, etc. is a far better death than by natural predators, disease, or famine.

1229.3297.text: Free range labels could be reformed to allow consumers to eat meat ethically.

1229.3304.text: Enforcing such legislation would take time, resources, and labour hours \(proportionate to its complexity\). This would necessitate extra funding or taking from somewhere else.

1229.2531.text: This is because humans have special, higher-order rights - for example, a right to freedom. Animals do not have these rights, so it is permissible to breed them for certain uses.

1229.2931.text: This is an anthropomorphic analogy.  It is a trait of human psychology and one in this case which is incorrect.  Comparing a human child to a feed lot animal is unbalanced in value. A feed lot animal if left in it's natural condition consumes plants and in turn is consumed by other animals. If humans were not eating them they would be eaten by other predators/scavengers in the wild. Their condition in life does not change much between feed lot and field.

1229.4137.text: Granting sentient existence just to revoke it is arguably the cruelest act one can rationalize. That is "playing god" to its worst possible meaning.

1229.5557.text: Bringing an entity into existence does not mean that you have the ability to use that entity for whatever purpose you want.

1229.2099.text: As long as these animals are given a reasonable quality of life, it is preferable that they get the opportunity to exist given to them by humans for the purpose of farming. In the alternative, many animals do not get to exist at all.

1229.2123.text: The lives of most animals in factory farms are plausibly worse than not existing, so it is immoral to bring them into existence.

1229.3561.text: If we cease eating meat then millions of animals will never be born at all. We cannot be certain that animals would prefer to never be born than to die prematurely.

1229.5125.text: The farming process is far from cruelty-free. As unanimous ethical farming seems to be impossible in our global capitalist climate the easiest way to ensure ethical treatment of animals is to take part in a widespread movement to stop supporting farmed meat.

1229.5622.text: Domestication was a "social contract" between the two species: humans obtained a mobile source of food and cloth and the animals were assured basic necessities and protection from natural predators and a guaranteed way to spread their genes. In the present, domesticated animals can be considered the most "successful" species, with 0 probability of becoming extinct, while many "free" wild animals starve and are less able to reproduce.

1229.6005.text: To not eat an animal who dedicated it's entire life so that it can be consumed is not only wasteful but disrespectful towards that animal's sacrifice to sustain us.

1229.3823.text: This still entails killing animals for their meat, and likely breeding and raising them in captivity.

1229.3957.text: This would only work if all other meat production was stopped. Maybe stopping meat consumption in the present is the most effective way to get this to come about.

1229.6923.text: Small productions cannot compete with large ones because they are small. It's already the case that most farms are small but most animals come from big farms, so adding more small farms won't help. For example, in the US in 2012: 57% of farms with cattle sold less than 20 cattle each, while 4.6% of all cattle came from such farms. 0.9% of farms sold at least 1000 cattle each, while 51% of all cattle came from such farms. [Source and more details and examples.](https://veganconclusion.wordpress.com/2018/01/27/most-farm-animals-are-treated-terribly/#farm-sizes)

1229.4009.text: If nobody eats meat, nobody will buy meat, and all meat producers will go out of business - including and especially the unethical ones.

1229.5472.text: If consumers stop eating meat altogether, then unethical meat producers know there is nothing they can do to get the demand back, so they do not change behaviour. If consumers switch to more ethical options, unethical producers are incentivised to produce more ethically.

1229.4200.text: The humaneness of their treatment pre-slaughter is still relevant, as minimizing suffering is the end goal or one of the goals of many moral systems.

1229.5698.text: Food production is fully integrated into capitalism, in which profits are always the priority. Unless/until that changes, this point is purely hypothetical/unrealistic.

1229.5702.text: Humans have always find nutrients around them. Killing an animal of another species has not the same ethical value as killing a human. There will be much more stress in going personally to hunt animals.

1229.6597.text: This doesn't mean you shouldn't eat meat from those sources if you have access to them.

1229.6925.text: Even if better welfare improves meat quality, most animals are still treated poorly, indicating that reducing costs is a better strategy for profits than increasing quality. This is probably because consumers are more sensitive to price than quality. There's no reason to expect this to significantly change any time soon.

1229.5451.text: In those cases, consumers could have a moral obligation to either purchase the expensive ethical meat or not purchase meat at all. This still would not imply that we should never eat meat.

1229.5869.text: Nearly every piece of meat comes from factory farms with unethical conditions – the meat in the supermarket, in restaurants, public events et cetera. Choosing to abstain from this kind of meat means practically to completely abstain from meat as there is in fact no supply for it.

1229.6866.text: Ethical meat consumption is not a widespread effective method of reducing animal harm. Not eating meat is simple, consumes little to no time, and has been proven to work for a massive amount of human beings.

1229.5435.text: Most animals lack essential prerequisites for the right to life, like self-awareness or the ability to have desires about the future. While they may have a right to be free of suffering, they do not have a right to life.

1229.5638.text: Eating 'happy meat' \(i.e. produced with less suffering\) is still discrimination, because we would not eat happy meat from e.g. humans or dogs. Killing a happy person \(e.g. a pig or human\) in order to eat him or her, remains a violation of the right not to be used as a means against one's will.

1229.4195.text: There are, in fact, better \(and more natural\) ways to manage pests than indiscriminately killing with pesticides. Naturally derived repellents are available and viable.

1229.6132.text: Vegetarian diets are also not free from wasted lives.[Jain vegetarians place value on plant lives](http://www.jainfoodie.com/jain-food-restrictions/). If a root vegetable goes to waste, they would believe that that plant died in vain.

1229.6133.text: Most meat comes from a killed animal, whereas not all vegetarian foods come from a killed animal or plant \(such as fruit\). Thus, a vegetarian diet could be cruelty-free for wasted food.

1229.6272.text: This is bad, because it accomplishes little and instead makes the world worse off than before.

1229.6134.text: Even waste from vegan food makes up for the loss \(that meat cannot achieve\) multi-fold. For example, not eating fruit helps the plant that wasted fruit came from. Here, the cycle of life continues because a person can plant the seeds to grow a new fruit tree that bears more fruits. This more than makes up for the one fruit that went to waste.

1229.3773.text: Plants are able to survive losing a large portion of their biomass, and many produce fruiting bodies deliberately intended for consumption by animals. Meanwhile, harvesting an animal for meat kills it 100% of the time. It is more possible to compassionately harvest \(some\) plants than animals.

1229.4842.text: Not all moral systems are centred on the reduction of suffering.

1229.5115.text: If reducing suffering is the only measure of good, the logical conclusion is that we must end all life to end all suffering. This is inherently wrong.

1229.5116.text: If reducing suffering is good, but we do not have to end suffering entirely, then responsible farming of domesticated livestock accomplishes this end, as few domesticated animals living in these circumstances will suffer as much, or die as miserably as their wild counterparts.

1229.5117.text: If the only moral factor is 'reducing suffering is good', then a responsible hunter who kills their prey quickly is more moral than a vegan who eats foods harvested from large fields where animals are caught and maimed by harvesting equipment. The hunter is more responsible than that same group because field crops cause animals to reproduce more quickly, only to have their food supply eliminated as winter approaches, with few natural predators nearby to bring them swifter death than starvation.

1229.5721.text: I don't think we can say definitively that it reduces suffering. Are plants capable of suffering? I know some would say so. Are insects capable of suffering? How would you define suffering? Is one creature's suffering more relevant than another's? Which is worse, the death and suffering of a million insects, a hundred mice, or a single cow?

1229.4841.text: It also shows, once again, that we are irrationally biased towards certain animals.

1229.6043.text: Thinking compassionately about animals and thinking of them as supper are not mutually exlusive. In fact, the vast majority of farmers producing meat think very compassionately about their animals and ensure their well-being. Not just for economic, but for moral and compassionate reasons.

1229.3232.text: Humans subjectively determine what has moral value for humans. It is possible and probable other animals with social structures have their own sense of morality. Several animals have shown that they understand what is fair and not fair, including [chimpanzees](http://www.pnas.org/content/110/6/2070.abstract), [crows](http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0056885), and dogs. [Capuchin monkeys](https://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/09/0917_030917_monkeyfairness.html) have rejected rewards when they saw them as unfair or unequal to rewards given to their peers. Surely a recognition of fairness equates a type of morality. Humans are not the sole arbiters of moral value.

1229.3367.text: Majorities are not always correct, and the original subject of "humans should stop eating meat" is prescriptive, i.e., discussing what we should start doing rather than what we are. Potentially changing societal opinions and perspectives is well within the scope of this debate.

1229.3366.text: The very first human societies were naturally gathered tribes, so applying morality to nature is not pointless - it is in fact a significant part of how humans became and continue to be what we are today, as moral constraints to our natural state formed a significant part of shaping modern society and the modern quality of life we enjoy. They can similarly help to improve animals' quality of life.

1229.5511.text: The illusion of being more than nature or above nature is created by actual society. The detachment from simple things as finding our own food make us believe we are not animals but the biology says otherwise.

1229.4045.text: Bivalves are marginal cases which aren't really relevant to the majority of animal agriculture.  It's readily provable that a pig can feel pain and suffering in a way that a carrot cannot.

1229.4643.text: This position assumes out of hand that some things are definitively wrong. Yes, a strong moral system gives us a tool for "objectively" decrying actions that we disagree with, but saying that moral relativism is a weak standard doesn't affect whether or not it is real.

1229.3572.text: Humans can determine whatever they want, just look back in history. The apartheid regime of South Africa or the Nazi German concentration camps. Or even further back to the time of the Roman Empire.

1229.3571.text: Taking into account preferences of different animals and trying to please all of them will eventually fail. Humans might have higher moral standards than other animals but humans still are animals that have preferences.

1229.3273.text: Humans are the only species on our planet with the power of sophisticated ethical reasoning. It is because of this that we can be bound by morality, which can include prescriptions about how we should or should not act on our environment and other beings in that environment.

1229.3274.text: Humans are part of the natural world. If morality is an irrelevant concept in the context of the natural world, it follows that morality must be irrelevant in the context of humans. But the author states that morality applies to humans. This is a contradiction, and therefore the claim taken as a whole is logically invalid.

1229.4043.text: We already apply moral concepts to non-human animals in most societies. Forms of animal cruelty are illegal in many countries, showing that we can intuitively and practically apply moral reasoning to non-human animals.

1229.4128.text: The philosophy of non-consumption of animals IS a human moral construct asserting itself onto human beings.  Vegetarianism isn't being applied to the animals. Animals are not being held to moral standards; we are.

1229.4456.text: Good morality and excercise of care is essential to keep both the human mind and the ecosystem in a healthy state, while ignorance will only lead to endless self inflicted suffering. Animals are not held under the same moral standards as human beings.

1229.4512.text: The problem with your argument is that many people don't actually contribute to society... Are we allowed then to experiment on them\(mentally handicapped, children...\)?

1229.4754.text: If being right means being beneficial to human species, then moral goodness is a merely “objective” property \(in principle measurable\) about the physical effects of something. But moral statements are not merely descriptive. People may disagree morally without disagreeing about any facts about the physical world and its laws.

1229.4797.text: If morality served only to allow people to live together and co-operate then all kinds of wrongs would be morally permissible. People can live together and co-operate in a society that allows slavery, forced child marriage, brutal excessive punishments or female genital mutilation, for example.

1229.6160.text: Morality is a subjective standard, and relative only to the standard which has been agreed is moral. "Right" and "wrong" cannot be debated objectively.

1229.3668.text: Large-scale farming also destabilizes, if not outright ruins and supplants, countless ecosystems.

1229.3755.text: Eating meat is also in some case a way to preserve species created by humans, and which can not survive without us. Such as in France: béarnaise, pie noire bretonne.

1229.3809.text: "Animals are meant to exist as part of a food chain" This is just an appeal to nature fallacy. That animals exist as a part of a food chain typically in nature isn't relevant to whether it's moral to eat meat.

1229.4008.text: Bringing animals into existences which will bring them only suffering is cruel and immoral.

1229.4044.text: It's highly unlikely that cows or other farm animals would become extinct under a vegan system, even if their numbers would be greatly reduced.

1229.5991.text: Some domestic animals are induced to produce more than what they would do naturally.

1229.4204.text: Preservation of species may not be more important than avoiding condemning \(members of\) said species to ongoing and indefinite suffering.

1229.4232.text: Factory farms are hardly a natural "habitat" for the animals which endure them, nor are such lives exactly conductive to their wellbeing. Survival is the only thing current farming practices offer them, and it is a very disturbing form thereof.

1229.3821.text: Some vegetarians and vegans do follow harm-minimization practices in other areas of their life as well, as much as reasonably possible given the current state of society.

1229.6548.text: A vegan diet does not require a dairy \(or egg\) industry.

1229.6549.text: Dairy also requires frequent breeding of cattle to keep the female in milk. Half of these calves \(the bulls\) will not be suitable for dairy production and will have to be slaughtered.

1229.6441.text: Consuming meat increases its production, but it is not consumers who determine the conditions of production and thereby cause potential suffering, but the producers.

1229.10796.text: If the production of meat can be cruel but the consumption is not necessarily, the consumer would need to take adequate measures to ensure the consumption is ethical. Such measures could be only buying meat products that meet certain animal welfare standards and supporting specific policy proposals that would raise animal welfare.

1229.6908.text: This is an oversimplification. It's clearly possible for some food systems to be significantly morally better than others, and we should strive for the best. Accepting this claim would enable all sorts of consumption which most people would find abhorrent.

1229.10816.text: That all food systems are morally debatable does not mean that the respective treatment of animals is not immoral.

1229.10818.text: That all human consumption implies the destruction of something is false, especially when also considering the net effects. Wood can be produced as a renewable resource in sustainable ways.

1229.10820.text: The claim is not about destruction but about cruelty and suffering.

1229.5734.text: That is a false dilemma and so is the conclusion. However, your claim about working conditions are probably correct in many cases. But when looking at what it takes to decrease suffering for laborers \(eg increase wages, rights to organize, improving working conditions\) versus for animals \(e.g. stop eating industrially produced meat and only eat free grazing / wild game\) it is clear that abstaining from eating meat is the more reasonable and sustainable action.

1229.2892.text: The sources linked here are extremely tenuous. For scientific claims such as these, journalistic sources are simply insufficient, and scientific literature should be cited.

1229.2967.text: Plants do not have a brain, so do not have a consciousness

1229.3008.text: The amount of consciousness that a plant could potentially have is nothing in comparison to the amount of consciousness had by animals

1229.3400.text: Further in the future, it could be possible to transition to wholly synthetic food or other means of fuelling our bodies.

1229.3519.text: The feeling of pain is produced by the nervous system. Plants do not have a nervous system so it is very unlikely that they could feel emotions at all.

1229.3578.text: Killing an animal without causing suffering is equal to killing a plant. Both have the right to live.

1229.3749.text: Plants never felt and never will feel pain. It is true, that they might have a basic awareness of their surrounding and can react to stimulis, but plants all in all lack a brain and a nervous system. Whereas animals clearly express their pain by screaming, running away etc. Plants can not react this way.This fact suggest that they are not experiencing pain. It would be straight up cruel, if nature would have ''given'' plants the ability to feel pain, since they cant move and avoid it.

1229.4000.text: The fact that plants *might* feel pain does not justify causing definite pain to animals.

1229.4046.text: It's not simply pain but also suffering. There's no good evidence that plants are conscious so they cannot suffer in any meaningful way, even if they can react to a stimulus which could be called 'pain'.

1229.4508.text: The focus should be on minimizing suffering. Humans cannot survive without eating and it seems apparent that if plants suffer, they suffer less and qualitatively differently.

1229.5211.text: Plants are the bottom of the food chain. Nothing higher up the food chain can survive without plants being eaten. Humans cannot survive without plants in their food chain.

1229.6296.text: Science might not be yet aware of the full spectrum of flora "feeling". We might, however, one day discover \(and are in the process of\) that they suffer and feel just like humans and other beings.

1229.6313.text: The alternative to eating meat on ethical grounds is eating plant based material. Plants, though, are life forms too. There is no alternative in which one eats inorganic matter or avoids killing. It is arbitrary and reductive to state that human life matters, and less complex animal life matters, but still less complex plant life does not. Consuming other species is inherent to human existence; It is naive to congratulate oneself on only killing and consuming a certain variety of life.

1229.6631.text: No one said humans had one idea at a time as a species nor was it implied. It doesn't matter whether one group of people cares for humans and the other devotes to the animal kingdom. This is about individual decisions. If someone cares about another species more than helping out their own then there is a problem.

1229.2104.text: The unintentional deaths of animals such as mice during the production of harvesting crops is very different to intentionally breeding animals such as cows for slaughter.

1229.2121.text: That study relies on a 'best case' farming practice that seeks to minimise animal deaths and protect crops through all stages of vegetable production. In almost all cases those practices are not followed in mainstream agriculture.

1229.3062.text: While the study suggests fewer animals are harmed in production of vegetarian products, the authors themselves recognize limitations in their own study. They clearly state that no accurate estimates exist of how many animals are actually harmed due to farming practices.

1229.3060.text:
That study included, "animals slaughtered directly for food, and animals killed in the harvesting of crops... predators killed in defense of livestock, animals prevented from existing by the destruction of their habitat, and human deaths from food poisoning, disease, or accidents on farms or in slaughterhouses."

It does not include intentionally killed pest animals, which would likely make a difference for both sources, especially if they included insects, which they did not.

1229.4299.text: The study talks about calories. Vegetables are more "calorie dense" \(as in calories/kg\) than meats. If we look at the numbers for protein production, the result would be the opposite, since meat is much more protein dense than vegetables. Calories alone are not sufficient for a healthy diet, and protein malnutrition can be fatal.

1229.4831.text: The study also does not take into account broader environmental impacts of plant agriculture like destruction of animal habitat for farmland, leaching of agricultural chemicals \(even fertilizer leaked into nearby areas like water source can cause negative impacts like increased algae growth which can choke out fish species\), and removal of insects which are often basal components of food webs of that area.

1229.5692.text: Animals per calorie is an absurd metric. 251.1 zooplankton are insignificant compared to 2.55 blue whales.

1229.5718.text: This is a severely misleading characterization of the study. A single cow provides far more than 1000 calories. A single pound of hamburger contains 1000 calories. [www.myfitnesspal.com](http://www.myfitnesspal.com/food/calories/generic-ground-beef-patty-1-4-lb-85-15-45681048)

1229.2117.text: In many cases, even [farming basic grains kills 25 times more sentient animals](https://theconversation.com/ordering-the-vegetarian-meal-theres-more-animal-blood-on-your-hands-4659) \(as measured against per kg of usable protein in the final product\) than the equivalent farming practices for red meat.

1229.2107.text: [Oil palm plantations](http://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/footprint/agriculture/impacts/habitat_loss/) in Indonesia and Malaysia pose significant threats to endangered elephants and tigers.

1229.2342.text: Animal agriculture also requires large amounts of land, and thus also causes habitat losses.

1229.2736.text: The vast majority of the global production of soybeans, alfalfa, corn and about 40 percent of all grains is used as feedstock for animals in CAFOs.

1229.3720.text: Technological developments can help this, for example via [vertical farming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_farming) which is much more area effective.

1229.4651.text: Land conversion occurs due to industrial activity and is not guided by an argument for meat or alternatives.

1229.2272.text: According to the [Doctrine of Double Effect](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/double-effect/), if a harm is just an unintended consequence of a good action, then that good action can be morally permissible.

1229.2489.text: At the point those consequences are systemic to mainstream agricultural practices they can't really be held to be unintended; they are known and consistent consequences.

1229.2871.text: It doesn't matter if the consequence is intended or not, it still causes harm.

1229.3793.text: There's an ethical difference between intentional killing and indirect killing.

1229.4193.text: Many of the animal deaths associated with vegetative farming are specifically intended, in order to protect crops and improve both yield and quality of harvest.

1229.4363.text: The line of thought of deontologist philosophers supports this morality.

1229.4364.text: The teleologist philosophers line of thought supports that the later is immoral since is produces what is not intended.

1229.5820.text: In as much as the production of other crops does not intend to kill animals, the intent of producing meat is also not to kill animals. The fact that the animal has to die in order for us to eat it is just as much a side effect as the mouse that has to die for the grain to be harvested and stored.

1229.2746.text: It is only true in theory that the dairy cows and laying hens are not killed in order to supply these products, but in practice, they are: these animals are usually killed at whatever point the farm considers to be the most profit-maximizing, generally when they have become too old and are used up.

1229.2743.text: [In The Netherlands](https://www.cbs.nl/en-gb/news/2012/39/growing-number-of-dairy-cattle-have-no-access-to-pasture), more than half of all dairy cows have no access to pasture and more than a quarter are tied into stalls.

1229.2744.text: Many dairy cows suffer from [claw disorders](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18096964) and [infections.](https://dairy.ahdb.org.uk/technical-information/animal-health-welfare/mastitis/recordstools/incidence-rate/#.V0bPGJF96Hs)

1229.3963.text: While this claim is true, it is not an argument for eating meat, but an argument against use of all forms of animal products.

1229.4422.text: This is not a necessary condition of dairy and egg farming. It is possible to treat cows and chickens humanely, and many farms do so. Consumers who seek out products prepared in this way, or who even raise their own cows or chickens, do not contribute to this maltreatment.

1229.4258.text: Insects do not have the same capabilities as farm animals to feel pain and suffer. [Do insects feel pain? - A biological view](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF01963580?LI=true)

1229.4330.text: Deer, Elk, Antelope, rabbits, and wild pigs are just a few examples of larger mammals that wreak havoc on crops, and which are regularly killed to protect crops.

1229.4882.text: Pests can be repelled or physically barred rather than killed in many situations.

1229.5719.text: There is no food source that does not involve the so-called cruel and immoral treatment of animals. All vegetable crops have natural predators, and these predators are harmed and killed in the process of producing these crops for human consumption.

1229.6935.text: The number of large intelligent animals which need to be killed to maintain crops is far smaller than the number of such animals farmed directly.

1229.3718.text: Through innovative new farming technology, such as hydroponic [vertical farming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_farming), food for animals can be produced in a very effective and sustainable manner.

1229.3719.text: Nature itself has a way of regulating wild life population. In the long run the population of for example cows will decrease, ensuring enough food.

1229.5142.text: Our produce is overwhelmingly grown in farms, not harvested, and thus not taken out of nature and away from animals. If you meant that any fruit that's eaten by a human was stolen from animals because it could have theoretically been gifted to an animal, than you'd have to consider eating anything stealing from every other animal on Earth, including humans.

1229.5144.text: Generally feeding animals farm-grown produce is thought to have harmful affects on both the animal and human populations of a region when we could allow nature to self-regulate its populations. Animal feeding could potentially be used to lessen the immediate impact of widespread deforestation on some species, but generally this would be drastically less efficient than choosing not to destroy their habitats in the first place and would only slow the local animal population's imminent demise.

1229.4971.text: Certain plant crops are easy to grow hydroponically such as lettuce. Hydroponic growing method harm less insects that randomly fly onto the plants because they are grown indoors. This method is better than raising meat because meat ends lives no matter the method.

1229.2835.text: Saying that a practice also causes a negative is not a counter argument. Everything effectively can be shown to create negatives. The issue is not if the practice is pristine and only creates positive outcomes, but the degree to which it creates less negatives. Animal agriculture creates more harm for animals. Animal agriculture includes all the harm of plant based agriculture plus the direct harm of farm animals. Farm animals are fed the plants, and much more than it would take to feed humans.

1229.6039.text: In this case, this argument would refute that eating meat is wrong if it were true, since eating plants and fungi is the only alternative to eating meat.

1229.6863.text: Whataboutism is a valid argument when there are only two choices, if the alternative is shown to have the same flaw, then both choices would be morally equivalent.

1229.4869.text: Ethics is not about absolutely eliminating harm, as that is currently impossible, but minimizing it and maximizing benefit.

1229.4171.text: Cows, as an example, will graze approximately [2% to 2.3%](https://beef.unl.edu/cattleproduction/forageconsumed-day) of their own weight in grass each day.

1229.4086.text: But you are operating under the assumption that you are correct that suffering and death is an unacceptable end, and therefore humans must not participate. If you are wrong, and we are arguing that you are, then the only thing that really matters is whether or not we raise plants and animals in an ethical environment where they will likely suffer less and die more peacefully than their wild cousins. If you are right, then all life is immoral and we must all die now to avoid further suffering.

1229.5394.text: There is no reason to believe that morality instructs us to remain exactly as we are originally. Rather, morality should be aspirational; it should tell us how we ought to live, not how we originally lived.

1229.692.text: This argument implies the necessity of killing for survival. Humans do not depend on killing and eating animals for their survival, and certainly not through the mass-breeding of animals with the sole purpose of killing them.

1229.970.text: Animals sometimes die out when a new predator interrupts a natural balance. Thus hunting animals to extinction is a natural process.

1229.2722.text: All living beings kill — either plant life or animal life — to survive. Even as a vegetarian, you're supporting the deaths of animals that lose habitat to farming, are killed for pest control, etc. The question isn't whether or not to kill--it's how to do so humanely.

1229.2997.text: It is natural for organisms to die so others can live. It is not natural for these organisms to be exploited, mass produced and fed growth hormones.

1229.4893.text: Nature is amoral. Humans are not.

1229.4958.text: If one day, humans disappear from earth, prey animals will be still eaten by other predators. Nature set up a system where some animals eat others. Humans are not a different creature, we only has a different weapon \(intelligence\) than other predators. Humans have no influence on nature's law; it is a system that was here long ago before humans even existed on this earth.

1229.4960.text:
If we didn't eat animals, their equivalents in the wilds would still be eaten by other predators, so as long as we give our animals living conditions and deaths that aren't worse/less humane than ones in the wild, eating them makes no difference, morally speaking.

Therefore, we should instead focus on improving the living conditions of animals and making their deaths as humane as possible. This is a far more realistic goal to focus on, compared to trying to prevent humanity from consuming meat.

1229.5668.text: This argument negates all contributions made by medicine.

1229.6127.text: Nature is quite specific about which animals routinely kill and eat others and which do not. A human without technology or fire would largely be unable to kill, butcher or eat anything other than perhaps a few bugs with their physical equipment. They lack sharp teeth and claws for ripping flesh and/or catching prey and a low enough stomach pH for safely digesting raw meat. Just like the other great apes, humans are physically adapted to consuming a predominantly plant based diet after weaning.

1229.485.text: Other animals eat animals too. For humans, as for these animals, it is therefore only natural.

1229.3863.text: It is not just how an animal dies that matters, but how it lives. A free life, even one with a \(temporarily\) painful end, is arguably preferable to a life in a cage, especially when some of the more barbaric and cruel factory farming practices \(de-beaking, other forms of un-anaesthetized mutilation, insufficient health care to prevent diseases from spreading across the herd, etc.\) come into play.

1229.4132.text: Indeed, keeping animals for slaughter who never knew freedom or happiness is arguably more ethical than capturing free beings in the wild with painful traps, no regard for offspring/mates, and potential waste. Not to mention the effect on the ecosystem of free-range hunting in the quantities currently demanded.

1229.4234.text: Eating animals that have been raised in a responsible environment and killed humanely offers a better life than most ever obtain from living wild.

1229.4265.text: Healthy farm animals fit into a healthy farm system like wild animals fit into a wild ecosystem. In domesticating live stock we have created animals that are most comfortable in agricultural \(rather than wild\) conditions.

1229.4480.text: It is not just that humans keep animals for slaughtering, but that they produce animals for the specific purpose of slaughtering and eating them. Without the meat industry, these animals would not need to be bred in such numbers and less animals would be killed.

1229.4965.text:
While we should aim to reduce and eventually eliminate the suffering of animals, vegetarianism is a tacit demand for the extinction of all domesticated animals used for food.
If an animal living in the wild were given the choice of being guaranteed food, shelter, and procreation knowing that their eventual demise would be painless and provide their ancestors a similar lifestyle, they would likely agree to live under those conditions rather than suffer in the wild.

1229.5389.text: If we did not raise animals for meat, those farm animals would not exist in the wild; rather, they would simply not exist.

1229.5391.text: We are not morally culpable for the deaths of animals in the wild. By contrast, we are morally culpable for suffering we deliberately inflict.

1229.6071.text: Not keeping an animal at all is therefore even "more humane" compared to both of these options. We should therefore, as intelligent beings, choose the best option possible and not keep animals at all, since we don`t need to do so.

1229.4590.text: No "prey" animal is eaten by its own nature, rather because other animals evolve to prey on it.

1229.4790.text: Morality is not predicated upon the nature of or actions of others.

1229.5453.text: Humans treat all sorts of things unnaturally: for example, using animal products to create glue, or minerals to create computers. Clearly humans have the capacity to go beyond a thing's "natural purpose."

1229.4083.text: All life suffers, and all life dies. Furthermore, all life inevitably results in the suffering and death of other life. Competition for food and habitat, predation, competition to reproduce...all of this happens even without human influence, even in microbial ecosystems. So the logical conclusion of this claim is that life itself is cruel and immoral. It is a spiritual, subjective, and therefore unsubstantiated claim. One cannot possibly know the truth.

1229.6982.text: When most humans see slaughter houses, they feel [discomfort](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TOBWoAwCQyk&has_verified=1) whereas if a carnivore animal saw one they'd feel hunger and likely attempt to eat the animal there and then. Therefore it can no longer be considered our nature to treat animals as prey or act as if we are instinctually predators.

1229.6850.text: Animals that form communities usually cooperate without killing each other, and humans are such animals. It is natural for humans not to kill each other.

1229.5454.text: What is "natural" is specifically that animals eat other animals for survival. Eating other animals for pleasure is not natural.

1229.5479.text: The fact that we transcend the natural order in many ways does not make us obligated to deviate from our natural behaviours. If I like eating meat and it is a natural thing for a human being, there is no immorality in eating it.

1229.5827.text: It is not very civilized of humans to adapt the same meat-eating habits as wild beasts in nature.

1229.6464.text: Part of the evolution of humans is to develop increased empathy for other species.
