We cannot advance as a species until we accept that we are no different than any other animal, and accept our place in the animal kingdom. When we embrace each other as earthlings or universal beings, as opposed to humans/vs animals, only then can we escape the trap of the speciesist mindset.

1229.6845.text: We still need to eat to live. Things we eat die. Therefore, we still need to have things die for us to live.

1229.5392.text: The methods by which prey animals are killed vary from predator to predator. It may be natural for humans to use technology to kill prey animals.

1229.5397.text: It might be the case that we ought to stop factory farming techniques, but this does not imply that we ought to stop eating meat entirely.

1229.6851.text: Any achievement of humanity was ultimately the product of their evolutionary path; every human action is "natural".

1229.6891.text: The vast majority of animals are bred artificially, separated from their families and raised in a completely artificial and confined manner. No element of their life is natural. This is what differentiates it from nature.

1229.5478.text: Murder or rape are not natural. When an animal kills a prey, it is not murder, it is hunting. Also, rape is not a thing among animals, as there is no consent among them.

1229.5943.text: To claim the natural order of the world is the ethical ideal, is an appeal to violence and dominance as a form of moral order. This is the basis for the old arguments in support of slavery and genocide; hardly a fit for the 21st century.

1229.5423.text: Most people intuitively make a sharp distinction between the deaths of animals in the wild and the deaths of animals in farms, which suggests that they do not treat farms as simply another instance of the predator-prey dynamic.

1229.5424.text: That we ought to eliminate both the suffering of wild animals and the suffering of farm animals is a natural consequence of the idea that animals are morally important. It is not a conclusion that we should avoid.

1229.5425.text: It is [plausible to believe](https://foundational-research.org/the-importance-of-wild-animal-suffering/) that most natural habitats are, on net, bad for animal wellbeing. If we cared overridingly about animal welfare, then we ought to destroy those habitats. The fact that we reject this indicates that animal welfare is not the overriding consideration, and that there is intrinsic value associated with the operation of natural habitats.

1229.5630.text: Humans are concerned about being responsible for the death of animals, so the question "Is eating meat wrong?" is about humans eating meat and being responsible for the caused harm, and not about non-human animals eating meat.

1229.5830.text: There is some concern for the [welfare of animals in the wild](http://www.animal-ethics.org/wild-animal-suffering-section/wild-animal-suffering-matters/), although the movement is probably not as large as it should be.

1229.5913.text: Humans have made improvements to nonhuman animals' habitats for welfare reasons. Examples of this are the [provision of water](https://www.thedodo.com/water-man-kenya-animals-2263728686.html) during droughts to prevent dehydration related suffering and deaths and the [construction of crossings](https://www.denverpost.com/2018/02/03/animal-wildlife-crossings/) over or under busy roads to prevent accident related injuries and deaths. The planting of biome-appropriate, food-producing plants to alleviate hunger might also be considered.

1229.5952.text: If the suffering of the eaten animal is what makes eating meat immoral, humans have as much right to meat or lack thereof than other meat-eating animals. Creating a world without animal consumption would make entire ecosystems dependent on the human existence and good will.

1229.6693.text: "Extreme forms of suffering like starvation, dehydration, or being eaten alive by a predator are much more common in wild animals than farm animals. Crocodiles and hyenas disembowel their prey before killing them \(Tomasik 2009\). In birds, diseases like avian salmonellosis produce excruciating symptoms in the final days of life, such as depression, shivering, loss of appetite, and just before death, blindness, incoordination, staggering, tremor and convulsions." \([Journal of Practical Ethics](http://www.jpe.ox.ac.uk/papers/consistent-vegetarianism-and-the-suffering-of-wild-animals/)\)

1229.6694.text: From a utilitarian perspective, to take farming away likely puts those animals in a state of nature or non-existence. Given nature's cruelty, there's little reason to believe either are better for the animal.

1229.2613.text: Many animals are killed and consumed by predators every day. The only difference is that humans do not perceive sadness when those animals suffer and are killed in the wild. It is actually the individual's perception that an animal is suffering \(when a human butchers it\) that causes him/her to feel pity, and not the fact that animals are suffering \(which happens all the time, everywhere\).

1229.6682.text: Extreme forms of suffering like starvation, dehydration, or being eaten alive by a predator are much more common in wild animals than farm animals. If non-existence is a better alternative, we should be at least as concerned with animals under nature's "care"; potentially sterilizing or deliberately destroying wild animal habitats. \([See Journal of Practical Ethics](http://www.jpe.ox.ac.uk/papers/consistent-vegetarianism-and-the-suffering-of-wild-animals/)\)

1229.5579.text: In fact, since humans evolved as the result of natural processes, whatever humans do is, tautologically, natural.

1229.5629.text: It is difficult to think of a case where people have to abandon part of their humanity to be moral. People can't have a moral obligation to grow gills or wings.

1229.6317.text: Reducing our lives to just what is necessary would make it a sad time. Not even animals \(as opposed to humans\) reduce their living to what is necessary. We eat meat because we find pleasure in it.

1229.5915.text: The argument could also be made about growing vegetables.  If we follow this rabbit hole then we would be scavenging natural resources to the point of greater harm.

1229.6069.text: We \(humans\) shouldn't be the ones to choose what kind of lives animals should have and there is no guarantee that "ethically raised animals" have better lives than those who live in the wild.

1229.6070.text: Only animals that have died of a natural cause can, therefore, be used as meat, since there is no such thing as killing ethically an animal that wants to live.

1229.6220.text: It could be regarded as immoral to use the resources of the planet in such an ineficcient and irresponsable way, considering that it might lead to hunger, as it dimishes availability of food for humanity as a whole, and the exhaustation of Earth's environment can as well be regarded as inmoral, as it affects all life on Earth.

1229.6763.text: But the way we rear most animals is not so humane. And often the killing fails and is not so humane.

1229.10516.text: Animals don't have a sense of morality so our choices on a diet should not affect theirs.

1229.10518.text: Forcing animals to change their diet based on our morals is ethically wrong because our way of thinking is not as advanced/complex as theirs.

1229.2026.text: Animals do not offer rights to one another. Animals hurt and eat one another.

1229.1534.text: By this logic babies, little children as well as severely mentally disabled people cannot be possessors of rights either. But that would be wrong.

1229.3276.text:
Nonhuman animals are unable to engage in sophisticated moral reasoning. Therefore, nonhuman animals cannot be held to sophisticated moral standards.

Humans on the other hand can engage in sophisticated moral reasoning. Therefore, humans can be held to sophisticated moral standards. This includes standards about how we should or should not behave towards nonhuman animals.

1229.5310.text: Animals can conceptualize morals. Dogs and monkeys, for example, have a concept of fairness. Experiments have been done where two monkeys \(or dogs\) are given different treats for the same trick and those receiving the lesser treat for the same work will become agitated, angry or refuse the treat, even though one bad treat should be better than none.

1229.5617.text: Animals act on instinct and cannot deliberate between actions, therefore they have no moral status. For example, a tiger cannot be made to stand at court for killing a man, neither can a dog. If they can have no regard for human, we cannot have any regard for them. Therefore we can kill animals for food.

1229.5822.text: Humans don't have a moral responsibility to those who they don't think would exhibit the same moral responsibility were they in the same position. You have moral responsibility to a child because they will one day be an adult and you can reasonably expect them to treat you morally. I do not expect cows to have morals besides not being pointlessly sadistic. They would eat me if they could and were hungry, so I feel no qualms about eating them.

1229.6038.text: You are not required to be a moral subject in order to become a moral object. Utilitarism, for instance, is not based on the ability to conceptualise right or wrong but by the ability to feel pain or pleasure.

1229.2125.text: Most humans are more developed than infants or severely disabled people. This does not imply that it is ethically permissible to use infants and severely disabled people for any purpose.

1229.3120.text: Suggesting that humans should have the ability to use animals for their own ends suggests that they haven't developed to a greater extent than other animals.

1229.3659.text: We wouldn't like to be enslaved or killed by a more advanced alien civilization or a much more biologically complex alien species. So we shouldn't do this to animals.

1229.4905.text:
While animals do have some rights, there is no equality between humans and animals, and our behavior to them depends on various criteria such as "is it harmful" or "is it useful". Some animals we try to eradicate, some we keep as pets, some we use for work or we use their wool / milk / meat.
Nobody cares if we kill rodents that carry diseases and affect crops; it's hypocritical to only "protect" the animals that we enjoy eating.

1229.5972.text: Having a higher state of development does not permit humans the right to do any harm whatsoever.

1229.3594.text: Although it is harder to empathize with something you cannot intuitively understand at a glance via biological instincts, this does not mean the other party is not a living being which should have rights - merely that most humans are inherently biased in a specific way.

1229.5879.text: There exist times when beings must make decisions that profoundly impact other beings, even thought the experiences of the affected parties cannot be known on a conscious level.

1229.2031.text: Animals do not conceive of pain and death the same way humans do.

1229.2097.text: Animals from a wide range of species have been shown to experience [emotions](https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animal-emotions/201306/universal-declaration-animal-sentience-no-pretending) including happiness, grief, empathy and jealousy.

1229.2533.text: Sentience is not a sufficient condition for having rights. For example, ants are sentient, but it would be unreasonable to say that they have a right to life.

1229.2542.text: We should grant rights to all sentient beings because there is no consistent way of differentiating between humans \(who have rights\) and other sentient beings.

1229.3244.text: Animals are sentient, but not rational, therefore cannot predict suffering or conceive their fates in slaughter houses. Rights emerge from the prediction of suffering.

1229.5137.text: Animals are not as self aware as humans, so they would not be aware of their coming death until it's already happened. Especially as the methods of doing so are quick and painless.

1229.5597.text:
Non-human animals, just like humans, are sencient and have a conscience. The conscience issue has been stated by '[The Cambridge Declaration on Consciousness](http://fcmconference.org/img/CambridgeDeclarationOnConsciousness.pdf)' issued by a prominent international group of cognitive neuroscientists,
neuropharmacologists, neurophysiologists, neuroanatomists and computational neuroscientists gathered at The University of Cambridge.

1229.6600.text: If we accept the fact that killing humans is wrong, as we are sentient beings, so is the killing of animals wrong as well. It is a clear fact that animals feel pain, join, etc. Some of them live among us as fellows, helpers...so if that's the reality for some that should be for all of them. It would be fair that way.

1229.2536.text: Animals desire to continue existing. This is sufficient to grant them a right to life.

1229.2750.text: With that logic, eating plants, fruits or vegetables also violates their right to life. There is nothing wrong with the occurrence of natural selection and the circle of life.

1229.4815.text: Animals have no rights because they have no obligations.

1229.6716.text: Nature doesn't give animals a right to life. It kills them cruelly and in great numbers.

1229.3612.text: Humans have legal \(and ethical\) obligations with respect to animals, but that doesn't mean animals have reciprocal rights \(they cannot sue, be awarded damages, etc.\). Our obligations to animals exist as a matter of appropriate human behavior, not something that belongs to the animal.

1229.5104.text: The original statement this is responding to was indicating that animals "lack rights".  That is not false.  We do not live in a completely free society, and there are rules and laws which permit and prohibit certain behaviors.  Animals are lacking certain rights- in that humans are given rights which animals are not, such as a dog cannot walk unleashed in public areas.  Contrarily people lack certain rights which animals have, such as dogs being able to defecate in public.

1229.3275.text: By this reasoning, if humans have the right to raise animals, then we also have a corresponding duty of care towards those animals.

1229.3975.text: The claim that animals are not rational beings is debated. This book gives an overview of the different studies on animal rationality and interpretations of the term rationality [philpapers.org](https://philpapers.org/rec/HURRA). Since it is not clear that animals are not rational beings, you cannot just assume their actions lack moral content. And even if their actions lacked moral content to them, this might not be the case for us, as human beings interpreting their behaviour.

1229.4031.text: Humans should not predate other species for the sake of it, only as and when it's out of necessity.

1229.4136.text: No one argued the moral onus to not eat meat was on the animals. We as humans have rights and therefore duties.

1229.5016.text: The claim that animals don't have rights, because rights equate with duty is an outdated one made by Kant, Descartes, and others. We now have greater insight- and more questions- about animal intelligence and the nature of consciousness in general, so can no longer hold these claims as valid arguments.

1229.5470.text: Rights correspond to duties that moral agents have towards the holder of rights, not necessarily duties that the holder of rights has.

1229.5973.text: Rights are based on the ability to suffer, not on the ability to think rationally.

1229.6448.text: By this logic we should be able to eat severely mentally disabled people or the insane, since many of them are incapable of acting with moral content \(which is why they often can not be held criminally liable for their actions\). Clearly that would be immoral. For the same reasons, this argument is flawed.

1229.6691.text: The rights of animals can correspond to the duties of humans, but not to duties of other animals.

1229.10624.text: Rights do not correspond to duties by nature. The definition of rights talks solely about entitlements that are granted to an individual. There are lots of humans \(e.g. mentally disabled people\) that are granted rights without bearing duties. Also "duties" is very vague.

1229.3758.text: If torturing animals is immoral, it follows that it would be logical to create rights for these animals.

1229.5005.text: That logic is used for torturing "terrorists". We created the Geneva convention in order to fight "respectfully". Animals deserve the same if we want to claim moral superiority.

1229.6424.text: No living being should be killed for food when there are other,widely accessible alternatives.

1229.3363.text: Without evidence, it could just as easily be stated that humans also lack free will, leaving all factors equal on this standpoint.

1229.3394.text: As a human, we know that we make choices and we also see each other making choices. Animals, by contrast, mostly seem to be biotic machines, always trying to get the components they need to run, and spread.

1229.4272.text: Many animals have demonstrated free will through play, associations and affections with humans and other animals, and more. Anyone who has owned a cat can attest that animals demonstrate free will; dolphins and primates also frequently exhibit it.

1229.4366.text: Because something lacks 'free will', does not mean it is incapable of suffering.

1229.4963.text: Assuming humans have free will, there's just as much reason to believe some animals do as well. Many of them have highly complex minds and problem-solving ability, crows being a good example. Contrary to popular belief, pigs are also highly intelligent.

1229.6465.text: Speciesism is the ideology that one species is 'better than' another simply because they view their species specific abilities as inherently more valueable than that of another species. Many humans view cognition as the valuable human attribute that raises the value of our species above that of other animals, however, each animal contributes to the health and well-being of the planet in their own unique way, and it is impossible to categorize one characteristic as more valuable than the next.

1229.5660.text: There is no "moral" way to kill an innocent animal who thinks, feels and wants to live — just like humans do.

1229.3593.text: If it were true that there was no difference between humans and animals that allowed humans right animals did not have, it would be unjustifiable to deny animals the right to vote. Not many people are pushing for the full citizenship of gerbils. Therefore, there must exist some characteristic that allows humans rights animals do not have.

1229.4306.text: For any supposed capacity that humans possess and animals lack, and in virtue of which humans but not animals are taken to have rights, some humans will lack that capacity and some animals may possess that capacity. For instance, humans generally have the ability to reason, while most animals lack this capacity. But this cannot be the basis on which humans have and animals lack rights, because certain humans, including young infants, lack the ability to reason and certain animals may have it.

1229.4339.text: Eating animals is like eating "stupid" people. We don't eat "stupid" people. We are not good at assessing intelligence, looking back at human history: complex cultures seeing tribal cultures as stupid & barbaric, believing birds are "stupid" due to the size of their brain \(they can actually use tools\), and believing animals are nothing like humans \(animals show love, empathy, remembers if you have wronged them, etc,\). Just because they don't speak our "language", it shouldn't make them food.

1229.5205.text: Any criteria on which we justify the eating of animals would have to be applied to non-human species right to eat humans.

1229.5637.text: Using the body of someone \(an animal\) against its will is a violation of the right to bodily autonomy; the right not to be used as a means against one's will. To avoid discrimination, everyone who has a will and a perception of their own body, including sentient animals, should get this right.

1229.3088.text: Animals not having recognised legal rights does not mean that killing them is an acceptable or appropriate course of action.

1229.3576.text: This argument begs the question. If a thing should not have rights because it does not have rights than progress is impossible. Slave did not have rights but they should have.

1229.4782.text: It has been argued, primarily by the 'abolitionist vegan,[Gary Francione](https://www.believermag.com/issues/201102/?read=interview_francione), that the one right that all sentient beings process is the right 'not to be owned.'

1229.4783.text: [Dolphins seen as 'non-human' persons by Indian Government](https://io9.gizmodo.com/no-india-did-not-just-grant-dolphins-the-status-of-hum-1149482273) in order to ban their captivity.

1229.5018.text: Throughout history slaves did not have any rights. That does not make slavery moral. Denying people who were slaves their rights was morally corrupt. It is immoral to deny rights to animals- the right to live \(or to not be brought into existence through intensive breeding for the purposes of slaughtering them\), the right not to suffer unnecessarily.

1229.5212.text: Rights are a human construct which do not exist in nature and are not universal across culture, geography or history.  If human's wish to grant or deny rights to animals, or even other humans, they can.

1229.5489.text: Does this apply to humans? You say animals without rights, rights are bestowed by groups of people from time to time. Slaves have not had 'rights' in the past, does their lack of rights mean they should be farmed for meat?

1229.4788.text: The same arbitrary extension extends to human people. We extend rights to humans as long as they do not pose a threat to arbitrary legal standards. Much of this is fear-based and mistaken - decidedly amoral. Right and Wrong is a moral argument, not a legal argument.

1229.4876.text: As living beings, animals should have rights if other living beings of similar traits are given rights, unless a meaningful distinction can be made.

1229.6732.text: We have very limited knowledge of the mental state of animals. We can only make observations, not irrefutable judgements on their inner mental states.

1229.5154.text:
The consumption of prey animals by humans is significantly more humane in comparison to how these creatures are hunted and ripped apart in the wild by their natural predators.

Refusing to eat meat does NOT prevent brutal, bloody or painful animal death.  Human consumption of meat in fact reduces that pain and suffering by ensuring the creatures are clean, healthy and unspoiled before being humanely killed for later consumption.

1229.6037.text: Beeing kept in narrow spaces and very likely has a negative utilitarian value. The utilitarian value of nonexistence is neutral. Since the animals we eat exist specifically for this purpose, not eating meat would lead to a neutral utilitarian value instead of a negative value.

1229.6049.text: Life has a high amount of value in utilitarian terms because prematurely dying means not being able to experience the positive emotions you would otherwise. The prematurely short lives of animals raised just to maturity for meat is probably a larger utility loss than how they end up dying.

1229.6731.text: Utilitarianism is not the most valid measure of moral value. Often, principles such as "killing is wrong" are considered to be a moral law despite the fact that this may lead to higher level of happiness.

1229.6877.text: This is a mischaracterisation of the history of philosophy; the understanding of fundamental or natural rights that we are referring to when we talk about rights in a modern context has been connected with a belief that all humans have the same rights since [the concept began](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_and_legal_rights#Ancient) with the Stoics.

1229.6941.text: While that might be the case within humanity as a group one can't apply the same standards for a different species entirely.

1229.10622.text: This is just a [common belief fallacy](https://bigthink.com/experts-corner/the-common-belief-fallacy). A belief is not true simply because a lot of people hold it.

1229.10642.text: Ethics should not be based on beliefs that aren't falsifiable. Until religious people can prove that non-human animals don't have souls \(which they likely can't\), and can effectively argue that lack of a soul permits us to kill non-human animals, then this statement carries no weight.

1229.10638.text: There is no reason look to animals and plants for moral guidance with regards to eating animals, when we would never do that with regards to any other ethical dilemma.

1229.983.text: It is not difficult to replace meat with non-meat products that taste similar.

1229.2374.text: Companies such as [Impossible Foods](https://www.impossiblefoods.com/burger/) and [Beyond Meat](http://beyondmeat.com/products/view/beyond-burger) are gaining momentum all the time elsewhere in the world as well, with the former opening its first large-scale production plant and the latter being sold in WholeFoods across the USA. Reviews of their products so far are very positive, with a 'meat-centric' celebrity chef [debuting the Impossible Burger](http://www.detroitnews.com/story/entertainment/dining/2017/09/15/michael-symon-debuts-plant-based-impossible-burger-royal-oak/105637090/) at one of his restaurants.

1229.3673.text: Soy in particular but also other legumes, pulses and grains contain varying amounts of phytoestrogens. There is ongoing debate as to whether they can be consumed in quantity by males without undesirable side effects such as reduction in the production of male hormones and increasing feminisation.

1229.6743.text: Lab-grown meat is predicted to be on-offer in a restaurant within a few years. Inasmuch as the normalization of lab-grown meat lowers the bar for eating non-animal meat—thereby exerting pressure on animal-meat eaters \(all else equal\)—and inasmuch as quantified, aggregated predictions serve as evidence for the likelihood of an event, a prediction \([like this one](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/395/a-restaurant-serving-cultured-meat-by-2021/)\) that a restaurant will serve cultured meat by 2021 supports the "Eating Meat is Wrong" argument.

1229.3460.text: This addresses the economic question of eating meat, but not the question of whether eating meat is moral or not.

1229.2600.text: There has been reluctance among meat eaters to try other alternatives. Recent advancements in non-meat alternatives, combined with recipes etc. at our fingertips, could open people up to other ways of eating, if tried.

1229.3321.text: Increasing numbers of people are taking up vegetarianism and veganism.

1229.3322.text: There are reasons beyond the taste and pleasure for why people continue to eat meat - authorities suggesting it \(whether parents in childhood or dieticians/dietary specialists/diet-writers\), the social acceptance of and ease of access to meat, encouragement from others to eat meat, other social factors, etc.

1229.5939.text: This is because vegetarians still like the [taste of meat](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/ed-coffin/why-do-vegans-eat-fake-me_b_3543316.html), despite being aware of the consequences.

1229.3771.text: As technology advances and production scales up, they will become more affordable and available.

1229.3766.text: Lab grown meat is not absolutely and objectively preferable to animal meat.

1229.6231.text: Long term studies must be done to evaluate the health impact of regular consumption of lab grown meat before it is considered a viable alternative.

1229.6232.text: If lab-grown animal protein analogues are an acceptable resolution to the problem of eating meat, it follows that the quarrel is not strictly with eating meat but with some secondary consequence of it.

1229.10557.text: At the end of 2018, there was a worldwide total of 27 companies developing cell-based meat and seafood products, of which 15 have already raised external funding \([p. 5](https://www.gfi.org/non-cms-pages/splash-sites/soi-reports/files/SOI-Report-Cell-Based.pdf)\).

1229.5944.text: The production of artificial meat still costs too much energy. [7-45% less energy cost](https://phys.org/news/2011-06-lab-grown-meat-emissions-energy.html) will not be a viable solution for the growing meat demand in the world.

1229.4827.text: The fact that meat has little to no taste can be refuted by anyone who has already tasted meat directly from the producer with no spices or other additives.

1229.5105.text: Broths from meat are often used to season foods or as a base for foods.  For example, some soups may start with a chicken broth because it has a better taste than just using water.

1229.6012.text: In vegetarian cultures like for example Indian Jainism eating meat is regarded as being far less pleasurable, rather vulgar and less refined than a vegetarian meal prepared with the proper skills.

1229.230.text: Many "classic" dishes - such as pizza, pasta, sushi, gratins or potato bake - can easily be made without meat.

1229.353.text: Even in a steakhouse/churrascaria you will be able to order meatless sides such as green beans, a salad or a variety of sides based on potatos.

1229.655.text: Even food chains like McDonald's offer meatless products such as french fries or a dedicated veggie burger.

1229.2004.text: If more humans stop eating meat entirely, there will be a greater incentive for restaurants and supermarkets to develop a broader range of vegetarian food options.

1229.635.text: Tomatoes are [healthier](http://www.news.cornell.edu/stories/2002/04/cooking-tomatoes-boosts-disease-fighting-power) when they are processed with heat.

1229.640.text: Some veggies, including broccoli, are even [healthier](http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/raw-veggies-are-healthier/) raw rather than cooked.

1229.667.text: In certain cases meat can be eaten raw.

1229.672.text: Quite a few vegetables need cooking as well.

1229.677.text: All salad vegetables can be consumed raw.

1229.865.text: You do not need cutlery/crockery to consume those.

1229.879.text: So are most kinds of fruits without a hard shell \(such as bananas, apples, oranges, grapes etc.\) and you do not even produce plastic-waste by consuming them to-go. Plus they are healthy as well.

1229.1472.text: Processed products on the basis of meat substitutes \(soy sausages etc.\) are comparably easy to consume.

1229.1474.text: If people were to act only based upon convenience, this would lead to a wide neglect of dutiful and/or moral behaviour \(e.g. going to work, recycling garbage etc.\)

1229.1470.text: You do not necessarily need time to cook if you are a vegetarian. Most fruits and vegetables can be consumed in their raw state or with little preparation.

1229.1471.text: Not having time to cook as a meateater is even more difficult, as meat generally \(with only very few exceptions\) has to be prepared.

1229.2527.text: It is only difficult to stay on a meatless diet because meat is so ubiquitous under the status quo. If less people ate meat, more vegetarian options would become available.

1229.78.text: As the production of meat is more expensive than a vegetarian based food industry, the market price of meatless foods is by logic cheaper.

1229.205.text: Unprocessed vegetarian products, which can be used as meat replacements, are cheaper than meat itself.

1229.180.text: The [most expensive](http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/92/5/1181.long) element of American food servings are animal products such as meats and poultry.

1229.179.text: According to [one study](http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/19320248.2015.1045675?journalCode=when20&), a vegetarian meal plan can be cheaper than a meat-based meal plan with the same nutritional value and impact on chronic disease risk.

1229.384.text: Since [1978](http://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/20/whats-wrong-with-this-chart/?mtrref=undefined&gwh=57859188BBA6F6C85580BF7D06FEB4CA&gwt=pay) the price for fresh fruits and vegetables has been rising, while the price for meat is declining.

1229.2339.text: Since people still choose to eat meat despite the relatively higher price, this indicates that eating meat is very pleasurable for them.

1229.2526.text: It is not plausible for some people to live solely on a diet without meats. The reason it would be impossible at the current moment is that the pricing of fruits and vegetables [costs more per calorie](https://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/12/05/a-high-price-for-healthy-food/) than meat and is not possible for many families with a lower budget.

1229.3839.text: Meat is often cheaper and easier to store for low-income households

1229.5529.text: Meat is so expensive that the [world's most expensive food comes from an animal](http://www.businessinsider.com/most-valuable-substances-by-weight-2014-9/#19-white-truffles-1).

1229.1976.text: "Getting bored" with available food options may be a result of a lack of cooking skills, rather than specifically related to being vegetarian.

1229.2591.text: Focusing on having meat as the central part of your diet limits your overall food options, since other non-meat alternatives, many richer in nutrients, in a variety of plant based products are overlooked as possible main courses.

1229.3270.text: Many moral life choices are difficult, and many immoral life choices are easy. The difficulty or ease of a choice has very little bearing on the morality of that choice.

1229.4849.text: Just because other sources of pleasure are rare or stigmatized, does not mean it becomes ethical to indulge in morally questionable sources of pleasure.

1229.5151.text: The concepts of right and wrong change as society changes. This changes are made possible by people who think differently to the majority

1229.5648.text: This is a typical example of [argumentum ad populum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentum_ad_populum), which is a logical fallacy.

1229.10659.text: Democratic countries, which are founded on principles of fairness that are maintained by a popular majority vote, regularly pass laws about the production, handling, and consumption of meat that are influenced by what most pleases their citizens.

1229.1806.text: Human pleasure evaporates quickly while an animal life is lost forever. These after effects make an animal life worth more.

1229.4190.text: While human pleasures are temporary and often secondary to other experiences, animal suffering and death is always salient and permanent.

1229.934.text: While the flower has no other option than growing out of the seed and becoming only one specific flower \(a proper watering, etc. assumed\) humans have a broader variety to decide what kind of human being they want to become.

1229.1307.text: That indicates that evolution would stop now and humans are standing at the peak of their development. But humans have [not stopped evolving](http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/no-humans-have-not-stopped-evolving/). Therefore every state of human development is natural - in the past, now and in the future.

1229.138.text: Sexual intercourse was naturally meant as a means of reproduction. But humans have managed to invent a variety of safe sex methods and even birth control.

1229.246.text: Humans in industrial nations have overcome the "hunting" part of stone-age culture; there is no reason why they should not outgrow the "consumption of meat" part as well.

1229.2592.text: It was once deemed natural to eat with one's bare hands, but humans went on to invent utensils to eat instead.

1229.3098.text: There are many things that are currently or were once considered "natural" that humans have ceased doing or have put limits on. For example, sex is natural yet there are obvious legal and cultural restrictions surrounding who, when, where, and how we can have sex. It is in human nature to hurt and kill each other, yet it is is illegal and immoral to do so in 99% of these instances. Wearing clothing is not natural, yet we do so. Bottom line: Culture, nature, and morality are often in conflict.

1229.1589.text: Our ancestors equally raped and pillaged - yet this is generally not seen as natural behavior. What counts as natural is thus a social construction.

1229.2594.text: [Scientists](http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/08/519048010/some-neanderthals-were-vegetarian-and-they-likely-kissed-our-human-ancestors) have predominantly found traces of meat on neanderthals' teeth, proving they had a meat-heavy diet.

1229.3240.text: A definition is a meaning attributed to something by humans, so must be a construct as such. Definitions for abstract things, such as "natural", are thus surely nothing more than arbitrarily delineated human constructs and are indeed subject to change over time.

1229.6416.text: The human body is not a social construct, it is a biological construct. The digestive system is not designed to eat a fibrous diet, it is designed to eat meat. [Nutrition and Degeneration by Weston A Price - the study of indigenous eating habits](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/544354.Nutrition_and_Physical_Degeneration)

1229.4303.text: Canines have nothing to do with us being carnivorous. Almost all mammals have them, herbivourous or not.

1229.4305.text: We have the ability to make tools to hunt. The same thing that makes someone capable of making tools - a greater capacity for abstract and logical thinking - can also make them capable of getting enough sustenance without consuming meat.

1229.3364.text: As the end of the article admits, the past has no bearing on how our future development should continue.

1229.3708.text:
The brain requires 20 percent of a human’s energy when resting; by comparison, an ape’s brain requires only 8 percent. This means that from the time of H. erectus, the human body has depended on a diet of energy-dense food—especially meat. 

[www.nationalgeographic.com](https://www.nationalgeographic.com/foodfeatures/evolution-of-diet/)

1229.5056.text:
There are [very serious concerns about the mental](https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animals-and-us/201512/how-scary-are-the-mental-health-risks-vegetarianism) as well as the[physical risks of vegetarianism.](http://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/vegetarians-are-less-healthy-and-have-a-lower-quality-of-life-than-meat-eaters-scientists-say-9236340.html) 

[Fish are particularly important for our health](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1753-4887.2010.00287.x/full). That is true not only for the body, but [even more so for brain health.](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2484683)

1229.1654.text: This is also an important skill to run away from carnivores.

1229.1130.text: The evolutionary physiology of human hands [has been linked](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1571064/) to the use of tools with the specific use of hunting.

1229.1131.text: The comparatively large size of the human brain [has been linked](http://press.princeton.edu/titles/6549.html) to the necessities of hunting, for example in terms of social organization.

1229.2848.text: Humans have unparalleled ability to mitigate heat.[ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nlmcatalog/101587029)

1229.3704.text: Compared to animals of similar size humans are among the slowest runners, thus rendering them unable to catch prey.

1229.3705.text: Humans lack natural weapons \(such as claws\) to kill a prey animal once caught.

1229.729.text: Unlike humans, other animals do not overproduce/overhunt and throw away most of their food.

1229.2983.text: It might be easier to gather a plant, but it is not easier to plant than to hunt. Taking into consideration that this involves a nuanced understanding of farming, having to plant, water, cultivate and wait, planting and eating only plants is not an option if you are starving. Hunting could potentially take minutes/hours, whereas farming involves constant attention over months.

1229.6168.text: From experience in the bush, it is easier and more efficient to get your daily needs for nutrition by hunting and eating animals than it is by gathering plants. Therefore I would argue that our ancestors met their caloric needs primarily through animal consumption.

1229.4064.text: Biologically speaking, the human dentition provides information on the proportions of different types of food we should be ingesting, and 1/8 of it should be meat \(4 canines out of 32 teeth\).

1229.3779.text: Who we become is based on our decisions from today. Historical practices have been successfully abandoned without unduly negatively affecting society.

1229.5332.text: A specific mode of nutrition is no tradition; otherwise, all living beings have traditions. Rather, it is a naturally \(evolutionary\) developed way of behavior. Therefore, this is no appeal to tradition but an appeal to our nature.

1229.285.text: Humans' canines are not specially meant for processing meat. All carnivores in comparison - dogs, cats, lions etc. - have [carnassial teeth](http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2016/05/19/478645426/humans-are-meathooked-but-not-designed-for-meat-eating) at the back of their mouths, "blade-like and sharp and perfect for slicing meat".

1229.587.text: Meat-eating animals have no skin pores and [perspire](http://www.celestialhealing.net/physicalveg3.htm) through the tongue, whereas herbivores perspire through skin pores. Humans perspire through their skin pores.

1229.588.text: Meat-eating animals have an [intestinal tract](http://www.celestialhealing.net/physicalveg3.htm) that is only 3 times their body length, so that rapidly decaying meat can pass through quickly, whereas herbivores have an intestinal tract 10-12 times their body length. Humans have an intestinal tract 10-12 times their body length, to allow [slower digestion](http://www.adaptt.org/Mills%20The%20Comparative%20Anatomy%20of%20Eating1.pdf) of plants.

1229.589.text: Meat-eating animals, including humans, have [more acidic stomachs](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4519257/) to digest meat than herbivores.

1229.591.text: Whereas carnivores have acid saliva with no enzyme [ptyalin](http://www.celestialhealing.net/physicalveg3.htm) \(needed to pre-digest grains\), herbivores have alkaline saliva with ptyalin. Humans have alkaline saliva with ptyalin to pre-digest grains.

1229.592.text: Humans, like herbivores, lack the sharp [claws](http://www.celestialhealing.net/physicalveg3.htm) of a carnivorous predator, used to hunt down and kill prey.

1229.600.text: While correct, this observation does not imply a prescription. Humans do not restrict themselves to activities that their bodies are optimized to do, but rather perform a whole range of activities, that the human body is not naturally meant for.

1229.605.text: Humans are physically created to build and use advanced tools - and [they need them](https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=7bdqAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT93&lpg=PT93&dq=%22Humans+can+grip+this+way+because+we+have+relatively+long+thumbs%22&source=bl&ots=dXitibmPmL&sig=iWCVFMrC88fDW6vD6OmztyuaVDY&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwim1eCGx_nMAhWHFJQKHSxiAfgQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=%22Humans%20can%20grip%20this%20way%20because%20we%20have%20relatively%20long%20thumbs%22&f=false). Hence it is only natural for us to overcome our bodies' limitations by using tools such as knives and forks.

1229.911.text: Adaptation to new circumstances and opportunities is a hallmark of evolution, and thus nature in action. A changing diet that overcomes the physical adaptation to a previous diet is thus natural.

1229.1065.text: That humans' anatomy enables them to stand upright allows for other hunting methods that do not require typical predator anatomy.

1229.96.text: The liver of a carnivore can [detoxify](http://www.adaptt.org/Mills%20The%20Comparative%20Anatomy%20of%20Eating1.pdf) the excess vitamin A absorbed from a meat-based diet. The human liver cannot detoxify excess vitamin A.

1229.1168.text: What is natural can be derived. Organisms' anatomy and physiology are good indicators for the kind of lifestyle they have adapted to - even though this does not preclude the possibility that an "un-natural" lifestyle is established.

1229.2779.text: Of all the anthropoid apes, man's teeth and digestive system most closely resembles the chimpanzees, gibbons, gorillas and orangutans. In captivity some of these animals will eat meat if starved, but in the [wild all eat a vegetarian diet.](https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/human-ancestors-were-nearly-all-vegetarians/)

1229.2720.text: Studying evolution, science and data gives a different perspective. We don't have the sharp teeth, claws or short intestinal track of carnivores. Also, our closest animal relatives are chimpanzees and bonobos which have an almost exclusively plant based diet \(less than 2% insects and animals\).

1229.6319.text: Humans aren't very successful at eating vegetables either \(as compare to, say, a cow\). These are the pains of being omnivores, and mean that humans cannot concentrate on only one kind of food. Thus, meat is an essential part of our diet. See [www.livescience.com](https://www.livescience.com/32435-why-cant-humans-eat-grass.html).

1229.6415.text: Human's digestive system is designed to eat meat therefore eating meat is fundamental to good health. [For more information here is a detailed study by Dr Weston A Price on nutrition](https://healthwyze.org/archive/nutrition_and_physical_degeneration_doctor_weston_a_price.pdf)

1229.10667.text: Humans are for example able [to outrun every animal in long enough distance](http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/sports_nut/2012/06/long_distance_running_and_evolution_why_humans_can_outrun_horses_but_can_t_jump_higher_than_cats_.html)(Thus, they probably obtained meat mainly via “persistence hunting”—chasing an antelope, for instance, until it was nearly keeling over with heat exhaustion—and scavenging. The latter was very much a running game: When distant, circling vultures tipped them off about a lion kill, they had to get there before hyenas, which strip everything edible from carcasses. And they typically could only outrace hyenas in the hot sun. As a result, they carved out a new carnivore niche: the hot-day meat chaser.), which is likely to have been an advantage over other predators when hunting.

1229.1271.text: Only through the development and wide-spread use of medical inventions, such as vaccinations, was it possible to protect humans from or even eradicate various naturally occurring infectious diseases.

1229.1512.text: A more natural lifestyle causes fewer interruptions to the functioning of our body, such as those caused by additives to beauty articles like [deodorant](http://www.realpurity.com/blog/top-4-benefits-of-natural-living/).

1229.1282.text: Human bodies are [not optimized](http://mashable.com/2012/06/18/too-much-sitting/#c_tWEkpkPEqU) for prolonged sitting, as it puts a strain on the spine and surrounding muscles, leading to [widespread](http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/25/health/25consumer.html) chronic problems. A more natural lifestyle would reduce these issues for humans.

1229.10630.text: Some natural things may be more healthy/moral compared to unnatural things. Yet that does not necessarily mean that eating meat falls within this category.

1229.3405.text: We do not still use bone tools. The opening statement is not "we should never have eaten meat", but "we should stop now".

1229.1486.text: When humans left Africa and lived in snowy, glaciated Europe about 250,000 years ago, there were no insects to eat, they were [forced to abandon](https://askentomologists.com/2015/02/11/journey-through-time/) it. It was not an aware and intentionally made decision compared to stop eating meat nowadays.

1229.2138.text: Even if some humans choose not to eat insects, doing so is still ethical because it is part of human nature.

1229.3745.text: In general, people do not find these substances to be tasty in the same way as food, \(see: flavored tobacco, mike's hard lemonade\) rather, they enjoy the effect that these substances have on them.

1229.4015.text: People also find foods high in fat and sugar tasty, but this 'natural tendency' of ours is causing rising numbers in ilnesses, such as diabetes. The fact something is tasty, does not mean it is generally good for us. The same goes for foods filled with artificial flavours. They generally taste good, but might not provide us with the right nutrients.

1229.171.text: Cutlery is useful, but not strictly necessary to eat food. We could instead use our fingers.

1229.3746.text: We crave high calorie foods, in particular, foods with high sugar and salt content. [businessinsider.com](http://www.businessinsider.com/evolutionary-reason-we-love-sugar-2014-4) These resources were rare and beneficial to survival

1229.3833.text: That humans are designed to enjoy food that is good for you comes from a time when humans needed a completely different diet and high protein or energy foods were scare. For example, Oreos are delicious but not necessarily good for ones diet.

1229.3862.text: Rape is morally abhorrent, but still physically pleasurable for the perpetrator.

1229.4750.text: There is no data to suggest that the thought of animal suffering accompanies the taste of meat.

1229.3924.text: The term "delicious" is subjective – what is tasty to one person may be disgusting to the next.

1229.5499.text: People who are incapable of deriving pleasure from meat consumption can voluntarily stop eating meat. But there are many people who enjoy meat consumption despite this fact.

1229.10690.text: Dishes based on [tofu](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/what-is-tofu), a common meat substitute, are also protein-dense.

1229.3295.text: Calorie intake is not the only measure of agricultural productivity; factors like nutrient content matter as well.

1229.10766.text: It's more like [6 pounds](https://www.noble.org/news/publications/ag-news-and-views/2011/february/the-efficiency-of-beef-production/) to produce one pound of beef. But ruminants can eat plants that humans cannot. Like waste or grassland that doesn't support growing other crops.

1229.2281.text: Growing food exclusively for direct human consumption, rather than using some of it for animal feed, could increase available food calories by [as much as 70%](http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/8/3/034015/meta;jsessionid=BE048803E5C08313A3954052670EAB15.ip-10-40-1-105), which could feed an additional 4 billion people.

1229.2285.text: 36% of the calories produced by the world's crops are being used for animal feed, of which [only 12%](http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/8/3/034015/meta;jsessionid=BE048803E5C08313A3954052670EAB15.ip-10-40-1-105) then turn into animal products that can be eaten by the human population. That is a waste of 24% of the world's crops.

1229.1439.text: Corn is commonly used as a feed grain in [beef cattle](https://www.ag.ndsu.edu/publications/livestock/feeding-corn-to-beef-cattle) diets. Only [11%](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corn_production_in_the_United_States#Production) of the total US corn production for 2013-14 was directly made into food for the US market, compared with 33% for livestock feed.

1229.82.text: Soybeans, predominantly in the form of soybean meal, are a major ingredient in global livestock [feed](http://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/footprint/agriculture/soy/facts/), especially for chickens, pigs and cattle.

1229.2806.text: The solution isn't to stop eating meat, but rather to eat meat that has not been grain-fed \(or fed on other potential human food-sources\).

1229.3049.text: Inedible byproducts of existing plant-based food production \(e.g. soybean pods\) can be used to feed livestock.

1229.5908.text: The livestock industry relies heavily on grains and oilseeds. The growing world population can not be fed if we keep using land for the production of feed for animals. [tandfonline.com](http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03066150.2012.752357)

1229.3927.text: Provided the water use itself does not disrupt the water cycle of flowing from mountains to seas or lakes, such use would be reasonably acceptable. In addition, there must be a lot more benefits from that endeavor than just letting the water just flow right away.

1229.4027.text: There is not enough land available for grazing to support our current demands for meat. Switching Western/modernized countries back to "free range" practices would require a dramatic reduction in meat consumption.

1229.4701.text: If all the grains used to feed farm animals were instead used for human consumption many people who are' starving' around the world could have a better diet.

1229.683.text: Raising livestock accounts for roughly 23% of all [global water use](http://www.worldwatch.org/global-meat-production-and-consumption-continue-rise-1) in agriculture, equivalent to 1.15 liters of water per person per day.

1229.244.text: According to the Worldwatch Institute, "As populations grow, lowering meat consumption worldwide will allow more efficient use of declining per capita land and water resources, while at the same time making grain [more affordable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegetarianism#Economics_and_diet) to the world's chronically hungry."

1229.447.text: According to a [United Nations initiative](http://www.fao.org/docrep/010/a0701e/a0701e00.HTM), the livestock industry is one of the largest contributors to environmental degradation worldwide, and modern practices of raising animals for food contribute on a "massive scale" to air and water pollution, land degradation, climate change, and loss of biodiversity.

1229.48.text: The livestock sector is contributing to [eutrophication](http://www.europarl.europa.eu/climatechange/doc/FAO%20report%20executive%20summary.pdf).

1229.47.text: The livestock sector is probably the largest source of [water pollution](http://www.europarl.europa.eu/climatechange/doc/FAO%20report%20executive%20summary.pdf) \(due to animal wastes, fertilizers, and pesticides\).

1229.2553.text: [Widespread overgrazing](http://www.fao.org/newsroom/en/news/2006/1000448/index.html) disturbs water cycles, reducing replenishment of above and below ground water resources.

1229.2872.text: This applies to concentrated industrial operations. It does not apply to organic permaculture or intensive grazing practices.

1229.2166.text: It takes [100,000](http://news.cornell.edu/stories/1997/08/us-could-feed-800-million-people-grain-livestock-eat) liters of water to produce one kilogram of grain-fed beef.

1229.6042.text: Marginal land that can't efficiently produce more than just forages can be used for feeding animals. At the same time, the manure from the animals can be used to return nutrients to the soil.

1229.10562.text: While this may be true, the end product is more [calorie-dense](https://www.livestrong.com/article/547226-which-gives-you-more-energy-meat-or-vegetables/) in animal products than in plant products, making it a more efficient energy source to consume and thus meaning that less of it is needed.

1229.2168.text: It is estimated that global vegetarianism would free up [2.8 billion](http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/five-things-would-happen-if-everyone-stopped-eating-meat-a6844811.html) hectares of land.

1229.2169.text: About [70%](http://www.worldwatch.org/peak-meat-production-strains-land-and-water-resources-1) of the world's agricultural land is used for animal pastures.

1229.2171.text: [About 60%](http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/78/3/660S.full)  of US pasture land suffers from overgrazing, which rapidly erodes the soil and makes it unfit for future agricultural production.

1229.3715.text: The organic manure produced by animals is useful in the growing of crops.

1229.6121.text: Indoor farming innovations have already shown that significantly reducing the footprint of agriculture is possible. [large.stanford.edu](http://large.stanford.edu/courses/2016/ph240/swafford2/docs/banerjee.pdf)

1229.3155.text: Developed nations are fueling the 3rd world and underdeveloped nation's population boom by exporting/donating food to areas that cannot sustain their current population.

1229.3156.text: From an ecological point of view, increased food availability for a given species, globally, results universally in an increase in species population.  Population control can only verifiably and assuredly be effected using those same ecological principles of controlling or capping a food supply to sustain x population at equilibrium or possibly a gentle, gradual rate of decrease.

1229.10610.text: As long as our ability to produce both animal feed crops and food crops for our human population are not exceeded, this point is irrelevant.

1229.2189.text: [Large percentages](https://www.gizmodo.com.au/2015/10/this-is-how-the-world-is-growing-more-food-with-less-land/) of the gains in agricultural output over the last 50 years have been due to increases in the productivity of agriculture.

1229.2186.text: Agricultural productivity per unit of land has [risen drastically](http://Agricultural productivity per unit has risen rapidly) over the past century.

1229.3372.text:
It is possible to act proactively, and thereby avoid or reduce the severity of crises.

Furthermore, other arguments made in this very debate point to ways in which the continued consumption of meat is likely to worsen the crises we may face, as it is an inefficient use of food and farmland, and environmentally damaging.

1229.4219.text: There is not enough farmable land on the planet to meet the nutritional needs of an entire population of vegetarians

1229.3501.text: Solutions to food shortages will need to involve meat production.

1229.5196.text: In many countries people have no choice but to eat meat cause if not they would starve, and their lands do not let plants grow up easily during a year \(e.g. Greenland, Iceland, Sahara\). And to transport vegetables there is quite hard and not affordable for economy.

1229.4897.text: A sizeable portion of land and plant produce is wasted on animal feed.

1229.5522.text: It is estimated that [1.3 billion tons](http://www.fao.org/news/story/en/item/196402/icode/) of food are wasted per year. 28% of the world's agricultural land is used to produce food that is then wasted.

1229.6166.text: Peter Joseph's recent book "The new Human Rights Movement" maintains that the carrying capacity of the planet using vertical farming is 34 trillion. Go 27 minutes into Peter's interview with Abby Martin to hear it in his own words: [www.youtube.com](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X7MOnwLOFOY)

1229.3531.text: We are all humans, and individuals should not be unfairly privileged or disadvantaged due to the circumstances of their birth. Solutions should be implemented for the greatest good of the most humans and other living beings.

1229.4566.text: It can be debated if the first world has "earned" its luxuries, as it is built on a history of exploitation and bloodshed, and has directly or indirectly caused \(and continues to contribute to\) many "third world" problems.

1229.4567.text: It will be beneficial and minimize damage in the short term, buying more time for and reducing the damage of finding long-term solutions.

1229.4568.text: Increasing efficiency of food production may reduce the amount of labour necessary for it, allowing for that labour to be potentially allocated to more progressive jobs.

1229.6207.text: Changing farming to feed a growing world population is only a never-ending treadmill if the population continues to grow. The vast majority of the world's population growth takes place in industrializing nations. Population growth tends to level off in post-industrial nations and although these richer nations often import large amounts of luxury food, most of them are capable of producing all the food they need. As economic development becomes more uniform worldwide, population growth will slow.

1229.6373.text: The statement that there are very few people in the world that starve to death is a gross understatement and incredibly false. Over 9 million people die from starvation per year as calculated in March of 2017. World Hunger is an epidemic.[borgenproject.org](https://borgenproject.org/15-world-hunger-statistics/)

1229.5452.text: As long as meat eaters retain a taste for and willingness to consume meat, there is the danger that they will end up purchasing unethically produced meat.

1229.5624.text: Same is true for alcohol, still most people are not alcoholics and alcohol is not banned in most countries.

1229.5632.text: Moderation being tougher than abstention does not imply that the latter is unfeasible.

1229.5633.text: Moderation stems from discipline, which can be [trained](https://justmind.org/how-to-practice-moderation/).

1229.6914.text: [This study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25453590) found that "\[Conscientious omnivores\] were less likely to perceive their diet as something that they absolutely needed to follow, reported violating their diet more, felt less guilty when doing so and that these differences could in part be traced to practical and psychological factors, making it more difficult to follow conscientious omnivorism."

1229.5240.text: Just because civilization have less civilized ways \(such as eating meat or crime\) does not mean we should accept it. We should instead work on getting rid of these actions.

1229.5799.text: This was a common theme back in the 1960's perpetuated by the book "Population Bomb" in which author reasoned incorrectly that the food supply would not keep up with the then current rate of population growth and everyone would have starved by now. However, because of Norman Borlaug and the "green revolution" that never occurred. Learn more about it in this [video.](http://www.freethinkmedia.com/shows/wrong/1/were-all-gonna-starve/)

1229.3358.text: Waiting for the market to adapt will cause extinctions, and massive food shortages.

1229.3467.text: Food shortages will primarily harm the world's extreme poor, who have very little purchasing power and are unlikely to be able to affect market trends.

1229.3470.text: As long as there are wealthy consumers in high-income countries willing to purchase meat as a luxury good, even food scarcity will not eliminate meat production.

1229.5078.text: In order for this to apply, supply needs to be limited. Right now the amazon rainforest is being cleared to make room for cattle. This is not efficient or sustainable.

1229.5085.text:
[Historical evidence](https://ourworldindata.org/extreme-poverty/) validates this. 200 years ago the world population was under a billion and 95% of humans were living in "absolute poverty". Today we have a global population of 7.2 billion and only 10% of humans are living in absolute poverty. Overpopulation is a myth. It has been disproven time and time again since Thomas Malthus popularized the notion in the 18th century.
More humans = more innovation = less scarcity.

1229.6248.text:
Globally, we currently produce a large food surplus; enough to provide for a growing world-wide population. Oxfam notes that "The world produces 17% more food per person today than 30 years ago." [oxfam.ca](https://www.oxfam.ca/there-enough-food-feed-world)

Undernourishment is therefore a problem of food distribution and waste; not reduced productivity from livestock farming.

1229.3597.text: Many vegan diet staples actually have a bigger impact on the environment and water resources than meat production, such [as almond milk](https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/shortcuts/2015/oct/21/almond-milk-quite-good-for-you-very-bad-for-the-planet).

1229.4014.text: A report by Worldwatch Institute states that animal farming is responsible for [51%](http://www.worldwatch.org/node/6294) of global greenhouse gases.

1229.1881.text: [Researchers](http://www.sciencealert.com/vegetarian-and-healthy-diets-may-actually-be-worse-for-the-environment-study-finds) at Carnegie Mellon University \(CMU\) say that a diet with more fruits, vegetables, dairy and seafood would actually be worse in terms of emissions than what Americans currently eat.

1229.2078.text: Eating a plant-rich diet ranks as the [fourth-most effective way](http://www.drawdown.org/solutions-summary-by-rank) to combat climate change.

1229.4307.text: Vegan diets not only potentially harm our bodies but the majority result in eating imported, high environmental footprint foods, that require massive amounts of crop land. Good livestock husbandry can actually heal and protect land.

1229.4682.text: Transforming into a vegan diet may do very little to reduce climate change as business organisations may simply create artificial products for human consumption that may re-enforce the issue of greenhouse gasses and pollution thereby re-enforcing the issue of climate change rather than ending it and further adding to the poor diet in humans

1229.6775.text: The same source \(now down, reup here: [www.mdpi.com](http://www.mdpi.com/2071-1050/9/9/1550/s1)\) also shows that beef makes the biggest difference. A beefless diet is only marginally worse in terms of GHG emissions than a vegetarian's/vegans diet. Another graphic from the same source \(reup here: [pbs.twimg.com](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B4sAuHGCAAAe3JH.png)\) also showed that the carbon intensity of fruit is actually 20% higher than that of poultry, pork or fish

1229.1152.text: Farming cows and sheep are responsible for 37% of the total [methane](http://www.fao.org/newsroom/en/news/2006/1000448/index.html) generated by human activity.

1229.467.text: Animals produce [methane](http://www.peta.org/issues/animals-used-for-food/meat-environment/) which is bad for the environment.

1229.4087.text: Climate change does not make eating meat inherently wrong. A small population eating anything in sustainable amounts would be the solution to climate change issues. What you're successfully arguing here is actually that overpopulation is wrong.

1229.3872.text: Most animals do not contribute to climate change because their net affect on CO2 and CH4 is zero \(they consume CO2 and CH4 indirectly via the plants that are grown specifically to feed the animals\).

1229.4685.text: Meat needs 10 times more land and water than vegetables. Impacts of changing land use to pastures or gmo-crops \(for livestock feed\) are deforestation and even desertification. This as world tendency decreases de overall biocapacity of environment to neutralize greenhouse emissions.

1229.5381.text: Research shows that livestock actually helps to restore vegetation growth, reverses desertification and with that, helps to store more CO2.[youtube.com](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vpTHi7O66pI)

1229.6019.text: The Haber-Bosch process for the synthesis of nitrogen fertilizer is heavily reliant on natural gas. Its use to produce feedstock means that the methane being gassed off by livestock is directly linked to mined hydrocarbons, not only from atmospheric nitrogen.

1229.6233.text: [This source](https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/sources-greenhouse-gas-emissions) seems to disagree with these numbers.

1229.6740.text: Researchers found out that an addition of 2 percent dried seaweed to a cow’s diet can reduce [methane emissions by 99 percent.](https://foodtank.com/news/2017/06/seaweed-reduce-cow-methane-emission/) As a result, eating meat doesn't need to be stopped in order to effectively fight climate change.

1229.3961.text: And every major industry will have to contribute towards reducing its climate impact, or even become redundant if its products are not worth their indirect costs - like, arguably, meat.

1229.4601.text: Mass production of almost anything negatively impacts the environment. If the public were to demand more fresh meat and food — without all the chemicals on the plants and in the animals — we would go back to smaller family-owned farms and ranches, which would all but eliminate harm to the environment.

1229.6055.text: This is a [fallacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two_wrongs_make_a_right) - two wrongs don't make a right. All the industries that contribute to climate change should be tackled, but that doesn't justify the negative impact that meat industry has on climate change.

1229.3902.text: Reducing meat consumption is not sufficient to overcome this problem. Therefore this argument does not entail a duty to stop meat consumption.

1229.4686.text: As  vegetarian diets have a lesser impact on resources a massive adoption of vegetarian diets would contribute to a massive cut of greenhouse emissions.

1229.4687.text: Overpopulation can't be the only aspect to address green house emissions; response should be focused on life style also, becouse if it's not posible to change life style \(Diet, Housing, Mobility, Consumerism\) the only way posible to reduce emissions would be to reduce population.

1229.4855.text: Whether eating meat is inherently wrong or not, the argument is that we should stop eating it. In the context of the current situation, there is certainly a viable argument to be made that we should stop eating meat to reduce our environmental impact.

1229.6617.text: In order to find a sustainable ecological balance, in order to keep the human species alive, we must find ways of reducing and mitigating our carbon debt to the world. Abstaining from eating animal meat \(even temporarily\) will allow us more time to find solutions to this global problem.

1229.4640.text: The global livestock sector creates [more emissions](http://www.fao.org/newsroom/en/News/2006/1000448/index.html) than the global transport sector.

1229.4641.text: Ruminants from livestock account for [about 6.5%](http://www.wri.org/sites/default/files/Shifting_Diets_for_a_Sustainable_Food_Future_1.pdf) of global greenhouse gas emissions, which is the same as 1/10th of all non-agricultural energy usage.

1229.4642.text: The greenhouse gases generated by large meat companies [almost compare](https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/nov/07/big-meat-big-dairy-carbon-emmissions-exxon-mobil) to those created by large oil companies.

1229.3875.text: Meat and dairy production directly hurts humans as it uses too much land/resources and produces more [greenhouse gases](http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=20772) than driving cars.

1229.4707.text: The overwhelming majority of people however consume agriculturally produced meat. Hunting meat at the scale needed to provide for the world's population is not viable.

1229.4771.text: That's how supply and demand works. By eating as much meat as we do now we are asking meat producers to continue what they are doing. Eating meat does result in more production and more greenhouse gas emissions.

1229.4851.text: Ceasing to eat meat would discourage further production of meat.

1229.6271.text: It does not make sense at all to see eight billion people hunting for their own meal every day.

1229.6452.text: Deflecting the Climate Change argument to argue for personally hunted meat only shifts the argument to the ethics of killing an animal for food, and attempts to detract from the very real environmental consequences of producing meat at a large scale.

1229.4858.text: The consequences of climate change are not limited to a mere slight warming of the globe; knock-on effects could quite possibly lead to the realistically unpreventable extinction of humanity, and severe effects up to and including mass extinctions on other forms of life as we know it, such as through a [global anoxic event.](https://greens.org.au/magazine/national/what-even-global-anoxic-event)

1229.5639.text: Global warming may not be inherently undesirable. As the earth warms, the capacity to produce food increases as land previously too cold for agriculture becomes fertile. While there are costs associated with global warming, some would argue that these are outweighed by the benefits.

1229.6310.text: Humans are one of the most adaptable species on earth, we can live in climates from freezing ice to scorching hot.

1229.6311.text: There are vast uninhabitable cold regions on earth, if the climate changes we will have pleasant new living spaces. Human settlements have followed climate change since the ice age.

1229.6336.text: This is to suggest that climate change is inherently bad. It may actually be of great benefit to many species, and to the Earth as a whole. The climate has fluctuated significantly over the course of Earth's history \(the Ice Age, Paleocene-Eocene period\) and life as we know it has survived, and has even been strengthened by these changes.

1229.5762.text: Plants used to feed those animals often come from intensive agriculture which needs fossil fuels directly or indirectly \(mechanization, fertilizers, pest control\). So there is a significant amount of indirect CO2 emission coming from fossil source.

1229.5770.text: That's just how you define 'league'. The source of the carbon in this case is hardly relevant, it's the transformation from carbon dioxide into methane that is. The carbon in the methane does not even out with the carbon in the carbon dioxide; [methane is a 25 times stronger greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide](https://climatechangeconnection.org/emissions/co2-equivalents/).

1229.6034.text: Eating in ways that are just less bad than the worst contributor do not justify supporting the runner up contributor, it just compounds the issue.

1229.5603.text: A high percentage of Meat is dense and high in moisture its moisture content at the time of its transportation. Its moisture content giving it a shorter shelf-life, and its weight making it more expensive when transported.

1229.5268.text: The facts aren't so simple, as shown in [this study](https://www.sciencealert.com/vegetarian-and-healthy-diets-may-actually-be-worse-for-the-environment-study-finds), switching to a less meat-heavy diet might actually cause emissions and energy consumption to increase rather than decrease. One has to keep in mind that not only the production affects the environment - to get the product from the farm to your nearest store one needs transportation. Vegetables are in general less \(calorie/nutrient\)-dense and therefore you need a bigger volume of them to feed people.

1229.5415.text: Vegetables have a bigger volume but less weight. Additionally when considering the impact of transportation, we can't forget about the requirement for refrigeration of meat products compared to others. As stated, the impact of transportation is not so simple.

1229.6858.text: This could be remedied by electric semis for transportation and powering storage facilites with solar power.

1229.6093.text: Plant matter also does not become 'unsafe' to consume nearly as quickly as any meat product.

1229.6449.text: Livestock takes up 30% of Earth's land surface. Forests, which help absorb C02, are being cleared to create pastures. 70% of the Amazon forest has been cut down for cattle grazing. [timeforchange.org](https://timeforchange.org/are-cows-cause-of-global-warming-meat-methane-CO2)

1229.4473.text: There are ways to reduce the carbon impact of meat.

1229.6228.text: An ethical diet is not one which eliminates greenhouse gas emissions or other forms of harm; if it were, the best diet would be starvation. Instead, an ethical diet strives to balance a variety of goals; health, taste, environmental impact, cultural legacy etc. In that case, a diet which includes some meat \(but perhaps less than a typical diet in a developed country\) would be morally permissible.

1229.6593.text: The amount of land required to produce the same amount of calories is nearly 5 times greater than is required for crops. With a growing population the consumption of meat could come at a detrimental cost. [Yields and Land Use In Agriculture, Our World In Data](https://ourworldindata.org/yields-and-land-use-in-agriculture)

1229.3535.text: Through the consumption of meat that is raised by respecting the nature of ruminant animals we can regenerate land into highly productive prairie and farmland. It has been scientifically proven by the Rodale Institute and other regenerative farmers that ruminant animals and multi-specieated farms can and will regenerate land and help sequester carbon in our soil where it belongs. By mimicking nature we right the wrongs of factory farming and KAFO's.  [rodaleinstitute.org](https://rodaleinstitute.org/our-work/livestock/) [www.resilience.org](http://www.resilience.org/stories/2016-03-15/joel-salatin-the-promise-of-regenerative-farming/)

1229.2201.text: The above claim seems dependent on specific ecosystems.

1229.2490.text: The definition of 'pest' is itself a normative description that privileges human activities; e.g. kangaroos are pests because they eat crops. To hunt and kill them thus serves our own purposes, not any 'natural order.'

1229.2552.text: If it is beneficial to kill pests, then we can do that without needing to eat their meat.

1229.2685.text: Humans, as apex predators who have usurped the predatory apexes of the other predators in the ecosystems we have come to also inhabit, have an ethical responsibility to keep those ecosystems in check so that, eg, rampant deer populations do not cause deforestation and subsequent ecosystem collapse.  Even where there are populations of healthy apex predators, these populations should also be checked so they do not cause problems and kill people- and it would be unethical to waste that meat.

1229.3280.text: The majority of meat consumption is from cows, pigs, chickens, lamb, turkeys, not deer or kangaroo.

1229.3352.text: Insects are numerous and contribute to vegetable crop destruction. Humans could have a large impact on the adverse effects of insects by eating them.

1229.4612.text: The morality of hunting is irrelevant to whether farming is bad for the environment.

1229.6590.text: The context of this argument \(this specific sub-point\) is directly related to farming, not hunting animals. Proposing an argument of benefits of hunting overpopulated animals is a misrepresentation of the argument.

1229.46.text: According to a 2006 [report](http://www.europarl.europa.eu/climatechange/doc/FAO%20report%20executive%20summary.pdf) by LEAD Livestock's Long Shadow, "the livestock sector emerges as one of the top two or three most significant contributors to the most serious environmental problems, at every scale from local to global."

1229.6801.text: A 2007 study concluded that "within the same method of production, a greater consumption of animal products translates to [a greater impact on the environment](https://www.nature.com/articles/1602522#ref33)."

1229.5386.text: Overgrazing and compaction are not inevitable effects of livestock, but of improper management of livestock. compaction is more dependent on the type of soil and climate in which the livestock reside, than it is upon the presence of livestock. Erosion is always happening regardless of the presence of livestock.

1229.441.text: Meat production leads to extensive [conversion](http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/should-humans-eat-meat-excerpt/) of tropical forests to new pastures.

1229.2713.text: Because humans have been farming animals for thousands of years, many of the earths habitats that we hold precious need grazing animals to maintain them as we know them.
