Grazing at the right levels maintains biodiversity and conserves many rare species of butterflies, small flowering plants etc.  If we were to remove all animals, we would also lose all of this.  A balanced approach is required.

1229.51.text: Livestock production is by far the biggest cause of [land use](http://www.europarl.europa.eu/climatechange/doc/FAO%20report%20executive%20summary.pdf), as it accounts for 30% of the global land surface. It is probably the leading player in biodiversity loss, as it causes deforestation, land degradation, pollution, climate change, overfishing, and invasions by alien species.

1229.4207.text: [91%](https://blog.pachamama.org/how-animal-agriculture-affects-our-planet) of Amazon Rainforest deforestation is caused by animal agriculture.

1229.2999.text: [Husbandry](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vpTHi7O66pI) is one of our best bets to solve the problem of desertification.

1229.4817.text: If we drastically shift from our factory farm agriculture mentality we still may be able to remediate damaged land.

1229.6320.text: Farming, just like ranching results in additional deforestation.

1229.6809.text: Agricultural expansion has had and continues to have tremendous negative impact on [habitats](https://theconversation.com/hunting-fishing-and-farming-remain-the-biggest-threats-to-wildlife-63723) and [biodiversity](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0921800917303646), including [species loss](http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2015/08/meat-eaters-may-speed-worldwide-species-extinction-study-warns).

1229.3004.text: Arguments could be made for each of those, and certainly there is a lot of work being done towards sustainable farming, mining, and manufacturing. Cutting meat out of our diets is generally easier than cutting computers out of our lives, so we start by doing what we can.

1229.5408.text: Other wrongdoings don't justify this wrongdoing. We may not be ready to abandon things like mining or tree cutting, but abandoning meat consumption is doable without negative impact in technological advancement.

1229.6583.text: This is a logical fallacy: the fallacy of relative privation. Dismissing an argument or complaint due to the existence of more important problems in the world does not actually address whether those problems bear relevance to the initial argument.

1229.4233.text: Sensibly winding down \(animal\) farming would cause far less ecological damage in the long run than continuing it indefinitely.

1229.4919.text: Many semi-natural habitats have developed on and around livestock and mixed farmland. Removing these habitats would have a negative impact upon the wildlife in these habitats.

1229.6054.text: We do not need to "release farm animals into the wild", but could create sanctuaries for them in places where they previously lived until their natural death would occur. Not only would that create jobs for those people transitioning from meat-industry jobs, but would also help make the whole transition easier for animals and humans.

1229.6361.text: Animals not being used for meat could lead to overpopulation of animals. Overpopulation of animals leads to other issues for animals. The article linked points out how animal overpopulation harms the animals [Why Animal Overpopulation is Harmful for Animals](https://sciencing.com/effects-animal-overpopulation-8249633.html)

1229.2666.text: Industrial, monoculture based, factory farmed meat is indeed bad in many ways. However, it represents only one failed model of agriculture. [Permaculture based farming](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s13412-015-0254-8) with strategic rotational grazing programs, have been shown to create many positive and vital ecological outcomes as well as improved ethics. Meat production, done in this manner, provides a very real and powerful tool in battling climate change, erosion, pollination and habitat loss, loss of bio diversity, and lack of soil health.

1229.3196.text: The problem is not meat eating, but agriculture. Growing corn, soy and wheat is incredibly destructive to our environment, to the soil. Nature's only sustainable food supply is herbivores on grasslands. The herbivore stimulates grass. The grass sequesters carbon. The meat of the herbivore is nutrient dense. Human beings participated in this natural cycle for 2 million years before the industrial revolution.

1229.2686.text: Farming plants often has a similarly severe environmental impact. Humans no longer live in an agrarian culture where every family can farm for their own sustenance, so this ecological impact is a function of human civilization itself, not our choice of diet between plants and animals specifically.

1229.3829.text: Meat animals can convert byproducts and waste that are not valuable for food into something humans can eat.

1229.3413.text: Not if done responsibly and with a particular focus on agricultural sustainability. If real farmers can take back the market from big-farma and work cohesively and symbiotically this is a very plausible potential.

1229.4218.text: The increasing demand for vegetables is causing deforestation in places like South America and Africa[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forest_farming)

1229.3031.text: The vegetable products used to create "fake" meat protein are typically soy and wheat-based, contributing to the threat that exists due to agricultural monoculture.

1229.2842.text: Feeding the planet on a vegetarian diet alone involves a heavy reliance on industrial monocrop agriculture.  Monocultural farms are more harmful to the environment than polycultural farms that grow a mix of plants and animals in a way that mirrors the natural ecosystem.  Polycultural farms only achieve the necessary output levels when you include the animal calories.  In terms of net animal life death, these polycultural farms cause lower loss of animal life than industrial monocultures.

1229.2669.text: This argument is highly dependent on "how" we raise animals. Many of the arguments in this thread are based on one small understanding of one single model of farming \(monocultural based industrial farming\). But there are other, more ecologically and productive models of raising meat. If we stay on course, your argument holds up. But if we shift to more permaculture based models of farming it does not.

1229.4340.text: Animal agriculture contributes to an environmentally, socially and financially balanced agricultural system, with mixed feed and food crops, nutritionally diverse diets, reduced inputs and closed nutrient cycles, and a balance of operating risk from diversification.

1229.4593.text: These same monocultural practices are also used to produce food for animals, thus creating a double impact. Cutting one half of this double impact would still reduce its impact.

1229.4780.text: The recycling of animal manures is an essential part of growing crops. The removal of this sorce of natural fertilizer would have a detrimental effect economically and environmentally on crop production and it would leave us totally dependent on artificial fertilisers.

1229.3904.text: In harsh climates of the world, the transport and storage of fresh fruits and vegetables could cause ecological consequences that outweigh the benefits of ceasing local livestock production.

1229.4292.text: More advanced farming methods allow previously unusable land to be utilized.

1229.4266.text: Not all land is good for planting human food, you need pastures. With pastures you can get herbivores to eat unedibe grass and transform it into eat into edible meat

1229.3107.text: Grasslands and plains make great areas to raise livestock but bad areas for farming due to lack of water or soil nutrients.

1229.2007.text: Farmers often rely on grazing animals to collect energy from a tropic level that cannot be accessed by humans. The meat gained from these animals has minimal costs to the environment yet is productive.

1229.1964.text: Village farmers often rely on their animals to store energy for their consumption over the winter or over dry seasons when harvests are poor.

1229.1999.text: Not all forms of terrain support intensive vegetable farming because the soil is poor, or the terrain too steep. Keeping animals in these areas displaces the need to raze new land for agricultural use.

1229.4820.text: Farming plants utterly destroys the environment. About 15% of the USA has been cleared, razed to dust, plowed, and replaced with planted crops. The damage to the environment is the total destruction of native plants and massive disruption of native fauna. Grazing is much less destructive. Concentrated feed lots use a negligible area by comparison. \(but depend on planted crops, the analysis of the problem is just not simple\).

1229.2879.text: We can raise animals in terrain that we cannot raise vegetables or grain. Areas such as steep slopes and high mountain sides can be successfully grazed in a sustainable, ecological way, but cannot be used for growing vegetables or grains without energy intensive and destructive modifications.

1229.4550.text: Responsible ruminant herd grazing programs actively combat desertification, which provides meat eaters a tertiary motivation to preserve green space.

1229.4560.text: Many natural rangelands are low-investment nutritional resources which can only be made useful to humans by using them to raise livestock.

1229.6066.text: There is [far less land](https://www.onegreenplanet.org/animalsandnature/facts-on-animal-farming-and-the-environment/) where only and exclusively livestock can be raised than there is agricultural land where plant foods can grow. If we, therefore, use the land that was previously used for livestock to produce crops, we won't feel the need to even use those remote lands where only livestock can be fed.

1229.6067.text: There are new [methods](http://www.bbc.com/future/sponsored/story/20170227-remote-control-farming) of farming \([hydroponics](https://bigpictureeducation.com/hydroponics-and-future-farming), etc\) that allow us to grow crops indoors or on the land where there was previously nothing at all, or just livestock.

1229.6077.text: Some level of animal husbandry is an integral part of a farm's nutrients cycle: from grass, to manure, to fertilizer. In alpine regions, where no crops grow, animals do not only increase the efficiency of the land but often are the most efficient way to use it to produce food. Thus, based on these two reasons, there is a justified level of animal husbandry \(which is far below current level\).

1229.4249.text: The "natural balance" was never stable, extinctions are as natural as the emergence of new species. Evolution is an ongoing process. It can be argued what the correct and moral action is for humans in any given situation, but species have been interfering with each other and forcing evolution since the beginnings of life.

1229.4563.text: Environmental damage can cause harm and suffering to both humans and other forms of life - [up to and including mass extinctions](https://greens.org.au/magazine/national/what-even-global-anoxic-event). Even if the environment is not naturally static, there are other reasons to avoid environmental and ecological damage.

1229.5420.text: More and more animals are being killed every day. All the remains of these animals are dumped in fields or waste piles. All this killing is polluting the world.

1229.5280.text: The population of sea birds has fallen almost 70% from 1950 to 2010 as industrial fishing has depleted the oceans' fisheries.[Seabirds suffering massive population declines](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/seabirds-suffering-massive-population-declines/)

1229.930.text: According to an [Austrian study](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2016/160419/ncomms11382/full/ncomms11382.html), it is actually possible to provide a diet similar to that of rich countries to all of the world's population without further deforestation.

1229.1676.text: That organic production is sustainable is a [myth](http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/13/opinion/the-myth-of-sustainable-meat.html?_r=0) because it produces relatively more CO2 emissions and requires more space.

1229.1936.text: All farm animals require [more water](http://news.cornell.edu/stories/1997/08/us-could-feed-800-million-people-grain-livestock-eat) per kg of food output than plants do. Therefore, it is always more sustainable to eat plant foods.

1229.2807.text: Raising livestock in a responsible way is a crucial part of the nutrient cycle that supports organic farming.

1229.3455.text: Meat should be eaten sparingly, and its externalities and environmental costs should be taken into account in its price. This will directly contribute to a higher price, and less meat consumption.

1229.6907.text: It's much easier for a consumer to support vegetarian alternatives than to find meat which satisfies these criteria. For example, meat is not generally labeled "raised on land that couldn't be used to grow crops for humans."

1229.5544.text: American culture might not easily adapt insects. They believe insects are pests to avoid rather than go to to eat. This is evidenced by the pesticide market being bigger than the insect-eating market. Although, getting rid of the "pests" by eating them might solve the "pest" problem to begin with.

1229.6182.text: Just because insects cannot "sense" damage, does not mean we have the right to end their lives or severely impair them.

1229.5674.text: There is a possibility that insects feel pain in a way that humans do not fully understand yet. People in the past thought animals did not feel pain but yet reacted to it \(in a different manner\) is the level we are at right now. We should not take a chance \(of creating pain\) in case we are wrong but instead err on the side of caution.

1229.6196.text: [There is a lot of new evidence that insects do have emotions. In fact, they are very similar to humans.](https://www.bustle.com/articles/187564-do-insects-have-emotions-the-answer-might-make-you-think-twice-before-swatting-one)

1229.6222.text: Eating insects is the future of meat consumption — it is easy to breed them in your own home.

1229.3152.text:
Every progressive change throughout history involved people collectively taking action to change "what is" in favor of their view of "what ought to be".

So if we look at "what is", we discover that it *is* the case that there exists an extensive proven track record of successful cases where "what ought to be" has led to positive cultural change that we value today.

So by this point's own reasoning, we should therefore take "what ought to be" seriously.

1229.191.text: Singer bases his argument on the presence of interests. If a being has interests, these have to be taken into account. Yet this would make eating plants as immoral as eating animals as they obviously have interests, for example in survival and reproduction. Singer's argument therefore suffers [from arbitrary delineations](http://www.abc.net.au/religion/articles/2014/08/05/4061202.htm).

1229.1410.text: Eating crops is necessary for many people to survive. Eating meat is not. Thus, there is a difference in the logic applied.

1229.3605.text: As noted in the linked article, plants are able to survive losing a large portion of their biomass - and many produce fruiting bodies deliberately intended for consumption by animals - whereas harvesting an animal for meat kills it 100% of the time. It is more possible to ethically harvest \(some\) plants than animals.

1229.3606.text: Farming animals for meat requires either farming plants for their food, or allowing them to graze in deliberately altered semi-natural environments. Therefore, farming meat produces a greater utilitarian loss than farming plants, as farming plants only harms and kills plants directly, while farming meat harms and kills both plants and the animals.

1229.1409.text: From a human perspective it is easy to produce more animals but difficult to create pleasure. Comparing the two, this makes pleasure more valuable to humans than animal lives.

1229.2231.text: It is not necessarily true that human pleasure is scarce. 1229.2479.text: "Reason" cannot be a parameter for moral judgement, because it gives us nothing about the moral status of a subject. Using "reason" as criteria for moral status is like using the capacity of breathing underwater or flying with  your own wings for the same ends.

1229.2480.text: Animal Rights Theory claims, in its most part, negative rights for animals, i.e.: the right not to suffer, not to die, not to \(...\). Some non-paradigmatic humans may have no positive rights, but they still have their negative rights guaranteed.

For the two claims would mean the same thing.

1229.1607.text: Animals also have [positive interests](http://www.animal-rights-library.com/texts-m/regan01.pdf) and it does not matter that they are of comparatively low grade, because the same is true of some human beings who may be largely restricted to food and beverages.

1229.3313.text: Animals evidently do have goals and preferences, or there would be absolutely nothing to drive them to action.

1229.4352.text: Animals act by impulse and not by will. It is automatic. Therefore they do not choose their actions. They only do actions.

1229.1524.text: A driver is prohibited to make an [emergency brake](http://www.theinjurylawyers.co.uk/injury-lawyers-blog/2013/03/19/rules-for-emergency-stop-for-an-animal/) for a cat when there is the danger of a collision with the car behind. Here human considerations weigh heavier than animal rights.

1229.2072.text: That humans have created laws that place their rights above those of animals does not mean it is the correct ethical decision, it only shows that humans are interested in looking out for themselves.

1229.4248.text: It could equally be argued that so is the right to life.

1229.1931.text: The evolutionary advance of the human species gives them the skill to reason and enables them to rethink their behavior. It lets them decide to not kill animals for food anymore - no matter if there is a right to kill and eat any animal.

1229.307.text: Research has examined [animal cognition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_cognition) in mammals \(e.g. primates, elephants, dogs, cats, horses, livestock etc.\), birds \(including parrots and pigeons\), reptiles \(lizards and snakes\), fish and even invertebrates \(including spiders and insects\). Thus humans are not unique in having a developed brain.

1229.3510.text: While morality exists independently of social construction \(i.e. moral relativism is not logical\), it does not exist outside of human perspective, or at least not in the same way. Perspectivalism shows us that all of our facts about morality \(eg. murder is wrong\) comes exclusively from a human perspective. For instance, our closest cousins, Chimps, may injure or murder their own species in dominance disputes which results in the winner getting a chance to mate \(reward, not punishment\).

1229.3785.text: There are many laws and moral codes which provide for the rights of animals.

1229.4353.text: Babies have the opportunity for free will and grown up human concioussness in the future. The animals do not.

1229.2096.text: Although humans and chimps have very similar DNA, they [often use their genes in different ways](https://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/permanent-exhibitions/human-origins-and-cultural-halls/anne-and-bernard-spitzer-hall-of-human-origins/understanding-our-past/dna-comparing-humans-and-chimps/), and therefore there are still big differences in the behaviour of chimps and humans.

1229.2290.text: Our genes may be similar, but our [brain size](http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20150706-the-small-list-of-things-that-make-humans-unique) is not. That is what makes us different.

1229.3025.text: The basis of this argument is fundamentally wrong. Whenever something is placed on a scale of "closeness" to something else, based on what is used, there will always be something closer than other things. It doesn't definitively mean that one comes from, or is related to the other.

1229.297.text: The line between animals and humans/nature and humans in general is a sign of humans' hubris and only exists in human minds.

1229.3139.text: It is not speciesist to point out the inherent differences in our thought processes, reasonings, technological leaps, and our huge impact on the Earth's environments, both positive and negative. We are animals, but there are no other animals like us.

1229.4913.text: Speciesism, like sexism and racism, is thinking that we as human are a superior species which leads us to slave, abuse and kill "inferior" beings. Nowadays we have advanced toward a more accepting and tolerant world and therefore we can assume that in the next 10-15 years there will be a prohibition to eat meat much like there is a prohibition to smoke in public places.

1229.6369.text: Killing animals for food, clothing, experimentation or any other reason directly enforces the idea of violence perpetuated by the strong upon the weak. It is similar to how all marginalized sections of society were and still are treated. Racism, ableism, sexism, homophobia - they are all directly related to carnism.

1229.6744.text: Rationally, there is no clear moral difference between a human's interests and a non-human animal's. If we are to try and justify human rights, we will see that we are unable to come up with a criterion which includes humans but excludes other animals. Sentience is the ultimate reason we think of it as wrong to harm humans; people feel pain. It is morally arbitrary to say other animals should not get the same consideration simply because they are not humans.

1229.186.text: Food chains are merely descriptive, not deterministic. If we were to eat other humans today, our food chain would reflect that - but by no means prescribe or justify that we eat other humans. To argue that we have to eat meat due to our position in the food chain is thus a circular argument.

Saying the eating of meat is immoral is to impose moral value 'good' upon a natural act, eating \(whatever it is\).  For instance is it really the act of eating meat that is being called immoral or is it the slaughtering practices?

1229.2234.text: Eating meat, in and of itself, cannot be cruel. [Cruel](http://www.dictionary.com/browse/cruel) is defined as willingly causing pain; unless you are eating the animal alive, it would be impossible to bring pain to a non-living piece of meat.

1229.3623.text: The meat must be sourced from somewhere. Even high welfare animal products and certifications involve some level of cruelty \(for example, gassing male chicks as opposed to liquidising them in the egg industry - better, but hardly cruelty free\). External monitoring of conditions can also be manipulated to put on a good show for the audits. By eating the meat, the consumer is complicit, just as using products made by slaves is tacitly supporting that industry.

1229.2647.text: If we were to outlaw meat 10 years ago, all the animals in the meat making process would probably be slaughtered to cut losses. In light of recent changes, it is plausible that in 10 years' time farm animals will be allowed to live beyond the time when they are 'useful'.

1229.4269.text: Wild animals almost invariably suffer more than domesticated animals properly farmed. Even a wild animal suffering the relatively peaceful death of kidney failure will likely be awakened when carnivores and scavengers begin eating their helpless bodies alive. There is no end to a wild life that is not brutal.

1229.4277.text: This is contingent on the farm in fact being ethical, and depending on exactly how it is run there are still plausible reasons why a life in the wild could be better.

1229.6912.text: Then the responsible action would be to advocate for reform while abstaining from meat until reform succeeds.

1229.3306.text: Animals in the wild have freedom of movement and other increased choices not available to farm animals. Quality of life is not decided purely by length or absence of suffering, or how its end is met.

1229.3877.text: As discussed earlier, these animals are bred specifically for human consumption. If humans had not created these animals, they could not possibly "be eaten by other predators/scavengers in the wild."

1229.4162.text: "Unbalanced in value" is dubious. By what objective measure of value are you using? A feral human left in the wild, or a mentally handicapped child, is of equal value to a penned sheep then.

1229.4163.text: Who is to argue when anthropomorphising is or isn't wrong? Blacks were enslaved because they were just brutes. Then one day we anthropomorphised them. Voila, suddenly rights are bestowed.

1229.5335.text: For this statement to be true every animal which is prey would end their lives at the hands of a predator. In fact most survive to experience a natural cause of death.

1229.5336.text: Anthropomorphism is the attribution of human characteristics to animals. There is no such attribution in the claim.

1229.5267.text: All humans are also born due to the actions and decisions of their parents. It is not subsequently moral to treat them however you wish to meet your own ends. Once a living being is alive, they should be subject to the same standard of morality that empathy drives us to apply to human children. Empathy naturally decreases the further from our species an animal gets, but we have empathy for them regardless.

1229.3264.text: That's like saying it's a parent's right to be abusive by virtue of causing their child's birth. The basic rights of any living creature are not affected by the circumstances of its birth.

1229.3888.text: This renders the concept of birth as giving claim to another life as being property to do with as one pleases. Ownership/property mentality as a form of colonialism was used for generations to rationalize the abuse of animals, children, women, other races, religions, under the concept that another is property to the person, group or country who feeds, employs or "owns" it, putting that life under their control. We have since implemented laws to counter abuses perpetrated under this philosophy.

1229.4645.text: People who don't eat meat give animals a better quality of life while avoiding the majority of conditions and situations that are caused by meat producing farmers. Thus, the terms of existence are better managed by the people that consider sentience above digestion. Most noticeably, the inferior existence and situation is massively created by industrially breeding domesticated animals into being.

1229.3436.text: Certain diseases become more prevalent due to the cramped conditions in "factory" farming.

1229.3437.text: Chickens are commonly de-beaked without anaesthesia, a process which is extremely painful for them.

1229.3869.text: An animal that isn't born can't prefer to be born at all as they don't exist. An animal that exists currently doesn't want to die prematurely \(they actively avoid pain\). Since we know they don't want to die \(avoid pain\) it is ethical not to harm them. If we create animals to kill \(harm\) we are acting unethically.

1229.5700.text: It is true that animal intelligence exists and should be considered no matter where it scores relative to ours. Since we do not know if they prefer to live a little before being killed, we should not assume they would, especially because factory farming living conditions are not even good in the first place.

1229.6596.text: A social contract implies a mutual benefit. The relationship between domesticated animals and their human captures is not a mutually beneficial relationship. Animals raised for slaughter are artificially selected for traits that humans value, which inhibit the animal's ability to survive in the wild. Each of our domesticated species suffers from various illnesses and conditions that are a direct result of captivity and human exploitation.

1229.6924.text: The goal of not eating meat is not to help an animal that has already been slaughtered, but to reduce demand and thus production of meat in the long term.

1229.6937.text: The animal has not made a choice to dedicate it's life to humankind nor has it chosen to sacrifice itself to sustain us. We have made the choice to kill it.

1229.6079.text: Claiming truth with no definition of the "right to life" or where this is a prerequisite to have desires about the future is not an argument. You have simply claimed these things as self evident truths. Also claimed animals are not self aware.  Which animals? Who said? When? etc.

1229.6788.text: Animals demonstrate their desires for the future through their actions. For example, they try to flee from danger and become panicked in slaughterhouses, so they clearly have specific desires about the future to not be killed.

1229.6873.text: One should err on giving more rights than less. Even if the essential prerequisites for rights are vague, we should err on respecting life rather than disrespecting it.

1229.6874.text: The main animal farming victims are examples of complex lifeforms that do not constitute borderline cases and should be given the right to life.

1229.6273.text: The animals could have a better purpose or be utilized better \(such as providing companionship to someone or providing other food like milk\).

1229.6274.text: More resources are used to make up for what is lost. For example, another animal has to be raised for the meat that went spoiled.

1229.4843.text: Some moral systems \(i.e., [deontologically-based](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deontological_ethics) ones\) classify actions - or even thoughts, goals, and ideals - as right or wrong, and are effectively based around maximizing "right" actions and avoiding or reducing "wrong" ones.

1229.4870.text: We are a part of reality, and thereby can shape it to an extent. If we choose to enforce certain standards, they are "real" to an extent as they have force on our interactions with physical reality, and thereby effects on physical reality.

1229.5581.text: By moral relativism's own measure, it is not real, but an opinion one has with no grounding, or weight.

1229.5582.text: If one uses a what they feel is right to determine their moral system instead of using their moral system to determine what is right, they are by no measure using a moral system.

1229.5583.text: If moral relativism is true, everything is permissible, full stop.

1229.5584.text: This assumes out of hand that nothing is definitely wrong.

1229.5585.text: We've seen morality in it's effect on the world, and we've seen the same moral concepts pop up independently in all corners of the world. Morality exists, and there is good reason to believe it is objective.

1229.6380.text: Each of those historical instances eventually fell apart by intervention from other countries to disrupt their immorality. Thus humans do clearly \(eventually\) determine and enforce subjective moral norms.

1229.3679.text: This argument is based on the assumption that there is only one meaning to the word "natural", whereas there clearly are at least two: natural as in encompassing the entire universe, and natural as opposed to artificial or anything derived from human thought and action.

1229.6382.text: There's a difference between contribution and cooperation.

1229.5133.text: Child marriage, corporal punishment, and genital mutilation are all injustices perpetrated against human beings, therefore this is not incongruous with the claim that morality only applies to human beings.

1229.6337.text: This is to suggest that reducing animal suffering is more important than reducing human suffering. Morality demands that the life of the enslaved vegetable farmer is of more value than the life of a farmed chicken.

1229.2918.text: Pain is understood to be a function of the brain and nervous system, which plants do not have.

1229.3213.text: Consciousness does not necessarily require the presence of a brain as there is no scientific peer-reviewed literature heavily supporting this hypothesis. 1229.3019.text: If eating plants is justified, as the amount of consciousness a plant could potentially have is nothing compared to that of animals, there is no problem with eating meat, as the amount of consciousness they could potentially have is nothing compared to that of humans.

1229.3255.text: If you accept consciousness as the defining factor, and also that consciousness lies along a continuum on which humans, animals, and plants lie \(as your argument suggests\), then the threshold on that continuum beyond which plants or animals become protected is arbitrary, and could just as easily be extended to plants as animals.  Currently, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that plants and animals experience consciousness the way humans do.

1229.3542.text: We already know that they do react to many stimuli, as do bacteria too, to be fair. Maybe systems analogous to the nervous system could be associated with some kind or level of pain. [newyorker.com](https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/12/23/the-intelligent-plant)

1229.4073.text: Domestic animals raised for meat would not exist except for that production chain which we are responsible for. Therefore, we are responsible for every moment of suffering during their life, not just at the moment of death.

1229.6161.text: The end of a life is the end of a life. Cutting a lawn does not kill the grass; it makes a lawn healthier. But killing a plant is equal in scope to killing an animal. Each has the same right to life. As do human beings.

1229.4001.text: In situations of uncertainty, it is often best to go with the highest probability of a good outcome, or minimize the known/likeliest losses \(in this case, 100% chance of pain/death for animals if animals eaten, ??% chance of pain/death for plants if plants eaten\).

1229.4060.text: Pain in and of itself is worth taking into account.

1229.3599.text: If we are considering animals as living beings worthy of rights, they are still relevant.

1229.3389.text: There is no bounded study without limitations. It is better to have some indication than none.

1229.4599.text: "Meat is much more protein dense than vegetables" is true only when comparing the average of all meats with the average of all vegetables. Some vegetable products like hemp seed and tempeh provide comparable amounts of complete proteins in comparable serving portions, while also providing other minerals and nutrients not typically found in meat. A vegan diet \(+B vitamin\) does not preclude adequate nutrition, nor does an omnivorous diet protect against malnutrition. [healthyeating.sfgate.com](http://healthyeating.sfgate.com/tempeh-vs-meat-4276.html)

1229.5695.text: The calorie is a more basic and important indicator of nutrition than protein content.

This point ignores the amount of plant nutrition necessary in order to sustain livestock for human consumption; that amount is vastly more than if humans obtained their needed calories from plants directly. A large percent of calories and protein are lost in the conversion of plant-based animal feed into meat during the life of the animal that is being harvested.[Feed-to-food conversions](http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/11/10/105002)

1229.2118.text: Ploughing and harvesting kill small mammals, snakes, lizards and other animals in vast numbers.

1229.2120.text: Red meat animals feed on pasture, which requires next to no upkeep. In contrast, farming vegetables requires the use of pesticides that kill massive amounts of insects and/or similar measures that kill birds.

1229.2340.text: Measuring against kg of usable protein is misleading, since meat has higher concentrations of proteins relative to other nutrients. So the gap between meat and grains is not that large.

1229.4289.text: Suffering is unpleasant, and all sufficiently conscious animals attempt to avoid it. \(Even less conscious animals reflexively avoid pain!\) This suggests it is something we should not deliberately inflict, and take reasonable steps to avoid inflicting in others, as well as avoiding ourselves. Even if we cannot perfect the world, we should attempt to improve it.

1229.4290.text: If life only produced suffering and negative experiences, this argument may hold water. However, life also produces joy and pleasure and enjoyable experiences. As such, according to [Utilitarianism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utilitarianism) and similar ethical theories, our "job" or at least the most moral courses of action are to minimize suffering while maximizing pleasure and pleasant experiences.

1229.4727.text:
This claim is invoking moral skepticism - there is no objective basis for wrong and right. Holding this position is extremely impractical as it permits all human behaviour and it follows that actions such as murder and rape- both observable in non-human life- are acceptable. 

In reality, this is not the case. Human behaviour is governed by norms whose content is subjective but whose existence  is not. Subjective though it may be, we accept that there are principles of right and wrong.

1229.6804.text: Babies, little children, and the mentally disabled do have substantially fewer rights than healthy adults. 1229.6692.text: Animal rights can correspond to human obligations, but not any obligations from other animals.

Any model of what "Rights" are supposed to be can be shown to apply simultaneously to all animals, not just the human animal.

An argument can be made that whatever *is* ought to be. Standards can only evolve naturally within culture and not through vast policy or legal impositions.

1229.6878.text: In utilitarian terms, ten animals that live for one year each in succession, and one animal that lives for ten years, if they experience the same utility, have the same moral value. Hence, there is no lost utility when meat animals die "prematurely" as long as the population does not shrink.

1229.6879.text: It can only be said that there is a more or less valid measure of moral value if there is a True \(objective\) Morality to be closer to or further from. If there is such a True Morality, it wouldn't be affected by what humans thought, because anyone who disagrees is objectively wrong. Hence, the fact that people often consider deontological principles to be valid moral rules cannot indicate that utilitarianism is a less valid measure of moral value than others.

1229.805.text: When comparing the average price of non-animal protein with animal protein \(especially beef\), vegetarian products tend to [cost less](http://plenteousveg.com/cost-vegan-protein-vs-animal-protein/).

1229.381.text: Meat prices [rise](http://blogs.wsj.com/economics/2014/07/22/vegans-rejoice-meat-prices-rising-more-than-fresh-fruits-and-vegetables/) faster than vegetable prices in the recent years. This indicates a trend change.

1229.2250.text: Unprocessed vegetarian products, such as lentils and unprocessed soy, are bland without seasoning and taste nothing like meat; processed meatless products - those that claim to be the closest in flavour to, and therefore the closest literal 'replacements' of, their meat equivalents - are more expensive than meat.

1229.1950.text: This suggests that meat may be cheaper than fruits and vegetables in the future, yet it does not tell us whether meat is cheaper right now.

1229.3431.text: Not everybody who eats meat "focuses on having \[it\] as the central part of \[their\] diet". Many dishes include meat as only one component, but this is still enough to be considered "eating meat" and thus, not strictly vegetarian.

1229.10661.text: Societies cannot commit logical fallacies because they are not making deductive logical arguments, they are making pragmatic decisions with an imperfect consensus.

1229.936.text: From a [deterministic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Determinism) point of view, every human action and choice is necessitated by antecedent events and conditions together with the laws of nature. Therefore the "path" they allegedly chose is determined as well and not a product of their consciousness.

1229.945.text: Consciousness is merely a result of [physical material interactions](http://www.eagleman.com/incognito). The brain is a system whose operation is governed by the laws of chemistry and physics, thus all of our thoughts, emotions and decisions are produced by natural reactions and not, as we like to think, by individual decision.

1229.784.text: Hunting in industrialised nations is no longer necessary for the acquisition of food.

1229.2593.text: The means by which people eat does not change what people eat. It's a very distinct behavioural change that is not comparable with that of changing the human diet entirely.

1229.4461.text: Although humans have canines, the animal with the largest canines is a herbivore \(ie. hippo\)

1229.1656.text: Humans' [final velocity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Footspeed) is simply not high enough to run away from most of the carnivores.

1229.3776.text: Humans are endurance hunters - weapons are less necessary to kill an already exhausted prey animal.

1229.3777.text: Against smaller \(and exhausted\) prey animals, barehanded attacks \(deliberate neck-breaking, etc.\) are a perfectly viable way to kill.

1229.6218.text:
The human weapon is his use of tools. 
Intellect derived from an enlarged brain, which itself evolved from a protein rich diet, is what allowed us to figure out how to use them.

1229.741.text: This argument applies to human food production in general, but only to a small degree to meat. Compared to other food categories the share of the meat production lost during growth, harvesting, processing distribution and consumption [is actually lower](http://www.fao.org/docrep/014/mb060e/mb060e02.pdf).

1229.749.text: Experts estimate that globally almost [12 billion animals'](http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2014/mar/19/meat-dairy-waste) lives are lost each year due to household food wastage. And [one third](http://www.fao.org/docrep/014/mb060e/mb060e02.pdf) of the edible parts of all food produced is lost/wasted globally. This equals about 1.3 billion tons of food per year. An extraordinary amount of living creatures born to be wasted.

1229.977.text: Some predators do. It is known as [surplus killing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surplus_killing), in which preditors kill more prey than they can immediately eat and then cache or abandon the remainder.

1229.1339.text: Some predators kill for reasons [other than](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surplus_killing) food procurement, for example to practice their hunting skills.

1229.4191.text: Exact numbers of teeth are not relevant, as evolution does not "plan ahead" in this manner or deliberately create specific ratios, rather creates or further emphasizes traits which prove useful. Humans would develop exactly as many canines \(and molars\) as they needed at the time, so the exact numbers or ratios do not prove what is described here, as it is possible that having more molars is more beneficial in ways that having more canines is not. \(Also, molars are still used to chew meat.\)

1229.607.text: The presence of certain teeth does not necessarily correlate with natural dietary preferences. [Hippos](http://science.jrank.org/pages/3340/Hippopotamus-hippo-s-teeth-its-diet.html), [gorillas](http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2015/02/150207-animals-gorillas-elephants-teeth-science-dentistry/) and [camels](http://www.fao.org/docrep/t0690e/t0690e09.htm) have canine teeth, yet are herbivores.

1229.608.text: Humans' natural physiology [made them](https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=7bdqAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT93&lpg=PT93&dq=%22Humans+can+grip+this+way+because+we+have+relatively+long+thumbs%22&source=bl&ots=dXitibmPmL&sig=iWCVFMrC88fDW6vD6OmztyuaVDY&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwim1eCGx_nMAhWHFJQKHSxiAfgQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=%22Humans%20can%20grip%20this%20way%20because%20we%20have%20relatively%20long%20thumbs%22&f=false) a tool-using species. We do not need canine teeth/claws to slice meat because we have tools for doing so.

1229.94.text: Humans do not have the large mouth or long, pointed teeth of carnivores. Human [teeth](http://www.adaptt.org/Mills%20The%20Comparative%20Anatomy%20of%20Eating1.pdf) are short and flat for chewing fibrous food.

1229.6675.text: We evolved with primates, then switched to eating meat later in the evolutionary path. We dont kill or hunt with our teeth. We can easily eat and digest meat and many of us do.

1229.1312.text: The mode of perspiration might correlate with the diet of many animals - but this does not imply a causal determination. Bears, for example, do not have skin pores, yet they can live on a plant-based diet, as pandas do.

1229.5787.text: Great white sharks, an apex predator, do not perspire through the tongue. The above claim is unfounded.

1229.593.text: This merely proves that humans may be [omnivores](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omnivore), able to digest grains and fruits as well.

1229.1067.text: Claws are not essential for eating meat.

1229.1073.text: Human hands are better able to hold meat than claws. So human anatomy is superior for eating meat.

1229.1163.text: Humans developed anatomical features that enable them to build and utilize tools.

1229.6987.text: You do not need claws to eat meat. For instance frogs, salamanders, toads and newts do not have claws but all of them are carnivores. Humans have hands so have never needed claws while other predators like cats lack this trait so they have claws instead.

1229.601.text: Sitting for hours - as many office workers do - is [unnatural for the human body](https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=wDB-BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA14&dq=human+body+sitting+hours+unnatural&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=human%20body%20sitting%20hours%20unnatural&f=false) and has negative effects on overall health as well as a direct link to mortality.

1229.602.text: Human biology points towards the benefits of polygamy - yet we are commonly expected to behave monogamously, which is [not necessarily natural](https://books.google.co.kr/books/about/The_Myth_of_Monogamy.html?id=Jl19414uE1gC&redir_esc=y) for us.

1229.606.text: It is unnatural for human bodies to vastly go beyond the spaces and speeds they can naturally reach, for example with the help of [airplanes and spacecrafts](https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=udIpBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA155&lpg=PA155&dq=%22space+exploration%22+%22unnatural%22&source=bl&ots=C-DDdRDBk1&sig=fdWW_EHDq2cQo08Cp3aw89Nvv10&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwis6IqLyfnMAhWCk5QKHezYB2QQ6AEIJTAC#v=onepage&q&f=false).

1229.614.text: Humans are not supposed to exist under water, yet diving is a popular and widespread hobby and sport.

1229.1310.text: Many activities that go against what our body is made for are however seen as problematic and unhealthy, for example extended sitting and diving without caution.

1229.912.text: When Italian wall lizards were introduced to a new environment in the 1970s, they [changed their diet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_wall_lizard#Rapid_adaptation) from one heavy in plants to one heavy in insects, and accordingly adapted their morphology over generations.

1229.2044.text: As the environment of humans has changed over time, they have [adapted their diets](http://www.beyondveg.com/nicholson-w/hb/hb-interview1c.shtml) to fit with their surroundings and depending on what was available.

1229.2570.text: Up until several thousand years ago, nearly all adult humans were [lactose-intolerant](http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2012/12/27/168144785/an-evolutionary-whodunit-how-did-humans-develop-lactose-tolerance); however, when European farmers began to discover the nutritional benefits of dairy products from animal milk, increasing numbers of mutations in the gene that produces the lactase enzyme occurred, enabling many humans to adapt to a diet that included dairy.

1229.1169.text: Anatomy and physiology are the outcomes of evolutionary processes. These are determined by the environment in which certain traits flourish while others perish. The anatomy and physiology of humans is thus an indicator for the natural environment in which they developed.

1229.3726.text: Humans actually have the jaw structure of frugivores, not carnivores, and our digestive system is not built to digest meat as easy as other animals

1229.6229.text: [Meat eating and hunting among chimpanzees is normal.](http://www-bcf.usc.edu/~stanford/chimphunt.html) Meat is also used in gaining political ground in the troop and as presents when attempting to mate.

1229.2850.text: The evolutionary growth of the human brain could only have been supported by meat consumption.[Waterlogged by Dr. Tim Noakes](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nlmcatalog/101587029)

1229.2849.text: When available \(but usually at least 3% of total consumption\) chimps prefer to eat meat due to the nutritional advantages. This quantity is significant when comparing the encephalization of humans, species ancestral to humans, and modern apes to their amount of consumption of proteins. For instance, humans require only as little as 15-20% of their total consumption to be protein to maintain muscle mass and brain function.[completehumanperformance.com](https://completehumanperformance.com/2015/09/11/dieting-protein-needs/) [www-bcf.usc.edu](http://www-bcf.usc.edu/~stanford/chimphunt.html)

1229.6674.text: Evolved with primates then took a sharp turn towards meat consumption with the shortening of our gut and efficient fat digestion, the loss of our ability to easily produce retinol from carotenoids, B12 from plants.

1229.4868.text: There are other plausible explanations for how that specific adaptation could have been acquired or emerged - it could equally be used to aid escape from predators, or cover more ground while searching for food, or - as the article also alludes to - beating other scavengers to a meal.

1229.1272.text: Until the Mid-20th century it was natural for millions to suffer from smallpox, many of whose victims went blind and died. The disease was responsible for [300 to 500 million deaths](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smallpox) in the 20th century - but was [successfully eradicated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smallpox#Eradication) through the use of vaccinations by 1980.

1229.1273.text: Vaccines are based on parts of the bacteria or the virus that make up a disease. In this sense, the working ingredient of vaccines [is actually natural](http://www.chop.edu/centers-programs/vaccine-education-center/vaccine-safety/immune-system-and-health#.V2Mvbfl96Hs).

1229.1274.text: The wide-spread use of unnatural vaccines was able to decrease the worldwide cases of Polio [by 99%](http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs114/en/) since 1988: From 305.000 to 74.

1229.1278.text: Vaccines work through a [natural mechanism](http://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/think-vaccines) and merely provoke the human immune system to produce its own, perfectly natural anti-bodies to viruses and diseases.

1229.4030.text: Artificial flavours are not an applicable argument here, as they are deliberately designed to be "tasty" no matter their actual composition, and thus to "trick" our brains and "natural tendencies".

1229.3768.text: However, in today's society, excessive consumption of them can lead to health issues.

1229.4844.text: People unaware of or uninterested in the moral implications of eating meat would not be likely - or in some cases, even able - to associate its taste with something which is not prominent - or even existent, in some cases - in their minds.

1229.4845.text: It is logical to surmise that someone who is consciously aware of and interested in issues of animal welfare would be repulsed by meat as a reminder of the issues.

1229.3798.text: A part of what we find enjoyable in food is what we are used to. If we change to vegetarian food we will become accustomed to those flavours and meat would seem less appealing.

1229.5195.text: Eventhough taste is individual and everyone experiences the pleasure of eating food, which he or she never tasted before, the sense that meat is 'good' and 'tasty' is a social phenomena. An example of the opposite direction but same phenomena could be algae, which are disliked by many people, without being tasted in the first place.

1229.3430.text: It is more efficient to grow plants for food for people than it is to grow plants for food for animals that will be slaughtered for food for people.

1229.2809.text: A benefit of this is that it lets farmers convert inedible organic matter \(grass, weeds, plant waste\) into edible organic matter \(meat, offal, gelatin, milk\).

1229.6450.text:
40% of global grain production is fed to livestock. 
To put this in perspective, the US alone could feed 
[800 million people](http://news.cornell.edu/stories/1997/08/us-could-feed-800-million-people-grain-livestock-eat) with the grain that is fed to livestock.

1229.105.text: It takes about 2,500 gallons of water to produce one pound of beef, and about 660 gallons to make a pound of chicken. It only takes about 220 gallons to make a pound of tofu and 180 to make a pound of wheat flour. So a vegetarian diet [conserves water](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/water_inputs_in_ca_food_production.pdf).

1229.1000.text: Livestock farming causes massive nitrogen pollution.

1229.448.text: According to the Worldwatch Institute, "Declining livestock herds will [take pressure off](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegetarianism#Economics_and_diet) rangelands and grainlands, allowing the agricultural resource base to rejuvenate."

1229.1155.text: The livestock industry generates 64 % of ammonia, which contributes significantly to [acid rain](http://www.fao.org/newsroom/en/news/2006/1000448/index.html).

1229.1156.text: Pollution of our [waterways](https://www.downtoearth.org/go-veggie/environment/top-10-reasons) is caused by animal waste, antibiotics and hormones entering the water cycle alongside chemicals from tanneries, fertilizers, and the pesticides used to spray feed crops.

1229.2554.text: Livestock are [estimated to be the main inland source](http://www.fao.org/newsroom/en/news/2006/1000448/index.html) of phosphorous and nitrogen contamination in the South China Sea. This had contributed to biodiversity loss in marine ecosystems.

1229.2893.text: The resource requirements from all three are extremely intense. The impacts on a per calorie basis are actually [more intensive](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301479712004264) for organic permaculture. Analysis on a per acre basis certainly reduced impact significantly, but given that the productivity of these approaches is so much lower than traditional agriculture it stays a net negative and the above point is maintained.

1229.10665.text: It is unlikely that the amount of manure produced is enough to compensate for the loss of productive farmland.

1229.4231.text: Previously mentioned new farming methods such as [vertical farming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_farming) can produce greater quantities of plant-based foods without necessarily needing more land. Production capacity can theoretically be improved in any number of ways through technology, potentially up to and including space-based farming systems.

1229.2877.text: Industrial, mono-crop agriculture is currently necessary to feed the world using only plants. Industrial agriculture is deeply environmentally harmful and we cannot continue to grow food in this way.  In order for a permaculture agriculture to match industrial agriculture's output and feed the world, animals must be a part of the system and a part of the caloric output.

1229.3279.text: Eating meat, such as farmed insects may be the answer to the world's protein shortage without damaging the environment.

1229.2878.text: Animals are an essential part of ecological farming systems. Eating those animals is necessary for these systems to obtain the outputs required to feed the world. In order to feed the world, ecologically and sustainably, we have to eat \(some\) meat.

1229.3945.text: Many areas of the world would starve or be extremely malnourished if they stopped eating meat.[World Health Organization](http://apps.who.int/iris/handle/10665/43411)

1229.3610.text: The Innuit people of Greenland are unable to grow crops due to the nature of their land. Their diet consists mainly of seafood, oily fish and hunted red meat.

1229.5224.text: Situations where survival drives the need to eat meat are morally different from a situation where there is no need to eat meat in order to survive.

1229.5222.text: With the technology available today and the low population of such places it would be possible to grow crops indoors with minimum water consumption \(hydroponics\) and almost 0 energy cost \(LED lights and solar panels\).

1229.3609.text: The solution that represents the greatest good for most human beings and other living beings would involve control and restriction of the population in unsustainable communities and regions.

1229.6374.text: Such 'first world countries' have only gained most of their highly developed statuses through war and dirty politics.

1229.6915.text: This claim is self-contradictory - "most people are not alcoholics" shows that moderation is easy for alcohol. There are probably more moderate drinkers than either complete abstainers or alcoholics, so "Same \[i.e., moderation is harder\] is true for alcohol" is clearly false.

1229.6916.text: The discussion is about morality, not legality. A world in which no one drank alcohol would arguably be better, but it's not banned because practically trying to enforce such a ban has historically failed and lead to more problems.

1229.6376.text: You cannot compare an 'uncivilized' action such as eating meat to moral wrongdoing such as crime.

1229.5519.text: And if it were replaced by vegetable farming, then vegetable farming would be the major contributor.

1229.1882.text: The researchers did not find that producing vegetables is more harmful to the environment than producing meat. What they found, in light of the data they examined, is that producing some vegetables and other foods results in high use of natural resources – and that eating more of those foods \(as recommended for health by the USDA\) in two particular scenarios results in higher energy use, blue water footprint and greenhouse gas emissions.

1229.3879.text: "\[T\]he results showed that getting our weight under control and eating fewer calories, has a positive effect on the environment and reduces energy use, water use and GHG emissions from the food supply chain by approximately 9 percent." [cmu.edu](https://www.cmu.edu/news/stories/archives/2015/december/diet-and-environment.html)

1229.4080.text: Shifting consumption to eating more sustainable meats like chicken and pork is a better solution than phasing out all of meats. As the source above says, chicken and pork do not consume nearly as many fossil fuels as some vegetarian alternatives. Maybe a shift away from red meat \(cow\) is what is necessary.

1229.2454.text: According to a [major Oxford University study](http://www.oxfordmartin.ox.ac.uk/news/201603_Plant_based_diets), adopting global vegetarian diets would cut food-related emissions by 63%.

1229.1247.text: Universal veganism from today would [reduce](http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/feed_the_world/2014/05/meat_eating_and_climate_change_vegetarians_impact_on_the_economy_antibiotics.html) agriculture-related carbon emissions by 17%, methane emissions by 24%, and nitrous oxide emissions by 21% by 2050. Universal vegetarianism would cause similar [effects](https://gnightearth.com/2014/06/26/is-your-diet-sustainable-vegetarian-trump-meat-eaters-in-terms-of-sustainability-and-greenhouse-gas-emissions/).

1229.4665.text: Vegan diets have been proved as healthy as non vegan diets, even more so in some aspects [\[1\]](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16441942) and the footprint of vegans is way smaller than meat eaters [\[2\]](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4372775/).

1229.4938.text: Much of the imported food is more environmentally-friendly than animal husbandry due to the releases of methane from those animals. Thus one cannot argue that imported food by default is worse for the environment.

1229.4939.text: Good land-use, crop-rotation and green-fertilizing can also heal and protect land.

1229.4976.text: Some vegan foods use more water than beef. [In fact the food that uses the most water to make per pound is vanilla. Even chocolate uses more water to grow than beef.](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/10/13/food-water-footprint_n_5952862.html) To heal the planet the consumption of all three of these foods should be lowered.

1229.4977.text: [Some vegan foods like tofu generate the same or more CO2 amounts than meat \(like seafood\).](http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/the_green_lantern/2009/10/how_green_is_tofu.html)

1229.4721.text: If somebody becomes conscious enough to turn to a vegan diet, there's a good chance that the person also questions other aspects of his diet, like the precedence of the products, the quality of the ingredients and the footprint it may have.

1229.4852.text: Just because something can go wrong in one very specific way does not mean it is not worth attempting where other outcomes are possible, especially if the risk of adverse outcomes is known and addressed.

1229.4952.text: Evidence of this is needed because actually, there is strong evidence that reducing the meat production can reduce greenhouse gases. [Less beef less carbon](https://www.nrdc.org/sites/default/files/less-beef-less-carbon-ip.pdf) [FAO](https://www.facebook.com/UNFAO/videos/10154823820723586/)

1229.5487.text: There are a lot of 'may' statements in this argument. Also, the assumption that not eating meat leads to a 'poor' diet. This is not sound reasoning nor reliable argument.

1229.5496.text: Artificial meat products would not cause any of the [environmental harms](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/dec/02/no-kill-lab-grown-meat-to-go-on-sale-for-first-time)(The small scale of current cultured meat production requires a relatively high use of energy and therefore carbon emissions. But once scaled up its manufacturers say it will produce much lower emissions and use far less water and land than conventional meat.) of meat, since production would not require grazing areas, the use of grain, or the creation of methane.

1229.5986.text: While the farming of cattle appears to emit methane due to digestion of grassars, grass  dies and rots \(emitting methand\) as part of its natural cycle if not eaten.

1229.6278.text: As noted in a comment to that claim, the FAO's more recent data significantly reduces this figure, to 14.5% of the total human-casued greenhouse gas emissions. "Total emissions from global livestock: 7.1 Gigatonnes of Co2-equiv per year, representing 14.5 percent of all anthropogenic GHG emissions." [www.fao.org](http://www.fao.org/docrep/018/i3437e/i3437e.pdf)

1229.4335.text: In 2011, methane from livestock accounted for 39% of all the greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture, according to a [report](https://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2014/04/11/301794415/gassy-cows-are-warming-the-planet-and-theyre-here-to-stay) from United Nation's Food and Agriculture Organization. Farmers trying to keep up with demand for meat is having a negative effect on the natural ecosystem.

1229.6626.text: Animals bred for slaughter are often overfed a poor diet. Overfed animals produce an excess of methane. Methane contributes to the greenhouse heating of our ecosystem. Every degree our planet's temperature is raised causes seismotic changes in the regulation of function. [news.berkeley.edu](http://news.berkeley.edu/2010/06/04/climate/)

1229.6785.text:
All animals including humans and many plant related source produce methane and not just livestock. Source: [link.springer.com](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF02208779)
Therefore replacing livestock with rice pads would not be a great idea.

1229.4679.text: Land conversion for crops, massive city infrastructure, human waste and energy consumption also all significantly contribute to climate change. All of these things can be inhibited by a smaller population.

1229.4697.text: The amounts and quality of what you eat should be determined by what´s sustainable to eat at this moment, for everyone, to live safe and healthy without sacrificing the future of the planet. All other aspects of daily life should be adressed this way.

1229.4862.text: It is not viable to immediately reduce overpopulation through any sane, viable, or ethical means. Even if future generations may enjoy greater comforts and luxuries due to hopeful reductions in global overpopulation, this generation must make sacrifices in order to ensure such generations can even exist.

1229.3880.text: [Methane](https://gizmodo.com/do-cow-farts-actually-contribute-to-global-warming-1562144730) is a by-product of the bacteria which help with digestion. It is not consumed by the animals.

1229.3934.text: [Methane](https://www.edf.org/methane-other-important-greenhouse-gas) is a far stronger ozone-disrupting agent than CO2, even on a per-carbon-atom basis.

1229.4522.text: In the absence of farm animals, more plants would be grown to feed humans directly, so net emissions would decrease.

1229.5354.text: A vegan diet would consume the plants that the animal ate, and would in the same manner indirectly consume CO2 and CH4 as you claim. The difference is that the animal becomes inefficient. The animal have to use the energy to grow and to live, where there is a spillage of energy from what it ate. By not eating animals we exclude this factor, which is the whole reason that a vegan diet is more environmentally sustainable.

1229.6309.text: Farm animals eat grass and animal feed, which took exactly as much CO2 out of the atmosphere during growing as the animals give back during digestion. Therefore animal farming does not contribute to climate change, it keeps it in balance.

1229.5941.text: These are animals that live in the open grass; but most animals that are used for meat, dairy and eggs do not live on open fields, they live inside.

1229.5980.text: The land that is destroyed for animal agriculture wouldn't have to be destroyed in the first place if we didn't consume animal products.

1229.4874.text: Regardless of the method, the scale would still be vast given the human population and thus would still have environmental impacts.

1229.5517.text: As long as there are large cities, food production,whether animal or vegetable, will continue at large scale, and will continue to impact the environment.

1229.5518.text: Without a major devastating calamity, agriculture will not devolve back to primarily small farm production.

1229.3919.text: Removing meat consumption removes its environmental effect. Reducing it only reduces the environmental effect.

1229.4587.text: We should do everything we can to reduce our damage, even if some is unpreventable - not all of it is.

1229.4856.text: This claim is an example of the [perfect solution fallacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nirvana_fallacy#Perfect_solution_fallacy) - it implies that just because a problem cannot be solved entirely with one solution, we should not attempt to minimize its effects until a solution can be found, or use a combination solution to ultimately solve it entirely by addressing various factors at once.

1229.6214.text: The costs associated rising sea levels would be much more significant compared to any benefit when taking into account human displacement and climate refugees, risk of regional conflicts, and damage on existing infrastructure.

1229.6780.text: Life as we know it changes significantly when the climate changes. When it changes rapidly, as is the case with human-induced climate change, most animals struggle to adapt fast enough and[suffer greatly as a result.](http://www.globalissues.org/article/172/climate-change-affects-biodiversity)

1229.5445.text: The [study](https://www.sciencealert.com/vegetarian-and-healthy-diets-may-actually-be-worse-for-the-environment-study-finds) is based on a "per-calorie" comparison, where broccoli \(34kcal/100g\) is compared to beef \(228kcal/100g\). While it is true that some vegetables are less calorie-dense, others are far more calorie-dense than meat, [beans](http://www7.slv.se/SokNaringsinnehall/Home/FoodDetails/874) for example. Beans are a more likely substitute for meat than broccoli, making vegetables less carbon-heavy.

1229.2292.text: The 2013 report released by the UK's Food Standards Agency reveals that of the animals killed by Shechita or Halal methods, a relatively [small proportion](https://www.food.gov.uk/sites/default/files/2013-animal-welfare-survey.pdf) were slaughtered without stunning \(p. 4\).

1229.2474.text: Shechita slaughter methods cause an instant drop in blood pressure in the brain that immediately results in [irreversible loss of consciousness](http://www.shechitauk.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/A_Guide_to_Shechita_2009__01.pdf) \(p. 3\). Thus, despite not pre-stunning, Shechita does not result in more animal suffering than other methods.

1229.2510.text: The Halal and Shechita presence on the Western meat market is [expanding](http://www.dialrel.eu/images/factsheet-market-uk.pdf); for example, Halal meat now comprises approximately 25% of the entire UK meat market, in comparison to 11% in 2001. Halal and Shechita methods therefore affect a significant \(and growing\) percentage of livestock destined for slaughter.

1229.6412.text: Unfortunately, Dairy Cows only produce milk once pregnant \(and shortly thereafter\). If a calf is female, it's stolen away from the mother and not allowed to drink any of the milk, because the milk must be sold for money for humans. These birds often experience leg problems associated with breeding, growth and husbandry, and can develop highly abnormal gaits, or become completely unable to walk. 1229.763.text: The [mammalian diving reflex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammalian_diving_reflex) is a reflex in mammals which optimizes respiration to allow staying underwater for extended periods of time. It exists - in weaker versions - in humans, in particular babies up to 6 months old \([Infant swimming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infant_swimming)\).

1229.764.text: Deep diving is only possible with special equipment such as [breathing gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breathing_gas) and [swimfins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimfin).

1229.782.text: In contrast to animals with bodies made for diving, humans have no skin between their fingers and toes \(and thus rely on fins\) and easily suffer from [decompression sickness](http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/769717-overview).

1229.858.text: Human skin is not made for long term stays under water. It deforms and wrinkles [dramatically](http://www.odditycentral.com/videos/what-10-days-underwater-can-do-to-your-hands.html) and finally breaks down.

1229.860.text: Divers need to wear [diving suits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diving_suit) for protection from the cold as well as high water pressure.

1229.2811.text: How the animals are raised does not affect the conversion ratio of organisms on different trophic levels, but it does have an impact on the overall efficiency on a farm. The claim that animals == inefficiency is a zero-sum outlook on farm production, which only holds true for certain kinds of agriculture. In systems-based agriculture an animal is one part of the system, using inputs \(e.g. grass\), but creating inputs for other parts of the system \(e.g. manure\). This can be highly efficient.

1229.2875.text: We measure those conversation ratios [by burning the material](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/how-do-food-manufacturers/) in question and measuring the heat outputs.  This is not a good analog for how our body processes those materials. The krebs cycle is a complex process that involves breaking and recreating chemical bonds with catalyst enzymes. Consuming all the amino acids needed to create a protein is not equivalent to consuming the protein. Protein folding is very complex and we don't fully understand how it works or the energy equations involved.

1229.4148.text: Do means justify ends? How is not quite so relevant when the end result is still the slaughter of animals. You cannot "humanely" kill en masse.  Indeed, giving a happy life to the herd only makes the inevitable that much more heartbreaking.

1229.2890.text: We know that the caloric efficiency of the Krebs cycle is somewhere around 1/3, which is very, very close to the efficiency of burning. Not surprising as chemically they are similar.
